UPDATED: SEP 2, 2014 Update:  This is what Furious would be as an ASA.  Similar in appearance, a bit maltier aroma, more sticky malt in the middle, and drying hops staying sticky in the finish.  It¬ís very present and assertive while staying drinkable.  Nice aggressive balance all around. 
Pours red amber with healthy beige head that sticks around as a film, leaving great lacing. Aroma is hoppy, fruity citrus with apricot and light caramel malts. Danker and earthier now that it¬ís warming up. Taste is grassy pine up front, sharp like Furious but slightly thin on palate and taste in the middle, quickly redeemed in the finish with a sticky finish and enough malts coming back around to complement the bitterness. Poured from can in cellar (at 52F). Pours a slightly reddish gold color, with a thick white creamy head. Leaves a whole lot of lacing on the way down. Aroma - grassy, floral, caramel underneath. Taste - caramel, malty, balanced by hop bitterness, resin/grapefruit. Overall this is well-balanced and I find the bitterness and the hops to play off each other well. It feels a little sticky on the palate. I like this a lot.

Red amber pour with a thick off white head. Great citrus/floral aroma. Robust malt flavor followed by a hop kick. Bright and refreshing with a some good body. Great red ale.

473ml Can from Brewdog¬ís Online Shop:
Lots of hops with a lot tropical fruit notes and a mix of pine and floral hops. There is some citrus and sweetness for a variety of fruits, as well as some medium strength grapefruit and some caramel that gets more pronounced as you go on.

Red to orange amber colour with a thumb sized, thick looking head that is foamy and a very slightly creamy white. Retention is amazing with little initial movement and some great lacing on the sides.

Tropical fruits and a hop-filled combination of floral and pine flavours. There is a definite sweetness to the beer with the caramel from the nose becoming a little more pronounced than with the nose. There is some alcohol in the beer towards the end but this is quite light and the hops cover it well.

Sticky smooth and very refreshing with good bitterness throughout without being overdone. There is a fruity sweetness on top of a medium body and the carbonation is softer than I anticipated, falling somewhere around medium with a nice bite and a very slight touch of alcohol.

This one is a very nice beer although it¬ís not quite hitting the heights of Deviant Dale¬ís. There is a sticky, hop-filled taste of tropical fruits, grapefruit and pine with the caramel sweetness balancing this odd very well.

Good retention and great lacing. Smells of strong citrus fruits and sweet malt. Tastes of bitter citrus fruits, followed by a sweet, smooth malt finish.

Canned 26 nov 2013 and opened 24 dec 2013. Copper colored, clear beer with a white, three finger high, head. 
Nose: Dried fruit, pine, grass, orange, citrus and malt. 
Taste: Pine, caramel malt, tropical fruit and citrus. Sweet aftertaste. Medium body and carbonation. Great bitterness.
Big Can. Pours cloudy deep copper with a small white head and a prominent citrus aroma. Citrus is the flavour as well and some toffee notes and slight alcohol warming.
A great American red with nice hop aromas and taste to start and a smooth finish make this a really nice red ale. Had this out of a 16oz can poured into pint glass great color, head, and aroma.

A bountiful plume lifts a good inch out the glass. The head a rocky, well retained off white cloud that laces well. Sparkling orange copper with very fine and intermittent carbonation. Assertive, raw and unapologetic pine forest aroma wafts like a projectile from the glass. Dry, rough and herbaceous with the softest pleasantries of stone and melonous fruit underneath. Much more mellow and sombre than expected on the palate. Perfume, rose water, pine needles, bitter leafy herbs amid a creamy, lightly carbonated and malty makeup. Biscuity with a juicy cherry and honeydew front, melds into a lengthy, all hop finish. Alcohol is dormant allowing it to slip down with terrifying ease. Found it balanced and controlled with a quenching freshness. Not too bad a drop overall. (1 pint, 16fl.Oz, canned on 10/08/13, Cellarbrations Carlisle)

One of my favorite American Strong Ales. G'Knight does not disappoint. Smooth, strong hoppy, malty flavor. High ABV but smooth.

Off white good sized head rich salmon like pour medium carbonation the aromas pine caramel stone fruit citrus earthiness wood flavours are pear honey pine grapefruit medium bitter peach caramel nice and full in flavour this the finish delicious is the word for this IPA rich notes hops sharpness malt richness a lingering pine and bitter taste good sweetness a fine ale

Color √°mbar oscuro/caramelo. Espuma cremosa marfil. Aromas de frutas, jengibre, resina. Was excited to try this as it got great reviews as an Imperial Red which is a style right up my alley. Boy was I disappointed.

Pours a deep garnet with off white head dissipating fairly quickly. Lots of lacing down the side of the glass. All downhill from here.

Nose is of heavy caramel/brown sugar. Hardly any hops detectable, maybe a bit earthy but malt overpowers.

Taste offers litte in the way of hoppiness either. Sweet caramel malt overpowers throughout finishing with a brown sugar aftertaste.

Very thick syrupy beer and way unbalanced in favor of malt. Any more than a 12 oz. can and I¬ím not sure I could¬íve finished it. This is really a mess and I can¬ít agree with the consensus at all. One of the worst beers I had on my west coast trip.

Can from Brewdog Bristol. Sweet honey nose with underpinning citrus notes and a papaya backbone. LIttle bit of spiced earth as well. Pours a deep, ruddy amber with a fluffy, firm, beige head. The flavour is well-balanced for a beer of this strength - more honey malt sweetness with freshening hop notes of pine, spice and orange zest. I get a hint of tin. I know they tell me you shouldn¬ít, but I can taste the can. It detracts. I think the can thing is a passing fad - or at least I hope so - and craft beers will go back to using opaque glass. Still, a fine drop for all that.
Heavier and sweeter version of an ipa. Orange colour with a full head. Taste is medium sweetness and medium bitterness. Good but lacking sexyness, or its a bad can.
Can from brewdog online store. Clear amber red color, white head. Aroma is sweet malts, hops, berries, fruits. Sweet malty taste, hops, fruits. Quite nice, maybe too malty.
October 2010. Tasted at the brewery in Lyons, CO. Amber color with a white head. Hoppy aromas with malt, fruit, caramel. Good balance and nice hoppy finish.
Bottle. Pours amber with a nice layer of off white head. Aroma of bitters and malts. Taste of hops with a similar mouth feel to unsweet tea.

Caramel malt and piney herbal hops aroma. Appearance is copper-amber a little hazy with white head that eventually dissipates. The taste is nicely balanced bitter at the beginning then mellowed and sweet in the finish. Palate is slightly oily and softly carbonated. Finish is smooth. Awesome beer!

Can. Pours reddish amber with light tan head. Aroma is earthy hops, pine, sweet roasted malt, caramel, toffee and citrus. Taste is bitter hops, caramel/toffee malt, and sweet citrus and faint spice. Medium to full bodied beer with carbonation that finishes very balanced. This beer has a lot going on and each sip reveals something new. Nice offering by Oskar Blues!

16 oz. can drunk straight. ¬íCourse, I poured a little into a regular glass to see what¬ís what.

A: Pours a radiant copper color. The head is a one finger offwhite shade featuring a soft texture and acceptable retention. This one leaves behind a nice streak of lacing as is - I can¬ít imagine how much it would leave poured into a full pint glass.

S: About what I expected: plenty of caramel malt sweetness, backed by some floral/piny hops. Black pepper and resin also pop up after a few whiffs. Standard, but well done.

T: Again, no real surprises in the flavor profile, except perhaps for the balance achieved. The hop flavors (no citrus/tropical fruit here, it¬ís all pine/floral/peppery) are strongest right before the finish, yet they never create a harsh spike of bitterness. The opening maltiness is typical: caramel, toffee, marzipan, earth, and maybe a touch of nut. Well balanced, almost to a fault - there¬ís little here to blow the mind, but the approachability is top-notch.

M: There is a decent dryness on the back end, which (somewhat) quashes the sweeter malts. Personally, it¬ís a tad undercarbonated for me, helping to create a touch of undesirable syrupiness at times - still, this one is easy drinking.

O: These amber/red ales (barring Nugget Nectar) never really do it for me. Having said that, this is a quality brew with a level of drinkability belying its 8.7% strength. Good one, but it¬ís a red...meaning this won¬ít be a regular in my fridge.

Lata de 1pt. Copa Globo. Color √°mbar intense y tintes cobrizos a contraluz. Espuma amarillenta que crea una tupida capa que presenta bastante buena retenci√≥n; una corona que se disipa lentamente y deja un amplio anillo de encaje en las paredes. Aromas de maltas caramelo y tostadas redondeados por notas de higos, pomelo y toffees. La entrada es de gentiles maltas caramelo y sabores de fruta madura que preceden a un ascendente y desbordante amargor resinoso. Cuerpo pleno y carbonataci√≥n moderada. Textura densa. Las maltas y las frutas maduras regresan en el intermedio para unirse a una astringencia c√≠trica provocando una sensaci√≥n agridulce que permanece en el largo final completado por resinas en el retrogusto. El ABV se manifiesta en forma de notas azucaradas. Sabrosa !!
1pt Can. Snifter glass. Deep amber color, copper tints to the light. Yellowish froth creates a close head. Crown shows fairly good retention so while slowly dissipates leaves a wide lacing ring on sides. Caramel & toasted malt aromas rounded by hints of figs, grapefruit & toffees. Gentle toasted caramel malt & ripe fruit flavors at first followed by increasing & overwhelming resinous bitterness. Full body.Soft carbonation. Oily texture. Mild toasted malts & ripe fruit come back in the middle. Citric astringency mixed them & provides a bitter/sweet sensation that lingers into a long finish. Resins on the aftertaste. ABV is felt just as a sugary note. Flavorful !!!

8.9% 270ml for 850 yen at 23 Craft Beerz, Nagoya. A clear amber with a filmy beige head. Lovely floral/herbal aroma with notes of pine & a bit of mild funk in the background. The piney citrus bitterness perfectly complements the caramel malt body & has some lemon in the finish. Delicious stuff, definitely above average-pretty damn good.

Beauty! Pours light amber with some initial head and lots of clumpy lacing. Nose is pine and light toffee. Notes of toffee, cereal, some fruit and lots of earthy bitterness. Tastes are light sweet and heavy bitter. Medium almost creamy body with lively carbonation and a long lasting big bitter bite.

this one suprised me. that is why is pays to get the whole flight.....I would never pick an imperial red based on the name alone, but now I know better. pours a deep red with a nice sized head that stays put. good maltiness and hopiness- better balance to me than the deviant. More drinkable. Hops come through but don¬ít bully the other ingredients out of the way in this one. still really a red ipa to me, but really good.

On draft at Christy¬ís Euro Pub in Greenville, NC. Pours a hazy brown or dark copper color with a white head. Aroma is nutty, piney, hoppy and has caramel in there as well. Tastes is similar with a lasting bitterness. Medium body, maybe slightly thicker with an average carbonation. A very good imperial IPA that is a little different from the rest.
Very nice orange-amber pour and pretty good taste, and just a little sweet. Wife hated it.

G'knight - a beer I've had many times. Perfect because it's in a can and therefore is portable pretty much anywhere I want to go. Poured into a porter glass. 

A - looks amazing. Red/amber color with 2 fingers off white head that dissipates to 1 finger of lumpy head. Lacing the glass already without even taking a sip. Each swig leaves a perfect ring of lacing on the glass. 

S - Citrusy/floral hops balanced by caramel/bready malts. Little bit of brown sugar in there too. 

T - Sweet. A lot of caramel malt w/ nice hop fruitiness. A lot of orange/lemon/lime flavors along w/ strawberry in there. The "red" part of the ipa is giving a smoother and sweeter taste with this one, which I like. 

M - Light-medium. Carbonation is light-medium too. Alcohol completely hidden. Leaves a light bitter/fruity flavor from the hops in your mouth. 

O - Great beer. I love this beer and I think it's nearly as good as Ten FIdy. The fact that Oskar Blues cans their beers makes them portable almost anywhere, which is another important aspect. Within it's genre it's probably the best red IPA I've had.

Can. A clear medium to dark amber beer. with a large, frothy, lacing, almost fully lasting off-white head. Medium to full body, velvety texture, soft/lively carbonation, not long lasting moderately to heavily bitter finish, moderately alcoholic. Rather well balanced, with surprisingly short aftertaste for the expectations and a bit undercarbonated, but otherwise nicely dangerously drinkable.

A - Pours a red hued amber with a giant light khaki head that melts very slowly. Minimal Lacing.

S - Juicy hops galore! Pineapple, mango, honey dew melon, flowers, sticky herbal pine, slighlty toasted graham cracker, caramel

T - Toasted caramel/toffee malt, floral hops, candied grapefruit, grapes, pine resin, hops turns soapy mid palate while finishing spicy. Alcohol comes out as it warms.

M - Medium body, swishy carbonation, can be a tad hot at times.

As a hybrid DIPA/Imperial Red this shines. The nose on this is intoxicating. It¬ís almost a sensory over load. It has a nice malt backbone and drinks easy for the ABV.

Serving type: bottle

06-24-2011
Perfect imperial red. Never tasted anything quite like this before or since. Smooth, hints of mellow spice on the palate, and caramel finish.

Can. Dark amber with thick foamy off white head. Big aroma of pine, orange, lemon, grapefruit, pineapple. Taste is sweet lemon, cereal and caramel, grapefruit, pear, sticky resin, fresh pine. Great smooth moderately carbonated body.

Can (thanks to Bill) consumed on the bus back to Brussels. It pours clear deep amber with a thick yellow-white head. The nose is pine, red berry, dark fruit, caramel and jam. The taste is pine, resin, decent bitterness, red berry, light jam, wood and alcohol warmth with a dry, bitter finish. Medium body, moderate carbonation and slightly mouth-feel. Pretty tasty stuff really.

On draft.  Pours a reddish copper color with nice off white head.  Aroma is heavy grapefruit, grass, and caramel.  Taste is nicely balanced with tons of hops and a welcome sweetness to balance it out.  Not overly bitter and very tasty.
Great Red Ale! Nice solid heavily hopped (but not crazy hopped) beer. Aromatics scream grapefruit and grass. Taste is lovely! Nice resin feel to the palate. Overall, really loved this.

Pine, citrus fruit, resin, caramel, and bread crust on the nose.  A clear, deep red-amber with a well-retaining, rocky, khaki head.  Dry and savory malts, nuts, toast, and caramel, combine with fresh, juicy, bitter hops.  Medium bodied, strong but very smooth, carbonation is thick and cleansing, finishes with more nutty, caramel malts, and a final dose of big hop bitterness.

Appearance was clear light reddish gold with creamy lasting white 3 fringer head, rings of lacing. Aromas was brown sugars, toffee, tostie roll, deep fruits and slight alcohol ting. Taste are sweet sugar of toffee, caramel, Munich malts. Hops are there but sublime. Deep fruit of date, raisin, cherry and spice. Touch of alcohol and rye. Palate was smooth soft CO2 with medium body, then lasting sweet malty fruity wonderful complex finish. A superior Red, find it.

Lots of things going on here, and not all of them are good.  The big killer here is this the predominant alcohol that stands out on the nose and tongue.  Perhaps a little too oily and astringent.  Worth trying, but not re-buying.  Still love Oskar Blues!

Half pint on tap.  Amber pour, clear, little head, adhesive.  Aroma is hoppy, balanced, and delicious.  Taste is surprisingly bad!  I can¬ít believe the rep this beer has for being so heavy-handed and unpleasant.  Too much of a bad thing. It¬ís bitter, hoppy, with toffee and toasty notes, but all in the wrong proportions.  Drinkable, barely.  Maybe it¬ís a quality control issue?   I¬íd like to try it again to see if maybe I got a bad batch.
Wow. Interesting beer. Super foamy pour from draft at drinking bird  creamy beer. Nutty malty and grassy taste. Carmel and sweet. Not my type but a good beer
From tap. Great west coast hop aroma. Appearance is slightly more amber than the red I¬íd expect. Good malt/hop balance of flavor without too much bitter aftertaste (but a bit of a linger).
Poured from a 12 oz can to a glass. Hazy red color with a delicious taste and great finish. Drinks surprisingly well for being 8.7%. Overall a great beer
Draft to pint at Dutch¬ís. Looks good; a transparent amberish-orange with foamy off-white head. Smells and tastes of intense bitter hops and caramel malt with a good mouthfeel. Good beer.

Pours clear amber with fairly small off-white head. Aroma of caramel malt, toffee, mango, peach, apricot and lightly floral. Taste is malty sweet with a wll-rounded bitterness about mid-way through. Finish is lingering bitter. Body is medium and creamy with low carbonation.

16 oz. can. Hazy orange color, with a small, beige head. The aroma is apricots, lemon peels, resin, cardamon, and light rye. Very sweet up front, with spiciness and some light bitterness through the finish. Medium to heavy body, slick, and a little watery. Overall, this is a lovely, spicy, hoppy, and dangerously drinkable beer.

Good stuff.

Pours a fairly clear copper-orange with a thicker khaki head that settles slowly, leaving plenty of intricate soapy lacing. Nose involves caramel and toffee alongside some piney, spicy, and herbal hops. A dash of peach and other stone fruit in there. Taste is quite sweet with a fair bitterness. Heavier, toward syrupy, oily, fairly active carb, with a sticky pine resin hop bitterness on the end. ABV not terribly noticeable. Drinks very well for its size: aside from the viscousness, I wouldn¬ít guess it to be nearing 9%. A nice malt-hop combo that works well together and is quite tasty.
From can...reddish copper color.  Nice palate.  Very solid imperial red.  Pine and grapefruit flavor.  More grapefruit than pine.

Can. Hazy amber pour with a nice white head.  Pine, grapefruit.  IPA like.  But sweet.  Caramel and coco.  Slight bitterness with slight sweetness with nice carbonation. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Had a sample on tap at the Hopleaf Bar in Andersonville Chicago. Pours a hazy, dark brown to medium red, crimson in center. Thick, beige foam atop a full bodied beer with a crazy delicious aroma of apples, malt, and cereal. Tasty and flavorful, thick and wonderfully velvety texture.

Sampled on draft. Nice ruby red pour. Very flavorful malty base with a great hop profile over the top. Perfect amount of lingering hop bitterness. Incredibly drinkable, and very enjoyable. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Poured from a can pours a dark orange with large white tan head.  Piney hop aroma. Caramel malt taste.

Can at bar. Ruby red color, white head. Bitter taste with citrus, caramel, grapefruit, floral hops, a bit of alcohol and fruits. Nice hoppy, aromatic body. Dry bitter finish with citrus and caramel. Excellent imperial red.

Can.  The pour gives up a top full of head, dark red.  The aroma is has a lot of hops in the nose.  The taste has more of a profile of a iipa, than any hints of red.  You can taste the booze, but in a good way.  A surprisingly good beer.

Can.  Aroma has notes of citrus and resin hops, caramel malt, cereal grains.  Deep amber red with an average off-white head that mostly diminished and left some lace.  Flavor is heavy sweet and very bitter.  Palate is full bodied and oily average.  Overall a big brew that is heavily hopped.

Canned 2/20/13 "Happy G¬íBirthday!"
Appearance: Like any other Oskar Blues product, crystal clear. This one has a color you¬íd expect -- red. The head is off-white, meringue-like, and about a finger high. Lacing is spotty but nice.
Smell: A very nice blend of hops, and it¬ís hard to pinpoint one aroma that I¬ím getting out of it ... the "aftersmell" is super sweet, which is the best part about it. After digging for a little while, I finally decided that this beer has a pretty significant pineapple and tropical fruit aroma.
Taste: Malty flavors coat the mouth quite a bit thanks to the fact that this is a red, but the intense amount of hops balance that sweetness extremely well. Peppery, spicy hops burn the back of the tongue just a little bit, and I find that it¬ís a great way to make sure the malt isn¬ít too dominant. The finish is a tad bitter, but the front is pretty sweet, so again, very nice balance here overall.
Feel: The feel on this one is nearly perfect -- it¬ís a pretty big beer (ABV wise and someone heavy in the feel as well), and it almost drinks like a meal. At the same time, the drinkability on this one is crazy high.
Overall: This could be my favorite Oskar Blues offering. Dale¬ís Pale is a great pale ale with a refreshing hop kick, Mama¬ís Little Yella is a must-try for anybody that¬ís a Bud Light only person (since it has a pretty light, but solid flavor), Deviant Dale¬ís is a huge, burning, whale of an IPA... but G¬íKnight is just better, despite how good all of those beers are. Super tasty, refreshing, gets the job done... must try.

16 ouncer to Duvel tulip, I cannot deny this beer gets me for some reason, I just love it. Ruby amber red with many fingers of head and tons of sticky lacing left behind. Pungent nose of caramel apples and fresh piney hops. Huge mouthfeel with sweet malt and hops coming together to create a well balanced brew were hops and malt shine alike. Lemon zest, bread, and tang and all in that this beer taste great way. Finish isn¬ít overly bitter and last just long enough with a lot of pine resin. Glad these guys came to Michigan, this beer just tickles me the right way for some reason... Loved it.
Nice sweet hop aroma. Good clarity with light head. Well balanced with a sweet hop flavor. Smooth mouthfeel.
Pounder can->SA.  Dark copper with thick foamy offwhite head.  Aroma: nice floral and citrus hops.  Taste: pine and citrus hops.  Nice bitter aftertaste.  Strong effort.

Slightly hazy orange pour with a nice off white head. Great lacing. Sweet peach and toffee aroma with citrus in the background. Taste is caramel up front, then some breadiness, and a bitter pine and grapefruit finish. Nice sweet and bitter balance. Sticky texture. Awesome beer.
Pours a cloudy amber colour with thin tan head. Nice lacing on the glass. Aromas of caramel, orange peel.  Superb beer! That says it all!

I love this beer-no red compares. It¬ís hoppy,malty,nice head,perfect
palate,hide the Abv,wonderful beer!

Tap: Reddish-amber pour with a thin white head. Aroma is piney hops with a malt backing. Flavor is pine resin, a touch of citrus, honey and a little bisquit. Palate is sweet malty with a good kick of hoppy bitterness. Nice drinking beer with lots of flavor.
Not sure if its an amber,  strong ale or DIPA but its good.  Nice citrusy and floral hops.
Floral hops dominate the aroma. Clear color with a full, lingering ivory head. Floral hops with biscuity malt background. Finishes dry and bitter.

Caramel colored, clear, with a frothy white head that leaves lots of lacing on the glass. Orange peel, caramel, and pine in the aroma with a touch of alcohol. Easy to drink, medium bodied, not boozy. A warm malt flavor with a juicy hops and enough bitter to balance without crushing the palate. Very drinkable and enjoyable.
Can. Amber/caramel color with tan head. Strong resin and hop aroma. Caramel with hops.

Can. Huge stinky citrus nose. Deep orange/copper color, 1-2cm off-white head.  Big hop hit, but then moves to balance right away / the juicy hopping gets deeper in mid, but the balance more or less remains / hopy and buttery finish. Medium-heavy body, hops felt as a texture. Seems less an imperial red than a big fat imperial IPA. Very good.
Ambrata buona schiuma piuttosto persistente agrumata citrica leggera nota floreale buona beva ma discreto corpi piuttosto secca bel luppolo quadi pepato cirico amaro deciso

Appear: clear amber pour with huge 2" head that was white with orange/red hue. 

Aroma: very light aroma. Sweet citrus and maybe a little rye, very pleasant. 

Taste: pretty Light. Bitter, biscuity malt and rye hop flavor.

Palate: medium body. A little sticky. Finish is fairly clean. Leaves faint but complex flavor, rye for sure but perhaps more like pure caraway seeds. Interesting.

Overall: okay beer. Not worth the price of admission in my eyes. Needs stronger scent and flavor. Rye flavor more like caraway is notable.

For a DIPA, nicely balanced. Not too hot, great grassy piney hops, fresh. Delicious..

Aroma, aside from evidence of malt, is pretty absent.  Initial flavor borders on lavender - dominated by floral notes, yet smooth and mellow in the draw.  Appreciably crisp presence.  Overall, this one came out different than expected for what the bar labeled as an imperial red (seeing now that even that label was casually assigned).  Very laid back for anything imperial - the presence of the hops is very prominent, while the malt maintains an awesome balance - to the degree that only flowery thoughts maintain.
UPDATED: MAR 14, 2013 First can was skunked somehow. Second tasted completely different. Nice aroma, good color (nice clearish mahogany). Subtle red taste. Smooth for the ABC. Not bad.
16 ounce can. Tasted at same session as Deviant Dale¬ís. More red in color, and slightly sweeter. Aroma and taste were similar!

Had on tap, pours a clear reddish, beautiful. Big hop aroma, flavor is hop followed by malt ones followed by hop aftertaste. Reasonably bitter.
Excellent red hoppy ale. Great beer.

3/1/2013. Pours green orange with a fluffy white head. Aroma is fruity, citrus, cherry, some salt (soy?), floral, green tea. Taste is fruity, alcohol, floral; finish is long-lasting floral. Medium bodied; nice carbonation. Highly drinkable; would drink this often.

Can from The Party Source. Canned 10/16/12. Pours a hazy amber with a small, resilient off-white head that only leaves small spots of lace. Aroma of caramel and amber malts, pine, grapefruit, and tangerine. Flavor of caramel and amber malts, pine resin, tea, grapefruit, and pineapple. Medium-bodied, with a resinous mouthfeel and moderate to medium carbonation. Solid DIPA. Glad I finally got around to it.
Draft at Farmers Cabinet in Jan 2013. Hazy orange amber. Pillowy white head. Lace. Orange spice tea. Lots of citrus pith. Light caramel sweetness. Black pepper. Feel the high ABV. Big hop bite.
On tap at the brewery - I¬ím glad they turned this into a season long brew instead of seasonal
Canned almost exactly a month ago. Malty aroma, far more so than expected. Hops play second fiddle until I take a sip, then it's time for piney hops. Like Nugget Nectar, but not as good.

UPDATED: MAR 8, 2013 Hops, you say? This is one of the stronger ones if y¬íask me, and I¬íve had Hopslam, Nugget Nectar, Resin, 120 min., and other notable IPAs/DIPAs. But the bitterest taste does not make for the best IPA, and while this is a good representative of the style, it¬ís mostly pine and grass and wood but little of that sweet citrus I crave in my IPAs.

Pours a deep amber color with medium head. Insane thick rings of lacing. Aromas are surprisingly light but very refreshing with caramel, light breadiness, honey, pine, and a clean floral touch. Taste is bready with a touch of caramel. Big hop flavors of pine resin, grass cuttings, and an earthy dankness. Finish is sweet and fades nicely into a lingering bitterness. A lot of great things happening in this beer.
Tap - pours crimson clear, nice full creamy white-tan head. Piney, resiny aromas. Tastes of nice creamy hops, long finish, bitter hops and orange notes. Medium body, nice and long.

Can pours a dark amber with a good thick khaki head with nice lacing. Aroma is kinda weak for a dipa, i get hints of resiny piny hops and some grapefruit , but this brew has a lot of caramel toffee sweet malt coming through. Taste is pretty smooth and balanced rhe hops and malts really equal out, ends dry, and the bitterness doesn¬ít linger any. Good brew but definitely not my favorite DIPA.

12 oz can. Pours deep amber with nice thick head and lace. Great aroma of hops and malt. Slight earth smell. First taste is bold flavor but mild hops bite.Midway through beer the hops come more alive. Very very good.
Excellent. Tastes like a double IPA to me, which is a good thing. Nice and hoppy, some fizz.

12oz can. Pours a slightly hazy reddish amber with a large long lasting beige head. Very good head retention and lacing throughout. Aroma and Taste is of earthy floral hops, caramel malt, yeast and fruity esters, a bit of dark fruit and bread notes. Palate is a medium body, smooth with good carbonation. A nice combination of sweet caramel malt, yeast and fruity balanced with some earthy floral hops on the ending.  Not overly bitter and with a good caramel malt background. Overall a very good, tasty and enjoyable brew. Nice
Beautiful amber color with off white head and messy lacing. Aroma is very citrusy and fruity. Flavor has nice fruity hop punch up front with a smooth malt finish to balance it out

Aroma of citrus hops. A slightly hazzy coppery pour with a mostly diminishing white head with sticky lacing. The taste is citrus and pine. Medium body with average carbonation. Crisp and clean mouthfeel. Overall, well done Oskar Blues. Refreshing.

12 ounce can.  Blehch. The aroma was grass dipped in lysol.  Appearance was bright glowing red-orange with a slightly yellow and thick head of foam.  Taste was all nasty.  Pine pine pine, hops, acid, booze, pine pine pine.  Palate was medium bodied, fair carbonation levels, and it could have been smooth if all that douglas fir weren¬ít liquidified in my glass.  Overall, I¬íll take a pass on trying it ever again. This was a big face punching imperial red, and it reminded me how much I admire the drinkability of others in the style.  Big and bold doesn¬ít necessarily equal enjoyable, and when I don¬ít even want to finish 12 ounces of a beer, it earns sub-3.0 status.

on draft. poured deep red color with white head. mild aroma of hops at least on the front end. medium body the flavor is bold and hopped very solid blend of hops that match the malts perfectly. solid ale

Serving: four ounce sampler from (nitro) tap at Beer Junction.

Aroma: heavily piney, hoppy.

Appearance: large, creamy, off-white, initial head with excellent lacing and fully lasting longevity.  Clear, flat, orange body.

Taste: harshly bitter initial flavor and finish with long duration. 

Palate: full body, creamy texture and no carbonation.

Overall: everything about this beer was fantastic except for the taste.  It was extremely hoppy to the point where it was really great at first but difficult to finish.  I¬íd try it again, but it seems to be more of a novelty than something I¬íd drink every day.

Look: Light brown, crystal clear, 1/2 finger head. Smell: Heavy citrus, earthy, passion fruit, spicy, resin, woody. Taste: Woody, hop resin, citrus rind, some spiciness, danky, smooth sweet malt backbone, citric bitterness. Feel: Medium-light body, soft carbonation. Overall: Interesting ale. The main reason why I like O.B., is that all their brews have a certain charm. Like a well polished Homebrew. This one has that quality. The clean hop flavor makes it one to savor. This brew is worthy.

16 ounce can into tulip glass, canned on 10/16/2012(G¬íiant G¬íKnight slogan).  Pours fairly clear reddish copper color with a 2 finger fluffy off white head with great retention, that reduces to a nice cap that lingers.  Nice spotty foamy lacing clings to the glass.  Aromas of big grapefruit, orange zest, floral, pine, orange rind, caramel, bread, light pineapple, and herbal earthiness.  Damn nice aromas with nice hop complexity and malt balance.  Taste of grapefruit, orange zest, caramel, orange rind, floral, pine, toast, grass, pineapple, and herbal spiciness.  Moderate pine bitterness on the finish; with lingering notes of citrus, citrus rind, caramel, toast, floral, pineapple, and herbal spiciness on the finish.  Fantastic hop complexity and balance; with a great balance of malts that still puts the hops out front; and zero cloying flavors present after the finish.  Medium carbonation and body; with a creamy and fairly sticky mouthfeel that is nice.  Alcohol is very well hidden with only a slight warming noticed after the finish.  Overall this is a highly excellent imperial red ale!  Great hop complexity and malt balance; and very smooth to sip on.  A highly enjoyable offering.
Pours a copper-red with a minimal white head.  Smells of citrus, pine, a bit of alcohol.  Taste is sweet and bitter, caramel, grapefruit, bitter herbs.

Can at Bishop Folkis, January 2013.

A bit hazy reddish/amber with a large white head. Hoppy aroma and taste. Quite a lot of caramel, dark fruit and malt. Also some notes of alcohol. Rather bitter with a big body. A nice Imperial Red.

Resinous pine and fruity, dank malts. Smells like you can strip finish with it. Hearty amber orange color. Was expecting something bitter and then grainy. Instead this is balanced out across the taste range. Thick, sticky body that leaves lace all about. Not the incredible beer I anticipated; very good nonetheless.

Near perfection for the style! Perfect body and great sniff. Balanced flavors and full appearance that is very inviting. If anything it taste young and fresh, not matured but that¬ís how I like my brew! Try it!!!

Amber orange and clear, with a good one finger head, nice lacing.

A bit of a grainy hoppiness, nice malts, citrus, pine and faint fruitiness.

Tastes very nice. A good, balanced blend of malts, hops, grapefruit, pine, and slight wood notes and fruitiness make for a tasty brew.

Feels rich, slightly slick, moderately bitter, decent carbonation, with a lingering aftertaste.

A pretty tasty and easy to drink brew.

Can. Pours a nice dark amber with a sticky white head. Aroma is really pine forward. Slightly dank. Pine forward taste with a lovely caramel malt backbone. It?s sweet but not overly so. Alcohol is well hidden. More like an American strong ale IMO.

Can from the Wine Source, Baltimore. Deep orange in colour, with a frothy, off-white head. Spicy grains, caramel, some orange fruit, floral hops and a dryish lingering, finish with a big alcoholic aftertaste. A bit overpowering for me.

This does not taste like an IIPA to me. It is too sweet. It really is what it claims to be on the can, am imperial red. Not a particular favorite varietal, I have found red beers to be lacking in balance. This is my favorite red I?ve had though. Woody aroma, like a lumber mill after rain. Slightly sticky mouth feel. Big malt flavor. Hops only affect the tip of my tongue. A little one-dimensional.

Very, very good. Pours hazy amber color with a nice white head. Aroma is soft, sweet, and citrusy and it filled the room as I was pouring it in the glass. Flavor is very balanced -- nice hoppinness against warm and sweet malt base. Alcohol can barely be tasted. Leaves a nice finish that is a bit on the bitter side. Overall, very enjoyable.

Can poured a nice amber color with a thick white head and fair lacing.  Aromas of citrus and light bitter fruity notes with dry malty undertones.  Bitter malty flavors with citrus and hops, light floral notes linger and transition back to bitter and dry citrus notes.  The Finish is clean and dry with malts and hops left on the tung.

Strong, fresh hops are dominate on the aroma. Mixture of gold and copper on the appearance with a fair foam. Flavors of assertive hops and pines along with intense caramel, biscuit and toasted nuts in the back of the palate. Overall, a very strong and well balanced ale boasting a lot of flavor. I¬íd give this an A rating.

Can. Poured a nice amber color with a big, off-white head. Tons of great aromas coming through, especially the caramel and hops notes. Great balance of flavors with the huge hop profile balanced out by the caramel and great bitterness on the finish.

16oz can - pours caramel with thin offwhite head and great lacing. Nose is a sappy Christmas up my nostrils. Flavor adds grapefruit, caramel and orange. Quite bitter but the sweetness keeps it in check. Feels like a juiced drink on steroids - KAPOW!  Great at first but gets old fast. Medium body. Yay citrus hops.

Can at home - 18/11/12 from Beermongers, Portland.
Lightly hazed mid amber with a big big off white head that thins but retains its presence well. Looks the bollocks!
Nose is caramel malts, pine resin, hops and a little cheese.
Tastes caramel malts, pine, bitter grapefruit, hops, light mango notes, caramelised sugars.
Medium bodied with bite, soft carbonation, smooth, great feel!
Excellent fayre!
user_location: Hazlemere, the lower Xhitlerns, Buckinghamshire, ENGLAND

text: Can at √ñ√ñWF 2012. Nose hoppy, grassy and bitter. Tastes full, caramel hoppy. The hop bitterness does not dominate the flavor.

I don¬ít do reviews unless a beer really impresses me.  This is a perfect example of a red imperial IPA.  The only complaint I have is that it is way to drinkable.  At 8.7 abv, it will deal with you very quickly.  Hats off to Oskar Blues!
Absolutely love this brew. Sticky, hoppy, and damn tasty that packs a wallop. Good times start with this one.

Tall boy. Pours a dark copper color with a small frothy off white head. Nose is resiny hops with light pine notes, sticky malt notes with light candy. Has an excellent taste. Very crisp with an awesome aroma. You can just taste the rye. This is my favorite imperial IPA

Can, 8.7%. Hazy amber with small tan head. Aroma is malt, caramel, fruit, hop, little citrus and a little oxidized. Flavour is malt, caramel, hop, little sweet, little citrus and a little oxidized.

Picked this up when I couldn¬ít decide if I wanted something hoppy or malty. Good, solid brew. Caramel, light toffee, citrusy, bitter hops. Enjoying the high ABV, as well!

Light pine and malty sweet nose. Nice piney flavors with a bit of toffee and caramel in there. Lasting bitter finish has you reaching for another sip in no time.

Can at home ... amber ... thin white head ... soft sweet toffee malts (that im not fond of )... light pine passion nose... sweet creamy caramel toffee malts ... light bitter ... soft floral hop ...

A hoppy & lemon citrus scent. There is a bitter kick in the taste. The bitterness soon dissipates. The Imperial Red that it states on the can sure makes sense now after a few sips. It is worth a try.

Growler---->snifter.   Pours DEEP amber with a nice pillowy white head that fades quickly but leaves great lacing.  Aroma is sweet pine and spice.  Taste is sweet tea with lemon and caramel.
