A great beer from memory.  Hoppy but is great for a red ale.  Very drinkble and sorr of spicy.  This bruery does not disappoint.
On tap at Woodstock¬ís Davis, medium lasting head, decent maltiness and bitterness.

Big caramel aroma, with a bit of a hop note.  Pours a cloudy reddish-amber, with a full white head.  This is a big thick brew, lots of caramel malts coming through, with just enough hops to prevent it from being overly sweet.  There¬ís just a touch of slickness to the mouthfeel from the hops, with a full body.  This is a nice solid Imperial Red.
Solid. Not overly hoppy, but it is there.  Nice balance all the way through. Very enjoyable as a session.

Poured from a can dated 8-22-12, so just over a month in the can, sourced at the local Wegman¬ís. Been on my "list to try" from Oskar¬ís for quite awhile, pours a nice amber, thick head that doesn¬ít seem to dissipate but leaves thick lacing on the glass as it recedes. Nice subtle hop aroma, fitting for the subtle-yet-strong hop flavor as it hits your tongue. THIS is the balanced hop-to-malt experience I¬íve been anticipating from Oskar  Blues, as a fan of the Ol¬í Chub for its extreme maltiness and their pale ale. perhaps overhopped (to some people) variations.  Looking for a strong, balanced, malty-yet-hoppy beer?  This is it!  Nice, long finish with both hops and malt in abundant flavor.  As I¬íve complimented about other Oskar¬ís offerings, it tastes LIKE I"LL HAVE ANOTHER!

Dominate floral, grass and skunky, hop bud aromas. Honeyed malt hits the mid-palate first, immediately followed by a wonderful transition of fresh hop flavors of green buds and herb resin. While a big, full-bodied, in your face beer, it manages to be balanced with a great mouthfeel. Long finish.

--- tasted while on a long journey to understand the world around me...

12 oz can pours a clear dark copper color with big off-white head and rings of lacing.  This is the first time I¬íve seen an IIPA (a favorite style of mine) in a can.  Smell is citrus and piney hops, but not as strong as I expected. Aroma is mostly citrrus and piney hops, but with noticeable caramel malts.  A nice dry, woody finish. Body is medium and mouthfeel is slightly sticky, without too much carbonation.  A very enjoyable IIPA, if not quite one of the greats.

Poured from a refrigerated can into a tulip glass. Pours a hazy dark copper with a huge large beige head of foam. The aroma is resin and citrus with a creamy malty, caramelly backbone. The taste is surprisingly sweet and woody with just a bitter finish. The beer was canned about four months ago, so maybe the hops used to be a little more profound, but I enjoy this beer as is. Not necessarily in your face, but quite good and well balanced.
Hazy deep orange color with a single finger head with lots of lace.  Aroma of pine and citrus.  Taste is full of caramel and pine.  Mouth is creamy.  Finish is wet and tasty.

12oz can, canned on 6/19/12. $3 from Beer Run. Good inch-tall thick khaki head. Totally hazy amber color. Ample lace, spicy hop aroma. Smooth lighter carbonation. Kind of a creamy texture. Little dry. Slightly sticky finish. Caramel malts, some orange hops. Medium body (light for the ABV, seemingly). Light sweet and lighter bitter, bit of spice.

Wow, what a huge beer. . . the sweet but sweaty aroma and nice deep red-- can now sez "Imperial Red". . . same 8.7% brew, right?-- gives way to a blistering hop assault that seems to go through several phases that last quite a long time. 

The balance of sweet, roasty malt flavors with the sharp, rich, hop flavors is amazing.  

Now I know why I saw the guy sneaking out of the store with ALL the Oskar cans that had come in that week¬ís shipment. . .
Loved this beer.  Big hop nose and taste.  Decent malt backbone, but the hops are showcased and are so very good.  Reddish in color, sticky white head.  YUM!!!
Nice dark, cloudy amber appearance. Sweet and grapefruity nose. Taste is pretty sweet, a bit of caramel, and a nice dry bitterness at the end.
Excellent all around.  Pours with a tall foamy head, deep amber to red color.  Aroma is a complex malt/hop blend, smooth, nice finish that lasts but is moderate and tasteful.

Found this Gordon in a can ona recent trip to Colorado. Poured orange amber with a nice fluffy off-white head. Nose and taste of caramel malt, a little bit of spicy hops, and then some citrus. Finished bitter. Medium body on this beer.

Draft.  Poured medium amber with a medium-sized off-white head.  Aroma and flavor were caramel malt and resinous, earthy hops.  Intensely hoppy but only moderately bitter.  Slightly oily, thick palate.  Long, dry finish.

A lot going on in this beer.  Aggressive pine and citrus hoppiness with some greater than average bittering elements.  Added to that, a bready, biscuity, caramelly base and body that works to balance it.  Very nice.

12 oz can into a pint glass. Canned on 8-01-2012 @ 12:58 "13 Bucks Little Man"

A - Well, its certainly red. Sort of a dark amber light red clear body with a soapy and frothy cap. Initial pour yielded a massive foamy head. Sticky lacing and retention.

S - Peach, baby powder, pine, and biscuits. Some sweet malts which really work well against the fruity hops. Incredibly unique and delicious. 

T - Peaches, pineapple juice, and some orange. Sweet biscuity malts with a touch of warming caramel and toffee. Just a very faint bitterness. Mouth feel is slick and coating with nice carbonation. Alcohol is very well hidden but creeps up on you.

O - Similar to nugget nectar, but with a peach sweetness. This is a really different kind of hoppy beer. Super tasty stuff!

On tap and served to a tulip at Lunar Brewing Co.. Displayed a hazed, coppery color, with a finger¬ís width of off white, cream & bubbles head foam, and curtainy cling to the silky lacing. The aroma was good malt presence with caramel notes, citrus, fruit sweetness, and a touch of resiny pine. The flavor exhibited moderately potent alcohol warmth, a palate filling hop bitterness, and light malt creaminess to the mouthfeel, all in a medium body. A warmer, more even tempered brew than the just previously sampled Deviant, with the Amber/Red subtleties showing a nice variation.
UPDATED: OCT 12, 2013 Kopparr√∂d med benvitt skum, fingerh√∂gt. Intensiv fruktdoft med mycket s√∂tma. Lite v√§l s√∂t f√∂r stilen.
Gordon can. Pours orange amber with off white head. Nose and taste of caramel malt, spicy hops, orange peel and citrus. Bitter finish. Medium body.

UPDATED: NOV 4, 2012 Canned, poured into snifter glass.  Orangeish hazy-amber color with off-white head that disappears fast.  Aroma of citrus (mainly mango), pine and caramel malt.  Taste is sweet, bold, some alcohol and a bitter finish.  Full body and creamy palate.  Nice DIPA.

Orange with a creamy white head.  Aroma is sweet malty, citrus, pine. Full bodied. Flavor has plenty of pine and light citrus hops, loads of sweet caramel malt. Good beer but not a lot going on, really.

Draft at Jerry¬ís. Clear copper with good, foamy, beige head / Bright nose of candied citrus, soap, cut pine, and bubblegum / Medium body, somewhat  sweet and syrupy, creamy and smooth with light hop bite, with good bitter finish / Flavors of candied orange peel, grapefruit, spun sugar, soap, and cut pine / Very nice in a sweeter style.

I picked up a 4pk can of this at Woodman¬ís in Janesville, WI in summer 2012.

Pours a reddish, orange color with a foamy, off-white head. Scents is rich with malts and a decent amount of bitter hops. Taste is bold and full of flavor. You get hit with a blend of malts and hops that make the taste buds go crazy. The overall taste and texture of the beer is fantastic. Finishes with a caramel, malty, hoppy after taste.

Can 355ml.
Pours hazy amber with low creamy beige head. Good lacing. Aroma is of citrus, fruits (mango), pine. Taste is of citrus, pine, fruits, malt, warming alcohol. Bitter finish. Palate: Creamy mouthfeel. Overall: Very good balance. A serious beer, not very easily drinkable.

Can (12 oz). Hazy amber with a small creamy off-white head and nice lacing. Aroma of citrus, pine, fruits, mango and malt (caramel). Taste is moderate sweet with citrus, pine, malt and alcohol. Slight bitterness (pine). Smooth and creamy mouthfeel with some warming alcohol. Good creamy DIPA/Imperial Amber Ale.

Can @ Cardinal, Stavanger. Great amber color with a nice white creamy head. Rich hoppy aromas! Full bodied, nice bittnerness and some alcohol warmth. Heavy sweetness. This is a beer you¬íll sit with for some time. :-)
Dark texture with good head. It is a mix between a very Caramel and double ipa mix. Two of my favorites mixed giving it a great taste to me

On tap at Dexters in Madison, pours a very dark golden orange with a thick white head and tons of lacing, the aroma is of wet dank hops and some citrus, the flavor has a good amount of fresh hops that is balanced well with the malt in the finish, bitterness comes through on the last sip, good stuff.

On tap 4 oz. sample at Judge¬ís bench in Ellicott City, MD. Clear, sparkling, light amber/red with white head and very good lacing. Aroma of pine and citric hops with caramel malt. Taste of pine, orange, grapefruit, caramel malt and grain. Medium body and medium/high carbonation with a foamy mouthfeel. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Aroma is piney hops and an undercurrent of caramel malts.  The flavor is caramel malts, citrus/grapefruit, a hint of slight sweetness and a long and bitter finish.

Sample at the brewery in Lyons.  Comes dark amber with a decent white head.  Aroma of malt, hops, citrus, and caramel.  Taste is caramel malt, piney hops and citrus hops.  A bit sweet but lots of hops too.  Nicely done.
Taken from old notes. Cloudy amber pour with creamy head. Nose is sweet and hoppy. Taste is the same with a bitter finish and a sweet malty aftertaste.

This beer pours a cloudy amber from the can, with a big, lumpy looking head that is still streaking down the glass long after the last sip.  The smell is hoppy with a presence of grapefruit and malt, and the flavor is that of a strong, dry IPA.  Bitter throughout, with big hops in the finish.  As a stout drinker this is the kind of thing I have to warm up to, but by the end I¬íd done exactly that.

Bottle from Wally¬ís in LA, CA
Glass: Tulip
Canned on 4/28/11
Pours a 2cm head of off-white foam, densely packed small bubbles, very good retention.  Gradually falls to a thick ring around the glass with an island of foam atop the center of the body.  Leaves copious, thick lacing along sides of glass.  Body is semi-hazy red-brown in color, with light causing a transition to a palette of orange-brown with yellow highlights.  Carbonation is readily visible from the bottom of the glass.
Aroma of sweet, toffee-like malts with a delicious fresh, mango-apricot-grapefruit semi-bitter hop aroma.
Pleasant toffee, nutty malt with a strong grapefruit and citrus hop edge, the sweetness well-balanced by the bitterness.  Bitterness becomes noticeably pronounced at mid-palate, then declines from the back of the palate on, with malt sweetness taking over as more noticeable.  Faint ethanol in the close, leading to a lingering aftertaste of well-balanced malt sweetness and hop bitterness.
Beer is medium-heavy to heavy bodied, expected for an ¬ìimperial¬î style, with mid-level carbonation that manages to propel this along the palate very nicely.  Finish is dry and slightly sticky along the palate and lips.

Very hoppy aroma, burnt orange in color. Medium head. Very hoppy flavor as well, almost like an IPA. Lingering bitter finish. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Look is great. Despite little head, a pale red that resembles some IPAs. Taste confirms, remarking on a curious trend of hopping beer at OB. Luckily red has a sweetness that offsets the hop, making the beer fun. Sadly, the sweet leaves a sticky sour feel. Had at Lyons brew pub 7/12.

Another great brew from OB, pours from the can an amber color with a nice white head.  Citrus and some minor pine hoppiness in the nose and flavor is similar with some caramel malts coming through.  Very awesome.
Awesome double IPA. Standard for what this should be. Go Oskar blues for what a beer should be.

My introduction to craft beer in a can.....thanks to my boy a-man.  Just as wonderful on tap at Blue 5 as well.  Don¬ít really get the imperial red part, but it is a fabulous brew nonetheless.  WTG Oskar Blues!

Musty vinegar and mild hop aroma.  I had it poured next to another double IPA (GDB Hercules) and actually could barely tell the difference in color even though this is supposed to be an imperial "red".  Very piney hop flavor - thankfully not musty like the aroma.  Rounds out a bit towards the end with an almost carmely malt.

12 ounce can pours a dark orange color, aromas of pine, and grapefruit with some caramel in the back end.  Flavors start with grapefruit juice, light pine resin, a smidge of honey followed by some caramel.

Amber red   Soft nose   Malt. Hops. Pine. Sweet.  Nice red ipa.  Very good   
         

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

On tap @ Chuck¬ís 85th. Pours slightly cloudy light amber. Aroma is piney hops and malt. Taste is dark caramel malts, piney hops, and plenty of alcohol. I love the slogan of this beer. Big. Red. Sticky. That really says it all. On tap the hops seem a bit muted vs. canned versions of this I¬íve had. Either way, pretty much what an imperial red should be.  If you¬íre shopping cans, this is probably the best you can do.

This is absolutely delicious. Dark amber color with a generous head and ample lacing. Hoppy nose with a bit of florals. Full bodied with a generous supply of both caramel malts and intense hops. A bit oily in texture, but overall a simply brilliant effort.
Great beer. Surprisingly good considering it is in a can. But all their beers are and taste great!
This beer was supprisingly good for coming straight out of a can it had a strong hops flavor

Tap @ Pony w James. Aroma is rich with dark earthy hop and even chocolate. Palate is caramel, butterscotch, hard candy, all balanced by solid hop bitterness. Kind of sweet. Like a richer, hoppier Belgian.
Can. Orange golden pour. Pine, grapefruit, caramel, malts. Malts more dominant than hops. Aroma a bit weak but taste is full. Not bad for a red, great beer.

12 oz can.  Pours a clear, darker orange amber with an off-white head.  Grapefruit hops and sweet honey in the aroma, herbal pine hops adding to it.  Flavor has herbal hops with pine and grapefruit, a little honey biscuit malts.  Moves more into caramel territory later.  To be honest, the flavor is a slight letdown from the aroma.

Location/Date:Can, in the past(before June, 2012.
Appearance: Pours a dark reddish copperr. 
Aroma: Piney, caramel malt..
Taste:Over medium bitterness, plenty of caramel malt.
Palate:Medium body, lingering malt aftertaste..
Summary: My style of beer, this is a great one.
Sampled at the 2012 American Craft Beer Festival.  Pretty hoppy, with a good amount of malts to balance it.  Worth trying, as it is a good beer.
Pours deep amber with thin white head.  Aroma is nutty, caramel and some citrus as well. Taste is sweet with some alcohol coming though.  Overall this was a solid double ipa with more malt then hops.

This hazy red brew had a fantastic nose that resembled grapefruits... and honey roasted peanuts drizzled with maple syrup - insane! The body was fairly malty at first - lots of pineapple, honey and grassy tones. In the finish was the hops - subtle and dry... picking up in intensity as it warmed up. A true rollercoaster of a beer.

In ¬í03 I tasted batch one @ 9.5%, aged a year in it¬ís 25 oz corked bottle. It was much more malty than this one, a fresh hop bomb in a can. This pours a rich gold color times three. Low flying aromas of citrus and sweet carmel malt. The malty flavors then douse any thirsty fires. Long astringent, bitter finish. I never met him, but I can hear the twisted renegade spirit howling.

UPDATED: SEP 7, 2012 A very impressive Double IPA. Pours dark amber with foamy white head. A mix of malt and hop predominated. Very hoppy and bitter on the side. A bit too bitter for my taste. Bold yet well-crafted beer!
Can - big thick head, dark copper color, big piney hop aroma and flavor, balanced by a fair amount of sweet malt
G¬íKnight, sweet knight. But not too sweet. And bitter. Grapefruit and spruce.

12 oz can - Pours medium body, amber/red with fluffy white head.  Sticky lacing. This beer is a monster. Toffee/malt backbone with a little bit of breadiness that is a nice undertone to the big hop bite. A superbly well balanced beer and must try for any fans of DIPA.

Pours a nice red with an off white head and aroma of hops and fruits. Taste is sweet, of dried fruits, hops, and alcohol with the alcohol and bitterness lingering in the finish. Nice brew from Oskar Blues

Pours a nice hue of red, with a small head. Nose is sweet and fruity. Taste is flavorful, with a sweet raisiny taste..... fair amount of bitterness. Landing is sweet, moderately long and bitter. Medium bodied and lightly carbonated. Worth a try but not a retry. Quaff Score 7/ 10

Sampled on tap pours a hazy light amber with athin billowing head.  Aromas are mainly floral and piney some grapefruit and alcohol.  Flavor is very bitter. Body is almost full and finish is dry and astringent.

On tap at David Copperfield's.  Grapefruit aroma, all hops. Well balanced between malt and hops on the palate. Had this beer when they first started making it and I think it's even better now.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Nice frothy pour with a bright orangish amber color. The aroma has nice citrus presence, but you also get the sweet resin.  Taste has the sweet malts, caramel, the citrus, and a little bit of bitterness. The beer has very sticky feel, but a medium body and carbonation. Definitely an Imperial Red winner.
Better than most red ales for sure. Just a big, sticky Imperial IPA  or something,

UPDATED: OCT 18, 2012 12oz can at Capital Ale House.  This was enjoyed with my broter-in-law after the funeral for a good friend.  The cloudy amber ale had a creamy head that stayed with the IPA.  Some lacing for this medium body ale.  The citrus aroma hits at the very first nose into the glass.  A very balanced ale and deceptive alcohol.  Smoth finish for the ale with average carbonation.  Enjoyed on tap at On the Rox with men from a network group.  Excellent beer.  Full of flavor and a drinking experience that you look forward to every evening.

Originally reviewed: 8/28/09. Canned in April ¬í09; poured into my snifter. Pours a much darker than expected tawny amber. A very thin off-white sheet of bubbles rests on top, but doesn¬ít last long. Little to no lacing sticks. Still, this is a nice looking beer. I dip my nose into the glass and I am bombarded with sweet citrus perfumes. Waves of pineapple, grapefruit, candied malts, brown sugar, and flowers burst forth. This smells wonderful.

The mouth is crisp, yet smooth. The bubbles leave a little zest on the tongue as I sip. Decent. This can is a bit ¬íold¬í for a DIPA, so some of the bitterness has worn off. I review it nonetheless, because I still loved this. As time has gone by, the malts are creeping to the forefront. Big toffee, brown sugar presence at the onset, a slight bitterness in the middle, and it finishes sweet and warming. There¬ís hints of what this once was with some hoppy bitterness, but it is tamed down for sure. Still, this is really good. 

I¬íve actually just started seeing this around this area, so I¬íll have to grab a ¬ífresh¬í can and see how it compares, but a few months on this bad boy has done it no harm. Recommend.

A very nice strong red ale, pours a deep amber color with an offwhite thick head. Being so dissapointed with so many other "red" ales, this truly is a "can o¬í bliss", thanks bro!  Very impressed, not as syrupy or thick as some double or imperial IPA¬ís, they might be on to something with this imperial red ales!

Pours a dark amber color with a small white head that goes down quickly into a ring. Aroma is of pines, grass and a bit of caramel malt. Taste is mildly sweet caramel initially followed by a bitter punch. Palate is medium.

12 April 2012, can. Dark amber, clear, some bubbles. Nose is light nutty malt, some pine hops, and moderate breast alcohol. Med body and a tad fizzy. Sugary sweet, cracked oats, faint lemon hops. Nice. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
From a can at home in Sk√∂vde. Nice clear amber colour with an offwhite head. Hoppy, fruity and grassy aroma and flavour with some metallic notes.
amber copper color, aroma of citrus/ pine hops, caramel, toffee, flavor of citrus fruits, caramel, toffee, honey, toast, great balance, not to bitter, pretty sweet, med body, very good DIPA
Can. Hoppy up front and resiny sweet in the background. Some noticeable alcohol throughout. Candy sweet finish with a lingering bitterness.

Great great beer. My favorite red that I've had. Great red hew with a sweet malty aroma. The taste is full of hops. It is like a mini IPA with the hop profile. Total surprise of a beer. Tasted on tap at the District in downtown Tucson. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Tap at Freshcraft. Poured a beautifully clear, deep honey, with a huge two-finger off-white head. Aromas of big grapefruit, citrus, pine, and slight resin. This beer smells awesome. Taste is bitter but refreshing, with a little malt present, but man is this beer hoppy, I love it. Moutfeel is very sticky. Overall this beer is a hop-bomb and so delicious.

UPDATED: APR 15, 2013 The G¬íknight, strong, refreshing, hoppy, and delicious. Definitely for fans of Nugget Nectar. There is something beautiful about an imperial amber. This beer is crisp, sweet, and oh so citrusy. Grapefruit is dominant and mixes beautifully with the malt. Great beer for a summer day

Pours a beautiful, deep reddish/brown with a thick head and lacing that sticks around. Take a sniff? Smell the grapefruit? This style of beer, and this one in particular, takes the citrus notes of a typical IPA and turns it up to 11. Not too much bite, not overly bitter. I like to enjoy this beer in small servings over the course of an afternoon/evening.

Great flavor, aftertaste just a little too bitter to my taste. Sweet malty flavor.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Tap @ Freshcraft, Denver. Pours golden orange with a white head. Aroma of malt, caramel, fruity, grapefruity hops. Taste is malt, caramel, toast, huge hops with floral, fruity, grapefruit like flavors. Mediun to full bosy, soft carbonation, wellbalanced beer that hides alcohol well. 080312

Amber color. Big and thick, resiny aroma. Screams of tree sap. Very malty with a huge hop flavor but not the bitterness you would expect. Moderate amount of bitterness but well balanced against the flavor and malty sweetness .

Tap. Pours clear copper with thin, creamy off-white head; short retention and spare lacing. Aroma is earthy and floral hops, biscuit and caramel malt, light spice, and woody notes. Flavor is malt forward, nice hop character, and light fruit esters; dry, semi-sweet, hoppy finish. Medium body and warmth with low carbonation.

From notes.  First reviewed 6/28/2011.  Poured from a 12 oz. bottle into a tulip.

Gordon pours a full orange color with a raspberry tint throughout. Mostly transparent, a medium sized eggshell head leaves nice lacing down the glass. 

I appreciate a brew where I don¬ít need to waft and dip my nose in, the aroma just bursts right out of the can. Gordon does this. A ton of caramel comes through, with a good blend of citrus hoppiness - orange, grapefruit, and a bit of lemon. 

The flavor starts out incredibly sweet; I nearly overdose on the caramel malt. There is a light solventy character that steps in right after the sweetness, which I don¬ít care for. Grapefruit, orange, and a good amount of spruce give this a solid hop profile, with a light lingering bitterness. 

The body is a little bit light consdering this is an ¬íimperial.¬í Medium carbonation, lots of sticky resin coats my mouth after each hoppy sip.

The intense sweetness is a little bit much for me, even with the huge load of citrusy, resiny hops.

Pours reddish-brown with nice lacy head; aroma subtle citrus hops with malt presence and honey notes; tastes nice mesh of sweet reddish maltiness and suprising hop presence; warming alcohol at the end, nice brew

Deep amber with orange hue.  One finger head.

Aroma is of a woodsy, hop resin, and grapefruit.  Some over-ripe orange and caramel malt.  Really pleasant aroma on this one.

Taste is of the citrus/pine up front with a nice malty finish.  Some sweet candy and hop resin taste.  

Mouthfeel is lush and luxurious.  Sharp, dry finish.  

Overall, this is a very interesting and impressive beer.  Not quite a DIPA and definitely not a red.  This is another fine offering from Oskar Blues.

Pours an orange hued amber with a bubbly offwhite foam. Aroma is citrus and pine hop dominated. Smells amazing. Taste is not as hop heavy. They are there for sure, but the caramel sweetness contributes most of the flavor up front. Nicely balanced. Solid beer.

Can. Beautiful, dense foamy head. Dark blood orange. Noses has wafts of fresh cut citrus some pine and caramel. Lots of citrus on the tongue, in all hues. Big body - very full. Finishes with a blast of coatting hops. Nearly too much , but everything is just on the edge of overkill.Gets quite seet as it warms up.  Pretty darn good - thanks Pete.

I¬íd seen this one and probably drank it as Gordon at one point or another... anyway.  pours really murky and hazy.  smell a little banana, light aroma of hops.  Just looked at the bottom of the can.  canned nearly 7 months ago..   not the first time i¬íve had an older beer from this store.  oh well, i figure a budweiser is supposed to be good for 4 months... this one has more alcohol.  still seems like this really kinda mellowed out.  not much in the way of carbonation.  flavor is a little brown sugar and bannana.  Finish is really smooth.  not much in the way of aftertaste or fresh ingredients.  little disappointed actually.  but then again.. ambers aren¬ít my style, so...
Very easy to drink and the crisp feel on the pallet is quite nice. Slightly hoppy yet bitter sweet and does not linger on the taste-buds.

Can 33 cl, tanks to Marwise. Pours clear deep mahogany amber with a creamy beige head leaving lacing. Aroma is very malty caramel citric piny fruity molassis sweet. Flavor is pungent sweet phenolic malty bitter caramel piny and fruity. Finishes longlived bitter fruity malty and sweet.

Goodness!  From the first sniff of the hops to teh last of the aftertaste slides down your throat, this is GOOD BEER.  Pours a redish dark orange with a light head on top.  Good aromatic aroma.  taste is hoppy and fresh.  Great thick mouthfeel!  Wonderful bittering to the back side.  I will be drinking more Gordon G¬íKnight!

It says imperial red on the can, but it¬ís more orange than red. Smells very hoppy, mostly pine and a little citrus. Tastes like a double IPA. I was expecting something with more body; it tastes like they used corn sugar to increase the ABV. It¬ís a decent DIPA, but I¬ím not sure that was the intention.

Not much of a head just a light coaling, bright amber orange in color.  Nose is hoppy, with a light smell of sweet orange blossom Unfortunately dish washer soap! Taste the nose makes you think it is hopper because it floes smooth and you catch the caramel malt in the front of the pallet then the hop opens up in the back of the pallet. It is a little heavy to have more the 1 at a time but it is very nice

This is kind of a pointless really old rating I have where I just wrote down some numbers on my phone and nothing else.  Sadly, it wasn¬ít incredibly memorable aside from i remember paying about $10 for the can.
This beer was delicious, very potent but the alcohol is masked by the very hoppy flavor.
Coppery color with a substantial and somewhat foamy tan head. Balanced, but certainly holding a lot of hops, there is a malt and nutty flavor that comes to a strong and bitter finish.

One hell of an Imperial Red. The pour is a bright amber orange with a thick, sticky yellow head that subsides to a thin layer. A few sticky lacing spots remain on the glass. Fantastic nose, a nice resinous, spicy hop with a mild grapefruit and a toasty, caramel malt. A bit of a pine note, but mostly citrus and spiced up hop nose. My first sip is of a sweet, nicely balanced hoppy brew with a good toasty malt in the middle. The finish has a resinous, sticky gob of hops with moderate bitterness. Getting a bit of a tropical fruit note with some residual sweetness. I did not notice the alcohol at all. This is a well balanced and well rounded brew. Awesome!

12 oz. can from Chuck¬ís, $2.99. Not entirely sure what separates an imperial red from a NW IPA, but it works for me. This beer pours a muddy burnt sienna color. It smells like a little like a barley wine and tastes similar too. Big hop boldness with a strong sweet malt backbone. Another solid from Oskar Blues.
Pours a clear amber with thin white head. Aroma is hoppy and tasty. Flavor is nice.
On draft at limericks tavern in upland. Malty sweet brown sugar and hops all blend together nicely.

Very tasty, big beer. Can out poured into tasting glass.
Beautiful copper color, smooth head, thick mouthfeel.
Nice specialty malt taste, very good stuff. Tart fruits, plenty of hops. Hell ya. That¬ís all I have to say about that.

Can at home in Salisbury, CT. Pours foggy orange with a creamy head. Huge, rich hop aroma, orange and grapefruit, oily coconut, grass and pine, tons of caramel and toasty bread. Medium to big sweet flavor, lots of caramel, candy, demerera sugar, pine, ripe citrus, light alcohol. Full bodied with average carbonation. Warm, sticky finish, oily pine, toasted caramel. Despite the intensity of character in this beer, there is still a crisp, refreshing aspect to it, which is very nice.

Pours a amber color. Medium slightly creamy body.  Aroma of pine hops, citrus, & caramel malt. Flavor of slight sweet malt, caramel/toffee, pine hops, and citrus.  Finish is slightly bitter.  Good IPA.

Can. Appearance is a solid coppery amber color with a thin ring of off-white foam. In the nose, it¬ís all hops oil, pine resin and grapefruit rind with a sweet coating of caramel. The taste is along the same lines with lots of resiny hops, grapefruit, pine and vegetal hops bitterness. Holding it all together is a candied sweet malt backbone reinforced by wildflower honey and dried tropical fruit. Mouthfeel is slightly syrupy with mild carbonation and a bitter, boozy finish. One of the better hops bombs from this brewery.

A very good IIPA or Imperial Red as the brewer calls it on the can. Pours a redish brown with an off white head. Big hop nose and taste. Not a major palate bruiser, but it is definitely a hop heads delight. Easy enough drinking and very enjoyable even it the price tag is a bit steep.

Ar: sticks malts, resin, grapefruit, pine, citrus, fruitiness, alcohol.
Ap: copper color, medium beige head, lacing. 
F: big bite, sweet malts, Candy, resin, fruitiness, alcohol grapefruit, citrus. 
M: big body, sticky mouthfeel, soft bubbles.
T: a bit Tierd, but still a solid IIPA!

Orange-red with small white head.  Aroma is flowery, lemony, a little bread.  Medium body, alcohol hidden and a touch of carbonation.  Flavor is very good, not quite living up to the aroma though, dry but not overwhelmingly so and a bit of malt.  Nice.

Reddish hue pour with an off white head. Aroma is caramel malt with fruity hops, Taste is phenominal. Nice caramel malt, well balanced with fruity hops, excellant aftertaste, Nice lacing. Nice aftertaste,
Canned sample at Bushwakkers in Regina.  Unreal beer for a can.  Would love to try a  fresh sample
Brown color. Frothy head. Looks good. Smells good. Pine aroma. Caramel aroma. Tastes good. Bitter. Caramel. Smooth. Yum. Me drink. Uh.

Can from Discount Waukesha. Pours orangey-tan with some head, nice lacing. Aroma has pine, sweet syrup, some citrus. Taste brings citrus fruit, pine, some grassiness, sweet caramel and some alcohol.  Quite syrupy with some stickiness. Solid malt presence as you get deeper.  Nice flavor. Finishes medium length, with some sweetness and a bit of bitterness. Not sure how it is described as "imperial red" by OB as I would say straight-forward double ipa with the hoppiness and thickness.
Can.  Clear amber pour with a white head.  Malty aromas.  Bland bitter hop notes and lots of caramel malts.  I prefer the Gubbna......

Had on cask at Cole¬ís, Buffalo.  Poured with very little carbonation and slight white head, dark amber colour.  Aroma of hops and malt and slight smell of something fruity.  With the cask version, I unexpectedly downed this like a glass of water.  Delicious.
Awesome red beer. Goes down smooth and sweet with a small hit of hops. Doesn¬ít taste 9%.

Old notes. Pours a clear deep amber with a bubbly off white head. Nose is sticky sweet caramel malts with grapefruit citrus hops. Flavor up front is sweet maltiness with some honey followed by citrusy hops. Touch of alcohol warmth in the finish.

Pours an orange hued amber with a bubbly offwhite foam. Aroma is citrus and pine hop dominated. Smells amazing. Taste is not as hop heavy. They are there for sure, but the caramel sweetness contributes most of the flavor up front. Nicely balanced. Solid beer.

Can/12oz - Pours a darkish red/orange/amber in color with a medium foamy white head that settles to a thin covering over the beer and leaves some very nice lacing on the glass.  Aroma is hoppy... a nice grassy citrus/grapefruit... with plenty of caramel to back it up.  Flavor mimics what it smells like except it adds some fruitiness... some citrus and a hint of dark fruits... as well as a good grassy hop flavor.  Finish is lingering, hoppy and medium bitter.  I like it!

Oskar Blues G¬íNight pours a beautiful copper with a 1/4 inch head that sticks to the sides like cob webs in the fall. As you draw this up, you are immediately met with hops that remind one of freshly cut grass and the sweet and yet sour smell of fresh grapefruit rind. The first sips are wonderful, malts melded with wonderful hops that leave you begging for a fire and friends yet longing for the last moments when you see the surf pound against the sands. And the finish, well, I am so thankful for the fact that I have an entire glass...it seems I am wrestling with a kind of astringent dryness yet my mouth is watering for an almost bread-like quality.

355 ml can @ Pannuhuone, Kuopio.
Pours a hazy orange red colour with a thick white head. Aroma of fresh hops, grass and caramel. Flavour of fresh hops, quite heavy caramel malts, citrus and some floral notes. Full bodied, thick mouthfeel and a warming finish of alcohol, hops and caramel. Would be even better from a fresh can.
Draught. Clear dark copper colour. Small creamy off-white head. The flavour is very caramelly, almost with a burnt sugar quality. But not overly sweet. Late hop burn, perhaps alcohol burn.

Can @ Oliver Twist on September 30. Pours a hazy reddish brown colour with a white head. Smell is fresh with orange zest and freshly cut grass. Taste is sweet and malty with grapefruit and lemon zest. Finish is dry and bitter. Quite nice!
Clear orange/amber. Spicy, hoppy aroma of clove & grapefruit rind. Med-full body with lots of arid hoppiness & more spice especially clove.
Can at Oliver Twist, Stockholm. Pours amber with a small white head. Smells hoppy. Tastes creamy hoppy and abit sweet with a sweet hoppy finish.

UPDATED: JUN 9, 2012 A: Copper-amber body.. clear with nice bubbles and a robust off-white head ... nice lacing

S: Floral, grassy hops up front... slight malt presence.. ever so subtle alcohol

T: Much like the nose.. nice malt backbone.. caramel-ish... floral, green, lemon bitterness.. nice if not a little mild

M: A tad thin... crisp, refreshing finish.

O: Good... can is a plus!

Beaucoup d¬íastringence extr√™mement bien balanc√© avec le profil robuste du malt. L¬íamertume plut√¥t florale, sapin√© est aigu et persistante. Elle enrobe bien le palais. Buvabilit√© moyenne, parfait pour d√©guster en mangeant.

Pours a deep amber orange color with soapy white foam head.  Aroma of dark fruit, caramel, and citrus.  A super malty, dark fruit, sweet ale, with a big hop layer.  It is classified as a DIPA, but it borders on a hopped red.  And for my money Cigar City¬ís Tocobaga wins out over this.  But still this is a solid brew.
Pour is tarnished copper with nice lacy white head. Smell is floral hoppy and slightly resiny. Taste is citrus pine floral. Good beer.

What an awesome lil¬í IPA! This one poured up a dark copper-colored body sporting a thin foamy head with good retention and wicked lacing. Aromas of lots of hops, citrusy fruits, and a hint of sweet roasted malts. The flavor was not as hoppy as I was anticipating but still a good dose to make this malt-head pucker up just a tad on those first few sips! It¬ís hoppy all the way through until the finish and then those sweet malts sneak in and balance everything up. Medium bodied and loaded with carbonation with a dry, refreshing hoppy finish and aftertaste.  Pair this one up with something spicy!!

Thick gravity; almost like pouring syrup. Watching the head form and noticing the carbonation has incredible hang-time; it¬ís suspended in the middle of the glass for so long before it settles at the bottom of the head...friggin¬í awesome...

Smells piney, almost metallic (not from the can, just metallic in essence), touch of booze, pine-pitch maltiness and some buttery caramel hidden in there too.

Taste is sweet and thick and resinous and sticky and hoppy as hell. It¬ís fantastic to have such contrasting flavors going on at the same time.

Heavy mouthfeel, sticky on the lips, and smooth drinking. This beer has gravity; total sleepytime beer. I passed out 2/3 through my 3rd can, woke to find the remaining 3rd and drink it warm, which was litterally like drinking candy. when it warms, it turns into hop-syrup. I love it so much.
BIG, bold, red, hoppy.. From the first pour to the last drop G¬ínight always makes me happy! This one¬ís a keeper..

Sampled @ GLBF 2011. Dark amber, slightly off white head, big citrus aroma (orange and grapefruit) in fact just popping the top of the can you¬íre hit with the aroma already, pretty malty but great hop flavor. Better than Gubnar.
Aroma of floral, pine, and molasses.  Pours red with a bright orange head.  Tastes of orange tea and pine.  Very balanced for a double.  Sweet.

Big aroma of caramel malt and hops. The taste is mainly sweet caramel malt, but there are also notes of honey, floral hops and pine. Very little carbonation. The alcohol is noticeable a bit too much in the finish. The beer belongs to the type of IPA that has a lot of caramel taste. I¬ím not so fond of such IPA¬ís but this is one of the better ones I have tasted.
Hazy reddish copper color with a foamy off white head and moderate carbonation. The aroma is hoppy and a little piney. The body is rich and the flavor is dry with a bitter finish similar to an IPA.

Pours a deep amber with an off white head.  Nice citrus and a little pine aromas from the pour.  The taste is certainly balanced with even caramel malt and citrus hops.  I prefer a DIPA with the hops outweighing the malts, but this is still a really nice offering.  After reading the description, it makes sense that this is a cross between a DIPA and an amber.  Nice smooth mouthfeel and the alcohol is well hidden.  Certainly a fan of this brewery.

Poured a rich copper color with an off white head. Nose of  pine, citrus, and floral hops.  Medium body and a very smooth and creamy mouthfeel for a DIPA.  Flavor is caramel malts with good hops on top, with rich bitter flavors. Long dry bitter finish. Good to the last drop. Very enjoyable.

Pours hazy red with off white head on tap at the brewery, aroma has notes of nice caramel, toffee,, spicy and resinous hops, touch of biscuit in there as well.  Taste is delicious with notes of nice pine, grassy, resinous hops, some really balanced caramel, toffee, biscuit and spice notes, finishing nice and bitter.  On the sweeter end and definitely the hybrid they describe.

Fantastic amber color with a moderate haze and a lacey off-white head.  Piney-hoppy aroma.  Hops dominate the flavor but the malt stands its ground hard...definitely a balance between ipa and amber ale/barleywine.

Served from a 12 oz can from Baron¬ís. The appearance is a golden red/brown with a dense foam head. Great hop forward nose with a cinnamon hop thing going on. The flavors are versy similar with the hops being a little dated pushing the malt more forward. The mouth is very dry and chewy. A solid brew but it didn¬ít blow me away.

12oz can poured into a shaker. My nose is somewhat stuffed so I didn¬ít get much in the way of aroma, but the taste starts with pine and floral hops, then transitions smoothly into caramel malt with a slight alcohol burn aftertaste. Pretty good.

Can, pours with some serious pillow head.   Aroma is hoppy, color is a great amber.  Taste is heavy on the hops, but no bitter finish.  Still has a slight dryness at the end.  Very tasty, and overall a better than good beer.
Keg at Rattle ¬íN¬íHum, NYC on 26th July 2011. Amber with thin dying head and no lacing. Very fruity aroma. Hop, yeast and smoke in-mouth. Finishes hoppy and bitter.

A Goliath made into a David. Massive Skor bar toffee and caramel malt in aroma and flavor, but balanced with enough hop character to keep its big 8.7% drinkable. Thick and chewy in the mouth, Gordon is a gentle giant, keeping any alcohol phenols in the background while delivering a tasty malt punch.

Aroma of citrus, pine, resin, lots of caramel, dates, alcohol, some kind of spice I can¬ít pinpoint (coriander? nutmeg?). Very small offwhite head, red color. Taste is sweet caramel with a hoppy bitter alcoholy finish. Medium to full bodied, oily texture, soft carbonation. Smooth, full beer. The aroma is quite interesting, smells a bit like christmas.

Draft at Rattle n Hum with Andrew, Kyle and STreets. Pours a hazy amber body with foamy off white lacing. Aroma is delicious fresh citrus and pine hop. Mouthfeel is medium and refreshing with notes of citrus, pine, grapefruit and floral notes.

On tap at the Pourhouse in Westmont, NJ.  Hazy copper pour that settles to clear with light carbonation beneath a shirt but tight off-white heat. Lots of delicate lacing. Initial aroma is of a pine forest but with enough sweet caramel notes to let you know there¬íll be plenty of malt as well. Citrusy punch smacks you up front with milk chocolate, toffee and maybe a light licorice note. Heavy malt backbone. Mouthfeel was just a bit on the sticky side. Relatively long and slightly sweet but still bitter finish.

On draft at enos pizza in bishop arts district.  Pours a deep copper with a thin white head. Aromas are pine, citrus, and black pepper.  Mouthfeel is dry, bitter and sticky with a heavy body.  This was a great beer!

355ml can @ Pikkulintu, Helsinki

Pours orange with a foamy and sticky head. Aroma has notes of exotic fruits and hops. Taste is quite hoppy with notes of exotic fruits and sweetness. Long lasting bitter finish. Refreshing, tasty. Great, quite fruity IIPA.

12 oz.can, $3 single from Ray¬ís, Wauwautosa. Um, no "psssht" when I pop the tab. But it pours okay: more an amber than a red, nearly half foam to start. Nice big hop nose of pine, even a hint of cedar. First impression is a big Double IPA, with alcohol and resin playing pick-up hoops on my tongue. Then the notes of a large amber ale come in, with toast and honey malts to make the whole thing deceptively easy to drink. I know this because I finished the beer before I finished writing this.
12 oz can pours a dark amber color with a nice white head.  Big aroma of hops, citrus, and a huge maltback bone.  Sticky and oily mouthfeel, with a great bitter finish

Slightly hazed amber with a small off-white head. Decent Lacing. Aroma of citrus, caramel and pale malts, and mild plum. The taste is fruity and malty sweet with a mild hop presence. Medium-full bodied, pretty smooth, a touch syrupy, a little dry, and mildly alcoholic. Should be in the American strong ale if you ask me...

[Can] Clear amber hue, moderate head formation. Earthy, citrussy hop nose, sugarry crystal malts. Sweet bready, crsytal malt flavor, medium bodied, plenty of bitter grapefruit in the finish. Decent taste but not a particularly complex strong ale.

(Can, 0.355 l, at Pikkulintu, 20110708) The beer poured amber and a little bit hazy. Its head was medium sized and white. Aroma had sweetness, fruitiness and malts. Palate was medium bodied and warming with medium carbonation. Flavours were malts, hops, citricness, fruitiness and bitterness. Aftertaste was malty, sweet and better. A nice IIPA but again a bit too sweet.

Rich amber/copper color; Medium slightly creamy body; Aroma of pine hops, citrus, & caramel malt; Flavor of slight sweet malt, caramel/toffee, pine hops, and citrus; Finish is slightly bitter; Nicely balanced; Overall, good brew - but not great.

Pour is more orange than red, with a thin white head.  Aroma is very citrus/piney hoppy.  Body is actually kinda thin supported by the hops, but with enough malt to carry it.  I do love the beer but I have a hard time with it being labeled as an Imperial Red.  Worth keeping around and drinking just not what I expected.  Almost just an IPA.
UPDATED: SEP 24, 2012 Very Red, Very Sticky......Really nice brew. Very flavorful, Big beer. I always have a couple of these on hand.

Orange brown in colour with minimal head. Rich nose with loads of hops - passion fruit, pineapple, nectarine and other tropical fruits is distinguishable. Something in the smell reminds me of lemon drops, very delightful aroma. Body is medium to light which makes the alcohol almost to noticeable, it removes some of the freshness for me. Taste is balanced with pine-needles and more hoppy notes of tropical fruit. Coats my mouth nicely. Moderate, balanced bitterness.

Great looking pour, Mango and ripe strawberry on the nose, balanced hop and malt, flavorful with refreshing malt body. Well Built. This beer surprised me. Wonderful finish. Very Drinkable. Beer Disciples Rating: A- 96/100

Can to snifter. Clear dark oarnge pour with a soapy off white head that fades to a thin film. Aroma strong resiness spruce hops and some sugar. Taste is more pungent spruce hops with a malty and caramel mix with a lasting bitterness. Palate is sticky medium and chaulky with a dry finish. Solid!
Smells like a fresh hop! Malty start drenched with a ton of hops. Nicely balanced. Floral spice. Crisp finish. Very smooth flavor and aroma but no bitterness. Very good.

Poured a light copper color.  Aroma of fresh floral hops.  Mild sweetness and, med bitterness.  Med bodied.  Nice finish.  This is very impressive.  Very simular to a df 90 min ipa which is in my top 10.  I will. E teying this again.
Pours a nice dark amber.  Nice aroma of light malt and herbal and citrus hops.  Medium bodied with a nice smooth palate.  Well balanced and tasty.

I¬íve been on an Oskar Blues kick ever since having Dales. Literally Big Red and Sticky. Pours a deep beautiful reddish color with an awesome head that leaves a gorgeous lacing until the glass is empty. Huge sweet flavor. The malts give it a bit of a roasted coffee hint but leaves it for the background vocals. The hops are assertive but not overly intense. Very enjoyable and after one or two you will get that sticky feeling in your mouth, but whos complaining? Props to Gordon, and Oskar Blues for creating this kick ass brew IN A CAN!

Pour copper golden orange off white head decent lace. Aroma grapefruit, pine, caramel, peppery, peaches. Taste caramel, malty sweet, grapefruit, pine ok bitterness, peach, pine. MF medium body light carb. Solid brew quite tasty leaning to the malty sweet side but still quite good.
Excellent. On tap at the Brasserie V in Madison. Dense hop flavors come in waves on a sweet malty backbone.
had this on cask double dry hopped for firkin friday at the tasty weasel.  the aroma did not come out for being double dry hopped and on cask, but overall was a tasty version of the beer. cheers
typical dipa, a little cloying however, the malts have turned a little sickly sweet, even the hops cant fight that off. Not a bad beer, but this one is a little bit oif a chore to finish.

Super thick and chunky, but burns like fat lighter.  Looks beautiful and red, with a head that leaves lace galore.  Smells hoppier than hoppy, citric and ganja-ish, with a malt backing that mimics waffles and syrup.  Yet, when I taste Gordon, all this goodness disappears behind a wall of medicinal, astringent hops.  This bitterness coats everything with IBU venom, failing even to attempt at balancing the heavy, sweet malt front.  I won¬ít go so far as saying this brew is too bitter, but it is too out of whack to drink again.  (12/08)

355ml can. Clear amber pour with an eggshell head that retains nicely. Huge piney, spicy hops on the nose with a real caramel edge, there¬ís also an almost phenolic note in there - mediciney. A little alcohol is evident on the palate but it¬ís rounded out nicely and there¬ís a good bitter finish. Not the greatest of the style, but solid.

Draft at Jonesy¬ís. Wow, that¬ís dark. Tons of lacing too. Big, sweet grapefruit aroma. Really tasty...not overpowering ever. Just really nice and balanced with sweetness up front and bitterness at the end.

Can. The can reads imperial red, RB says iipa...? Dark copper almost red, but not quite. Big offshore head that holds and laces well. The aroma is great, of sticky herbal hops. Very fresh. The flavor is nice, extremely unique, but just a bit too sweet for my taste. It tastes almost like cotton candy, and the toucan hop bitterness only comes in late in the finish. Really unlike any beer I have ever tasted. Medium to full bodied. Overall: pleasant and unique

UPDATED: MAY 5, 2011 Poured a slightly reddish honey color with a creamy off-white head.  Aroma is very hoppy with lots of hay.  Slightly sweet aroma.  Taste is creamy and well balanced between the sweet malts and the hops.  Some alcohol present with cereal.  Hops have some resin.  Aftertaste is crisp and hoppy.  Very good and unique.
Orangeish red color with an off white head. Smells of pine trees and wood. Taste is a bit sweet at first with some pine trees after! Nice maltyness in the flavors. Weeee

Great beer. The appearance is a light amber color that pours with a small off-white head. It has good carbonation. The aroma is hoppy but balanced nicely with the malty sweetness. The taste is very similar to the aroma but it only gets better on the finish with a nice clean finnish following the hoppy middle. Great beer

Sample, draught, trip to the Boston Beer Summit with Luc Bourbonni√®re, savoured on April 16 2011; eye: copper, lightly hazy, no effervescence, tiny ring of tan head, average lacing; nose: hops, malt, citrusy, light orange, light caramel; mouth: hops, malt, citrusy, light orange, light caramel, rather-dry finale in hops with presence of caramel-orange, medium-full body, good carbonation, mildly bitter, lightly sweet, lightly harsh texture; overall: fine
