√âchantillon, en f√ªt, voyage au Boston Beer Summit avec Luc Bourbonni√®re, savour√©e le 16 avril 2011; ¬úil : cuivr√©e, l√©g√®rement voil√©e, pas d¬íeffervescence, petit anneau de mousse fauve, dentelle moyenne; nez : houblon, malt, citrique, l√©ger orange, l√©ger caramel; bouche : houblon, malt, citrique, l√©ger orange, l√©ger caramel, finale plut√¥t s√®che en houblon avec pr√©sence de caramel-orange, corps moyen-cors√©, bonne carbonatation, moyennement am√®re, l√©g√®rement sucr√©e, texture l√©g√®rement rugueuse; en r√©sum√© : bien

Can. Canned on date is Sept 30 2010. I shouldn¬ít even rate this, but I will. My rating makes no difference in the big scheme of things. Pours out lifeless, no fizz or pop when the can was opened. Aromas of sticky caramel and some bitterness. Taste is a sticky cluster of caramel and hops. Some lingering hop bitterness. Not very good flat, I¬íd like to try this a few months fresher.

Tin. Red orange pour with thin fast dissipating white head. Full citrus aroma, mostly tangerine.  Full bodied, lots of hop character. Long hop finish. But the malt prevents this from just being another hop bomb.
user_location: Munchen an der Willamette, Oregon, USA

text: Amber with a creamy head. Strong blow your nose hair out aromas of citrus and pine.  Thin body; sweet and crisp.  Nice, big IIPA.

G¬íKnight has a wonderful aroma that is hoppy but smooth.  It doesnt burn your eyes.  Very floral.

The appearance is great!  A nice clear, light amber beer.

A perfect balance of bitter and sweet.  The hops are not overpowering and you can tell why it is an Imperial.  

It does not appear to be very carbonated but it is quite bubbly on the finish.  Very smooth body with a perfect hoppy finish, that ends up sweet and malty.

Overall this beer is great.  If you are looking for a slightly unique, solid beer that wont offend most people, this is a good choice.  Yet another heavily hopped, smooth craft Colorado beer.

copper color with good hop haze and a 2 finger french vanilla head, good spicy fruit compote nose with some pine resin. Mouthfeel is great, the 8.7% ethanol is very well hidden in nose and taste.  Not sweet even though there is a good malt presence holding it all up.   A sessionable DIPA.  enjoyed it much more than the more expensive Gubna
Dark yellow or amber.  Sweet and hoppy.  A good IPA, but beginners stay away.

pours hazy light red with a thin white head and lots of lacing.  Fabulous aroma of fresh hops, floral notes, raspberries and spices.  taste is plums and berries balanced nicely against a citric hop character.  finish is bitter but flavorful.

Can. Pours hazy amber/brown with a foamy beige head that sticks around and laces nicely. Very nice hoppy aroma with lots of resinous pine, herbaceous, spicy, a bit of citrus. Very little malt, but aroma is dominated by hops. Very flavorful with some more malt on the palate to support the hops, a bit of caramel up front, medium to full bodied, gives way to the hops in the middle and on the finish. Surprisingly, not overwhelmingly bitter given the massive hop aroma. This beer is really a hop-bomb, but in a good way. Massive hop aroma but a decent malt backbone and tame bitterness. Not quite in the top tier of IIPAs for me, but it¬ís up there.

Reviewed from notes.

Pours a moderate amber-red color with an off white head. The nose is citrus hops and a bit of sweeter malt in the background. The taste is a bit overly sweet, almost verging on being cloying. A pretty good amount of citrus and slight bitterness. Bitter and sweet both for sure in the feel. Drinkability is pretty good, but it¬ís a bit too sweet in the end.

Serving type: on-tap

Reviewed on: 11-02-2010

[Can] Pours a light copper color with a large cap of lasting white head. The aroma is somewhat masked by the foam, but includes lots of pine, herbs, and lighter amounts of citrus. Dank herbal and grassy hops abound here. Decent caramel malt backbone, but the balance was not quite as good as some other beers I¬íve had from these guys. Thick mouthfeel. Lasting bitter finish includes light amounts of alcohol. Respectable.

Can. Pours a hazy amber with near white head that lasted throughout the beer and laced slightly. Aroma has a nice combination of a light pine hop, sweet grains and a bit of light fruits/flora. Flavor started with sweet grains and light fruit but was joined by pine along with a bit of resin.

12oz can from Julio¬ís. Drank few weeks after purchase. Canned 12-21-10.

Appearance : Clear shiny amber with small foamy white head. Some lacing.

Aroma : Great fruity and piny hops. Nice malt with light caramel. Quite floral. Light honey. 

Taste : Nice malt with piny and citrusy hops. Finish is piny and herbal. Resinous and quite bitter. Nice malt on finish too. Light caramel.

Overall : Very nice nose. Caramel is light and I like that. Sharp bitterness. I bet it was quite better when fresh. I guess I will have to look for it again (and this time I need to check the date before...)

Pour is a deep orange amberish color with next to no white head. Nose is of all kinds of citrus fruit and hops obviously. Taste is incredibly smooth all the way through and stays rather fruity with a hop background. There is a very certain alcoholic warmth presence also.

0.33l can @ Henrik, Bergen. Gordon is a deep semi-cloudy caramel-orange body with a creamy off-white head. Aromas are a bit low for a DIPA, but there are  notes of fruity peach, dark malts and piny-hops, but still, I found the aroma astonishing anonymous for this genre. The body is really mellow, quite smick and the carbonation is medium to low. Nice oh yeah! This was really nice. Starts of with dark malts, continues with fruity strawberries and alcohol before it get¬ís quite piny, boozy and a strong and fresh cleansing bitterness. Finishes in a fruity and dark aftertaste. I didn¬ít know Gordon Knight, but you don¬ít need to be sorry mister Blues, your beer is really nice :-)

Beautiful reddish copper pour, thin white head, decent lacing.  Wonderful hop aroma.  Starts with some dank citrus flavor and end with a slight bitterness that fades quickly.  A very well balanced beer.

tap - 
aroma - nice floral hoppiness on the nose
appearance - clear amber brown
taste - mildly bitter nutty notes
palate - creamy with a lingering bitter finish
overall - too bitter for me, but others may enjoy it

Hard to say anything bad about this one. The aroma from the tap is almost mentholated. The color is starkly amber. It¬ís hard to believe this one is 85 IBU¬ís because it¬ís so nicely balanced until the finish when the hoppiness kicks in.

Can. Nose is so herbal as to almost be minty; there¬ís definite camphor overtones to this one. Pours a hazy red-gold with a stiff head. Taste is clean and floral; there¬ís some citrus as well, but it wears its hops bitterness surprisingly cleanly. There¬ís even a touch of sweetness on the close. Not a bombast, but a well-balanced DIPA.

At a tasting, thanks YK23, can, pours red with a nice head that dissipates quickly, very hoppy and fruity aroma, slightly disappointing and slightly metal taste, very bitter aftertaste, and overall a slightly deceptive beer.

12 oz can.

It pours a brownish red with a soapy, slightly off-white head.

The smell is sweet with some pine.

The flavor is thick and malty. The hops are there providing some back of the tongue bitterness but the mouthfeel here is super thick and syrupy. There is just a huge blast of caramel in there that makes it so sweet.

This is a thick, syrupy DIPA, not my cup of tea.

Serving type: can

Reviewed on: 12-21-2010 00:34:09

12oz can. 
Orangish amber color, sticky white head. Caramel malt and pine hop aromas - chewy and slightly sweet which helps keep the bitterness in check.

Bright sunshine amber with a thick, white, three-finger head.  Solid lacing and the head leaves frothy puddles as it recedes.

Faint herbal scent with some bitter earthy hop aroma.

Taste is well-balanced.  Some toffee toast malt supports the earthy/herbal bitterness.  Little bit of dried caramel.  

Nice sticky aftertaste.

I had a Gubna earlier, and this is only faintly distinct from that.  Gubna has a little more herbal bitterness and G¬íKnight has a little more malt sweetness.  Both are good not great.

Can. Pours clear red/amber. Thick pale tan/off-white head, gorgeous lacing. Nose is intense, spicy citrus/grapefruit hops, nice big, round sweetness from the malt. Pine character comes off as pine resin, rather than spruce or juniper. Flavours of grapefruit, oranges, some bitter stonefruits here too, nice pine resin and toffee, very light nuttiness towards the finish. Long and warming finish, the first and only sign of the alcohol. Very nice.

An orange amber ale with a thin off white head. In aroma, a nice floral hops with light vinous notes, restrained but nice. In mouth, a good clean DIPA, with fruits, kiwi, mangoes, some nice c-hops, medium bodied, well balanced. On tap at Brewvival, Feb. 26, 2011.
Draft. This is like a hybrid strong ale between a double ipa. And imperial red ale.ots of flavor with bigtime hoppiness and bitterness complemented by a sweet fruitineds. Very good

On tap at taste of Colorado at the Stags Head.  Pours a deep amber. tastes of pine, caramel, citrusy apricot, sweet malt, and toffee.  they were calling it imperial red ale, i went back for multiple samples

Can. Light tan head, dark reddish brown.  Lots of caramel and citrus hops in the aroma, and continues to the taste where the hops are a bit faded.  Very sticky and softer carbonation.  Not as fresh as it should be, but still not too bad.

A little disappointed with this one.  Poured a dark amber hue with a thin white head that had no retention or lace.  Aroma had some nice caramel notes and some citrus hop notes.  Flavor was similar hops were a little more assertive A thin body and overall pretty tw-dimensional.  Finish was smooth.

Not a double IPA but an Imperial Red. Like it says on the can, this beer is truly the "Big Red Sticky" (makes me feel like im drinking a can of LME). Could almost pass as a double IPA due to the high bitterness but there is also a strong sweet fruity character as well that makes this beer a powerhouse of flavor. One of my favorites to take into the hot tub after a nice long day on the slopes.

12 ounce can. Canned on 9/30/10. Drank 2/17/11. Poured into Duvel tulip. 

APPEARANCE: Pours deep burnt orange with a slight ruby hue. Cream/light khaki colored head is 1 finger and has medium duration. Once head settles, thin layer of cream colored film is left on surface. 

AROMA: Piney hops and plentiful caramel malt. Some earthy character. Faint skunk and cereal notes. Hint of alcohol and green raisin. 


TASTE: Hops and caramel malt nicely balanced; with hop bitterness a bit more pronounced. 

Front of palate is toffee; plentiful amount of it makes it seem almost syrupy. Citrus and grassy hops on front of palate as well. 

Piney and slight grainy taste on mid palate. 

Back of palate and finish is bitterness. Bitter finish is a bit lengthy. 

MOUTH FEEL: Medium bodied. Slight prickly feeling on finish. 


OVERALL: Aroma has nice balance between hops and caramel malt. More bitter (and with a longer bitter finish) than I prefer. Straight-forward; rather than complex. A bit syrupy.
Hops. Hoppy. More hops. Hint of malt? Maybe? Nope. Hops. Wow this is a really good beer.

Tap @ Boulder Strong Ale Festival. Light burnt orange appearance with a light white head. Pretty piney hoppy nose with an amber maltiness. Quite piney hoppy flavor with a quite sweet amber malty flavor. Fairly strong hops on the finish. Strong flavor but not all that impressive for a strong red ale.

355ml gushing can ¬ñ the flow covering half of the table at H√•ndverkerstuene. Partly cloudy, red-orange coloured body. A few patches at the surface. Fruity smell of citrus and apricot. Dry herbal hops in flavour mixed with apricot and caramel malts. More sweet than bitter to the ending. Slightly oily palate. Satisfying. Shared with OleR (Oslo, 07.02.2011).

Thick, resinous hops with a malt sweetness.  A brilliantly clear dark copper with thick off-white head.  Great lacing.  Explosive hop flavor and bitterness; dark malts present in the background.  Caramelly and bready, a little chewy.  Medium body but light carbonation.  Slight alcohol slickness and alcohol warmth on the finish.  Great imperial beer.

Clear amber pour with a soft, frothy white head. Aroma is moderate hops, strong grapefruit and light malt.  Flavor is moderate sweet malt and soft, oily mouthfeel.  FInish is moderately dry and smooth.

Canned. Pours amber with a small off-white head. Aroma is pine, caramel, and citrus. Taste is very sweet with a focus on caramel and the bitter piney hops. Though the pine flavor was apparent, Gordon doesn¬ít seem to have the hop bite I expect from a DIPA (perhaps due to it¬ís hybridization between a DIPA and an IAA). Mouth feel is somewhat sticky.

Pours a clear dark amber.  Aroma of bubblegum, pineapple, caramel, apple, pine, and grass.   Flavor is caramel, pine, brown sugar, apple.  It is a crazy mix of sweetness and bitterness.  Quite interesting and complex.

Can 355ml @ Patricks Pub og Restaurant, Kristiansand
Pours clear dark amber with a off-white head. Aroma has notes of sweet malts, caramel and fruity hops. Taste is medium sweet and medium bitter with a long dry bitter finish. Body is full, texture is oily, carbonation is soft.
Pours a redish caramel with off white head out of can.  Strong herbal smell with great taste.

Pours a orangish red with a medium white head. Aroma is heavy grapefruit and citrus. pretty hoppy. taste is bitter and sweet grapefruit. floral hops with nice alcohol punch. palate is heavy with a decent warming ability. overall a very good Dipa

Pours a golden-red with minimal light brown foam. Smells sweet and florally hoppy. Tastes like an resiny ipa with a bit of spice and a little more barley. Advertised as an imperial red, but tastes much more like an imperial ipa.
Pours a dark orange. Aroma is only medium hoppy. The beer comes alive with the flavor. Nice balance here. Hops are big but don¬ít overshadow the base of the beer. Hops are floral and strong.
Can. Hazy copper, medium head. Caramel nose, full body, nice hops. Excellent, overall.

Deep amber with little head.  Aroma is straight pine cone, caramel malts.  Light carbonation.  Caramel malt and hop bitterness that starts low and grows as you drink.  Light residual bitterness and somewhat dry finish.  Definitely grows on you...

Poured into a snifter.

4.0 A: Slightly hazy dark orange color. Two fingers of frightfully creamy head that has average retention and some lacing.

5.0 S: This is my absolute favorite type of DIPA, I can tell already. It has a malt bill that can stand up to the hops in flavor and complexity. Hops are citrusy with emphasis on orange and grapefruit. Malts are full of caramel flavor and dark fruitiness like a barleywine. I smell lots of cherries and plums.

4.0 T: Initially this beer had me scratching my head. I didn¬ít know what the hell I was tasting. The malts (or maybe the hops) put a "chalky" flavor on the tip of my tongue, which isn¬ít necessarily unpleasant. The malts were a big disappointment as it wasn¬ít as complex as I would have liked. Mainly just has the caramel flavor. Lots of citrusy hops in the flavor.

4.5 M: Heavy medium body. Very creamy and smooth. Can¬ít tell there¬ís even alcohol in it.

4.5 D: I would definitely like to have this been again, but not too often since it¬ís quite expensive.

Serving type: can

Reviewed on: 09-14-2009 23:28:14
Can:  Pours a clear orange with a thick off-white head, aroma has pine and grapefruit, medium bodied, starts and ends bitter with a long caramel aftertaste, slick mouthfeel with ample carbonation.

Pours a mostly clear golden amber with large 3-finger head. Smell is bready and sweet, with pine and citrus hops. All of these come out in taste, in great balance. Light bodied, with moderate carbonation. Very enjoyable and easy-drinking for a DIPA.

Huge hop aroma.  Pineapple, mango on a resiny background.  Dark orange and hazy with a thin tan head.  Assertively bitter, maybe even a little harsh.  Strong citrus flavors up front with pineapple foremost.  Fades down into nice carmel and vanilla notes from the malt.  Alcohol is strong but not overwhelming.  Nice beer when you¬íre only having one.
Can: The label just states. ALE, so I¬¥ll rate is as such. Nice malty sweetness, full flavor with a nice subtle hops presence. As for a DIPA? Where does that come from? Food Pairing: Lasagna.

Tasted on 12/18/10 from a 12oz can purchased at Sun Devil, canned on 06/18/10.  Pours light amber with an average white head that leaves a pretty thick bubbly lace.  The nose is intensely bitter resin hops with some floral and citrus notes.  There is also a nice bread malt backbone.  The flavor starts off with sweet caramel malt, but then moves onto the citrus and resin hops, leaving a nice bitter finish.  The body is medium plus with average carbonation and a long resin bitter finish.  The flavors are all very well integrated, but the hops could come through a little more for my taste.

Poured a beautiful Amber color with a nice head that clinged very nicely to the glass.  Very citrusy with very nice malts coming though on the smell.  Very fruity with peach, raisin, and some carmely malts on the taste, not as bitter as expected.  Even though this is 8.7% i tasted not alcohol.  Overall a very all around satisfying and surprisingly drinkable for the style.  Highly recommended

Shared 0,33l can at Cardinal. Hazy amber with a creamy white. Good lacing. Rich hoppy notes of flowers and peaches, fruit drops. Most inviting. Full bodied with heavy sweet, bitter flavors, an alcoholic warmth and light toasted tobacco tones. Dry finish.

12oz can. Pours a deep golden amber with a small creamy off white head. Aroma is sweet toasty bread, caramel with plenty of citric and piney hops very well balanced sweet and hoppy. Flavor starts sweet very rich caramel and a touch candyish. Picks up a nice amount of citric fruity notes before the aggressive piney bitter hops come in through the finish. Medium body and a softer carbonation.Very well balanced and tasty beer

Red pour and not lasting head.  Nose is very hoppy and caramel malts.  Floral, lightly toasty, light alcohol, and citrus.  Taste is American citrus hops up front and sweet caramel malt backing.  Good blend of cara malts and hops.  Medium to full body, smooth and creamy.  Good brew. Thanks to Phillybeer 1779!

Trasparent redish orange.  Smells of fresh cut grass, pine neddles wet hops, with a hint of Carmel malt sweetness.  Medium bodied and super clean.  Chewy resiny hops dominate the flavor with a bit of orange rind and spice.  This beer really suits my tastes, layerd and flavorfull without being over the top, well crafted, excellent beer.

UPDATED: APR 9, 2011 Nice red color. Sweet at first taste and the more bittering hops come in at the end, but it is superbly balanced. Unfortunately I was eating with the beer and it kind of messed up my palate. I liked it, but I need to try it again at home without food.

I need to try it again, this rating is not definitive yet.
Another great can. Deep imp amber balanced by great heavy and resiny hops. One of the best malt forward big ipas I¬íve had.. interesting and lets me know it can be done this well.
Sample at SBWF 2010. Pours amber with an off-white head. Very nice balance between the malt and hop flavors. Heavy, fat and with lots of tropical fruit aromas. Lovely IIPA!

Palate rocks with dryness and some silky carbonation while the flavor brings on a good dose of citrus juiciness. I love the flowery grapefruit knockout aroma. Alcohol is not well hidden though. Malt base doesn¬ít seem to balance the bitter tones either.
Dubbel-IPA med massor av tropisk frukt, stickig humlejuice, aningenss r√•tt k√∂tt f√§rskt tr√§ och rej√§l grapebeska. Gott
A big toffee beast, underpinned with resiny hops, and an oily, almost whipped-cream mouthfeel. Certainly an interesting beer, though almost a little too much toffee/caramel.

UPDATED: APR 30, 2011 THIS ONE POURS A CHERRY RED WITH A HUGE THICK TAN HEAD IT SMELLS OF RICH STRONG HOPS AND A HINT OF STRAWBERRIES. THIS SEEMS LIKE A SUBTLE IMPERIAL IPA MIXED WITH A STRONG ALE (TWO OF MY FAVORITE TYPES OF BEER) THE FLAVORS ARE OF UPFRONT HOPS BITTERNESS THAT DOESN¬íT LINGER IN THE MOUTH MIXED WITH  A HINT OF VANILLA SWEETNESS. INCREDIBLY SMOOTH AT NEARLY 9% ALC. CONTENT WITH AN ABUNDANCE OF FLAVOR, TRULY A GREAT  CANNED BEER .

For those you question good beer from a can, you must try this beer! This could be my favorite IPA from Colorado. It¬ís as if they stuffed whole hops into the can! Crisp clean hoppy aroma and a perfect fresh taste. One of my all time favorites! Try it if your lucky to get your hands on one. It¬ís worth the extra money.
12oz can - Orange with thick tan head.  Flavor and nose reminded me of OJ concentrate, just not as sweet.

A lusterous amber color with a nice head that lends no inkling of departing. Smell is sharply resiny, almost surprisingly so, with good candy notes in the background. Also making an appearance are orange peel, and maybe caramel. Taste is even better than the smell. The hop presence isn¬ít as overpowering as one might expect from the aroma. Sweet with some good orange peel and then the resin that was so strong in the aroma comes around to tap your tongue out at the end.

Sampled at Great Lakes Brew Fest in Racine, WI.  Aroma hops kinda smokey.  Appearance copper not much head.  Taste hoppy, light smoked malt, mostly hoppy.  Can¬ít argue with an aggressively hopped beer!  Definitely want to have this again.
UPDATED: SEP 18, 2010 At a tasting: piny and citrusy hoppy aroma, quite malty, caramel, the flavor the same, not very hoppy, strong rich malt is quite dominant, good beer.
At a tasting, thanks Yuval, pours deep orange with a medium head, aroma of grapefruit, pine, peach and orange, dry flavor with grapefruit, tangerine and orange, medium to full body, nice.
Best beer ever to come out of a can.  Slightly over hopped but with incredible malt to balance.  Beautiful red ale.

Bottle sample at a tasting. Thanks Yuval. Clear reddish amber. Aroma of resinous hops, some pine, light citric hints, caramel, malt and a bit of cookies. Bittersweet flavor of piney and resinous hops, grainy hints, malt, caramel and a bit of honey. Medium to full-bodied.

Great beer thanks to Don.  Pours amber with a very small white head.  Aroma is almost all hops, sweet and some caramel.  Taste is bold hop flavour and dry hop bitterness.  Sweet and syrupy with caramel undertones if you can get by the hop blast.

At a tasting, thanks yk23, small head, clear cherry red colour, aroma of pine and orange marmalade, flavour of pine and touches of barnyard with a candy sweetness and a light bitterness, not even regular IPA standard. Not really good

Deep copper color in the glass.  Fruity/piney hop aroma that shows amazing depth.  Slightly sweet caramel malt and quite bitter hops come together really well on the palate.  Another very solid offering from Oskar Blues.

UPDATED: MAR 4, 2011 Pours a clear and dark amber with a pretty thick cream colored head. Aroma of sweet caramel, sticky grassy hops, grapefruit, peaches, and...wood?  Flavor holds a solid malt backbone with a nice resinous grassy hop complexity on the forefront.  But the hops never over-dominates, just like a good DIPA. Mildly complex, full bodied, balanced, and just pure straight delicious.  Oskar Blues best work

Can. Attractive red with lasting head. Amazing hoppy aroma that won¬ít quit, honey and hyacinths, rosemary and thyme, metal. Sweetness stronger than bitterness, would probably prefer more bitterness in the balance. I think Shark Attack is better, but this is easier to obtain.

UPDATED: SEP 4, 2011 Rerated at Rotary after-party vs GBF 2011 cons 2011-09-02
New rating 3,9 new average 3,9

Can at Rover 2010-09-05, G√∂teborg (a last beer to go, one too many)
AR:  north american hops, toffee
AP: redddish/brown body, creamy rocky yellow head
F: hoppy, vanilla, great maltiness, caramel, citrus, great bitter finish
Lovely creamy curtains
Golden yellow orange in color. Strong earthy hoppy nose. Nice bitter hop and earth flavor. Great beer.

Poured a clearish amber with a 2 finger white head, faded and left tons of sticky lace.  Aroma was of big time spicy hops, earthiness, and tinge of citrus, some caramel malts, a bit of bread like malt, and absolute goodness.  This stuff tastes a lot better than it smells, and it smells great.  Flavors start out hoppy, lots of hop spiciness, some caramel sweetness, laid back bitterness in the finish.  This stuff is incredible.  Rock on.
12 oz. can.  by far my favorite beer I ever had in a can.  dark red color, hoppy, and smooth.  add the alcohol content and this one is tough to beat.

355mL can, pours a beautiful amber with a small off-white head. Aroma of soothing pine hops, pungent floral notes, grapefruit, apricot, and with a strong caramel malt backing. Flavour begins with grapefruit, toffee and caramel, with the resinous hops kicking in toward the middle and are full-throttled by the end - little bit of an alcohol kick at the end as well. Excellent IIPA.

Can at Bishops Arms, Karlstad. Pours a sligthly hazy orange-amber color with a mediumsized white head, some lacing. Aroma of pine needles, resin, grapefruit, apricot and caramel. Flavour is pine needles, resin, grapefruit, citrus and caramel with lingering balanced bitterness. Rather sweet and malty with lots of toffee also. Carbonation is average to lively. Fullbodied. A nice beer, though it¬ís a bit sweet maybe.

Can from Bottleworks in Seattle. Pours copper/amber. Nice aroma of cutrusy-pineapple, sticky, resiny hops. Also some sweet caramel malts. Flavour is strong bitter grapefruit, citrus, biting hops, again a nice sweet malty balance, and a wonderful alcohol warming finish. Excellent!

Can, 12 fl.oz. Pours a clear amber beer with a beige head. The aroma is hops with citrus and grapefruit and slight notes of malt and caramel. The flavor is close to the nose with more sweetness. The palate is bitter. Overall a really great beer.

Here¬ís the thing, the can doesn¬ít really tell ya much about the beer.  It says it¬ís an ale, but doesn¬ít go into just how past an IPA the beer is.  I¬ím sure it¬ís not a bad beer for those who like IPA¬ís.  But I just can¬ít say I like it.

Can. Dark amber, slightly off white head, big citrus aroma (orange and grapefruit) in fact just popping the top of the can you¬íre hit with the aroma already, pretty malty but great hop flavor. Out of a can!

On Tap at Fuel and Fuddle, Oakland Pittsburgh.  Very nice IPA, not quite a double though.  clear red amber, with no head but some lacing, plenty of hops and a wide variety which makes for a full mouth and great beer.

Hops. Hops. Hops.  If there were an inbetween for the Elder and the Younger.  This would be Pliny v3.0.  incredible when straight off the line at OB, and a kick in the mouth from the can.  Not the hoppiest beer I¬íve come across, but a fine refreshment indeed.

Cask at GBBF 2010. An orange/amber coloured pour with a medium white head on top. A really lovely aroma of sweet malt and caramel. Taste is sweet malt, caramel, spice, hops, tropical fruit, butterscotch. Absolutely bloody delicious.

Well i keep on being told that craft beer can be found in cans these days but this brewer is currently the only one that I know of doing such offerings as their primary thing. Poured into a flouted beer glass this amber brew had a one finger head. The aroma was citrus hop which i found to lean toward orange as well as grapefruit. There was also caramel malt smells. The taste was of course bitter but also more orange sweetness. Much more manageable than I would have expected from a DIPA but over all enjoyed.

Good but not amazing...nice strong hoppy nose, then full bodied and candied hop flavor, clean finish.  

I think it¬ís good, but overall I prefer a strong IPA to a DIPA because I¬ím not as big a fan of heavy pale ales or the sweet full body that doubles produce.

Canned 04-05-10. Clear, amber/reddish colour, medium off-white head. Hoppy aroma, mostly pine, some citrus, also a whiff of alcohol and a some fresh bread.  Medium body  with a nice maltiness, soft medium bitterness, piney hops, alcohol. Generally I like my IPA:s a bit more attenuated, that said, this is one of my favourite canned beers to this date. A good one!

Appearance: Pours a deep caramel brown with a 1 finger creamy tan head. Nice lacing throughout.

Smell: A nice mixture of malty sweetness with a hint of caramel along with strong citrus hops.

Taste: A complex mixture of sweet caramel and citrus. Nice bitterness at the finish with a hint of alcohol.

Mouthfeel: Medium bodied with just the right amount of carbonation. Sticky, but in a nice way.

Drinkability: Very high drinkability. It doesn¬ít seem nearly as heavy as the 8.7% ABV would typically indicate. You could down a few without a problem.

Overall: Very good representation of the style. This is proof that good beer can come in a can. I would highly recommend it.

Nice hops and malt at first followed by an unbalanced finishing blast of alcohol. Very malty and hoppy on the nose (about 60-40). Looks beautiful...dark red, almost brown, hazy and inviting. Definitely more of an imperial amber then iipa in my humble opinion. Good be great with a bit more balance.

First off this beer looks great. Bright reddish orange topped by a thick creamy head that retains throughout. While not overwhelmingly bursting with hoppy citrus aromas, the smell harmonizes fresh hop pine and sweetness resulting in an enticing and refreshing nose. I expected a mouthful of sticky hop bitterness, but was pleasantly surprised by a full load of caramel maltiness. Toffee, buttery biscuit malt flavors orchestrate the palate and are gracefully followed by a sharp hoppy aftertaste. Though I am typically less fond of malts overshadowing hops in an IPA, this dynamic works well for me. The soft piney hop flavors play off the caramel malt sweetness with a unique likeability. The beer feels smooth and rich and is quite drinkable. I can¬ít say I¬ím blown away, but definitely another impressive offering from Oskar Blues.

Not a great beer at all, not terrible, I wouldnt buy it again. I was expecting substantially more. Can from Hamiltons, hop aroma was stale and smelled like broccoli, poured darker than I expect an IPA to pour, and no real hop flavor.

Thanks to jgasparine for this brew!  12 ounce can, canned on 3/15/2010.  Served in a Sam Adams BL glass, the beer pours an amber/red color with about a half inch off-white head.  Head retention and lacing are both decent.  Aroma is grassy and citrusy (grapefruit and tropical fruit) hops, caramel malt, and a bit of spice.  The taste is similar to the aroma, however the bitter hops come out much more in the taste compared to the aroma which I thought was fruitier and sweeter.  Mouthfeel/body is medium, it¬ís a bit creamy and slick, and is well carbonated.  Drinkability is good, it certainly wasn¬ít hard to finish this brew!  Not a bad beer overall, I liked it.

had a can at a recent beer event.  had lot¬ís o beers that night but this one stood out the most.  aromas of sweet malts and floral.  good flavor. immediately noticed the very very sweet, candy like taste and syrupy mouthfeel.  big on ABV which is noticeable.  finished rather quickly but the mouthfeel lingered.  overall i liked it but it was almost a little to sweet for me tat night.

Aroma of pine,resin and bready malt.Flaour is exotic fruits,pine ,sweet malty grains,sugar and hops,Full body ,soft carbonation.Very nice full bodied beer.

Can dated 3.15.10, with the phrase "Hiphopsynonymous" printed on the bottom.  Awesome.  Pours deep ruby red with a foamy light brown head.  Aromas of sweet pine, sugary citrus, juniper, and a bit of alcohol.  Sweet sugary pine flavor with slight orangepeel, bitter grass, and resinous pine.  Finish is sweet malt and alcohol.  This is rich, thick, syrupy, and warming.  This is really nice, and well-balanced, although pretty expensive.
Canned of course.  Poured dark, some earthiness and some caramel. The hops were pretty mild. good.

From a can into a pint glass.  Pours dark red with fluffy, sticky head and lots of lacing.  Aroma is of piney hops.  Mouthfeel is sticky and thick.  A little too much carbonation for my tastes.  Taste is totally of piney hops.  Not much balance or depth to the taste, just hops.  I haven¬ít been a big fan of Oskar Blues¬í IPA¬ís so far.  They have this weird after/hind taste to them which is very off putting.  Meh, better IPAs out there.

Gordon was my first introduction to Oskar blues. beer in a can i thought cant be good. But the local beer master in flagstaff az insisted. I was in heaven just enough hops the right amount of alcohol. perfect.

Poured orange and hazy with a whippy thick off white head aromas are of pine,citrusand floral notes taste is of the same with a bitter grab your tounge ipa quality that you hop heads love i have respect just not my thing

I¬íll cut to the chase.....this is one fine brew!  Gorgeous hazy copper gold colour with a thin eggshell head.  As it warms, the bouquet fully develops into a complex mix of citrus, evergreen, and floral hops backed by a strong alcohol tingle.  Thick, oily, some roastiness, sweet malt and a lingering bitter finish.  Not a pounder, but more of a get home from work sipper.  Another super offering from Oskar Blues!
Can. Golden- orange colour with an off-white head. Aroma is pine, peaches, grapefruit. Flavour is sweet, pine, peaches, grapefruit, hop. bitter finish. Nice beer.

Pours a nice amber with a light white head.   Holy cow, did this come out of a can?!  

Nice sweet attack which fades to a lovely balanced, very hoppy finish.  Very good.

amberish/red with a medium head.  a bit sweet.  not that powerful on the hops especially for a double IPA.  i could tell it had a bit of an alcohol kick. it was a good beer, but my least favorite of the oskar blue¬ís varieties i¬íve tried thus far.

Amber/orange beer with a small white head. Aromas of floral hops, pine, and abundant hops. Taste is pretty solid but did not wow me. Tastes of pine/spruce, lots of bitter hops. Refreshing and zesty with a slight citric aftertaste. Good beer.

Gordon is among the best Oskar Blues has to offer.  Copper, red body, thin white head.  Various hops nose with the usual mix of pine, citrus, and floral.  Very well balanced in the flavor with malt/grains coming through.

UPDATED: NOV 28, 2012 Gordon: Wow... let me say WOW.  I was really impressed with this one.  Much more so than Gubna.  Has a cloudy amber color with a thin head.  Aroma is seriously hoppy.  Nice!... Sweet and malty and sticky... a slight roast characteristic.  Light on the palate, but hardy.  Bitter, alcoholic finish.  Really, really good... 
And then, enter G¬íKnight in 2011.

G¬íKnight, 25 whole IBUs less bitter, is just as good.  It still boasts a dark orange color, but the body of the beer seems to have improved.  Its off-white head is thicker, stickier, and leaves behind gorgeous, thick lacing.  The aroma is of a soft, but acutely refreshing bouquet of gorgeous hops, coupled with the dark caramel sweetness of crystal malts.  It¬ís thin in the mouth, but extremely refreshing and easy to drink, leaving you with a sharp finish of bold, fresh hop cones and alcohol.  It feels like a hop flower has actually gotten stuck in my sinuses.  Ah, heaven.  The thick sweetness is well-balanced by the beer¬ís thin body and alcohol presence, and a great flavor profile of hops decorates the whole experience quite awesomely.  It¬ís an incredibly delicious beer and worthy of representing.
UPDATED: SEP 8, 2010 Pours a nice amber colour with lots of white head and lacing.  Citrus/pine aroma. Tastes of citrus, pine, and malt. Not a bad beer.

Deep golden color with an orange tint ...... sweet malt and piney citrusy hop aroma ..... citrusy hop taste with sweet malts and caramel lots of bitterness in this one with a dry citrusy hop finish ..... can taste a little abv in it .... if you love a bitter hop this is up there

Wow...huge aroma when poured into a pint glass. It really hits hard. I get cirtus/grapefruit & malt nose. Head is beautiful, thick, and reasuring that I am about to taste something good. Nice thing is that is fades fast enough to get some more aroma. Decent legs for this style beer too. Taste is pine, malty sweet with hop bitterness on the finsh. I also get a definite alcohol undertone, which I like a lot. I am very interested in trying more of their beer. Tasted from the can @ 60.4¬∞F.

12oz can served in a shaker pint. Poured a slightly hazy reddish gold with a finger of off white head. Fragrant with piney hops and also some caramel malt. Medium bodied with a rich mouthfeel. Nice and malty with a good amount of hop bitterness to balance the sweetness out. Very drinkable for the ABV. Another solid beer from Oskar Blues.
The overall malty sweetness dominates in aroma and flavor. The ruby amber color has a small bubbly head. It is smooth, especially out of the can.

poured a slightly cloudy amber color with a whispy white head that lasts.  Up front hop citrus aroma.  Some malt sweetness hidden in the citrusy, grassy hop flavor.  Medium body, moderate hop bitterness that lingers.  Overall a wonderful beer.

I poured this 12 oz can (natch) into a snifter, the better to observe its deep orange-umber body and noticeable lacing. The beer raised a fleeting one-inch head, then settled into its attractive body. The nose is from the grassy side of hops rather than the citrus side (if that makes sense), but it¬ís clear that there are more than enough hops here to counteract the heavy malt spine. This goes down smoothly, with a lingering malt sweetness washing away both the hop bitterness and the abv burn. Without a doubt, this is my favorite offering from Oskar Blues.

12 oz can served in a tulip.  Pour is highlighted amber with 2 inches of foamy white head on top.  Nose is hops, but not the kind that hit like a mack truck, pine tar, light citrus, and a nice malty backbone.  Taste is right on with a wonderfully mellow palate, followed by lovely finish with just a tad bit of boozy taste.  This is a fantastic brew!  It is similar to Gubna, just not as much citrus, and the hops are there for taste, not to prickle the skin.  Both are amazing and I¬ím starting to think Oskar Blues can¬ít make a bad beer :)

On tap, poured into a pint glass at just below room temp.  Exhibits a rich copper amber color. Very nice lacing but not great head formation or retention. Fresh and lively hops on the nose with just a hint of malt sweetness. Mouthfeel has a malty rich texture with a lighter than expected body and just the right amount of carbonation. Not super bitter but consistently hoppy across the palate with a very subdued and light malt. Its not a resiny as a lot of DIPAs but the hops are still the the star of the show, staying fresh and piny on the tongue. Overall I would say this one is just as drinkable as any good regular IPA while still packing the higher abv. A truly unsung gem in the double IPA world.

Pours light brown with a slight reddish tint and a thin white bubbly head. Aroma is of pine needles, citrus, and light fruits. Taste is very floral and ends in a bitter sweet finish and a slight warming sensation. Very good.

Drank from a goblet glass from the taps at Hop Devil, NY.  Oskar Blues is a fantastic brewery, and this beer is no exception.  Piney, hoppy, fruity aroma.  Taste is of hoppy grapefruit and pine, more hops on the aftertaste and a wonderful crisp, lip smacking finish.  Perfect DIPA
355ml Can (Thanks Papsoe) - Amber in colour. Piney aroma hints of grapefruit, peach and toffee. The taste is hoppy with grapefruit and toffee. Enjoyable and doesn¬ít taste its strength.
On tap at Mahars. Very solid big IPA. Pours a really stinky grass and lemon, really happy about that. Taste was somewhat musty and hoppy, but finished clean enough, a bit sweet too.
What a steal of a deal for  this baby. Bought for only $1 at Crown. Nice darkish red color and a nice aroma of hops and pine. Very smooth and drinkable. You wouldn¬ít know it was 8.7 ABV.

A super beer. Love the reddish copper color of the gody and the nice head. The aroma is strong of crisp and bitter hops. The taste delivers a big hoppy spice up front and a good underlying malt balance. the finish is hoppy and bitter but not overly so. Great beer.

Solid double IPA or Imperial amber. Very drinkable. The alcohol content is well integrated and hidden. Pretty nice lacing after a solid head on the pour. Texture of the beer was slightly underwhelming. Felt under carbonated for the mouth feel or not quite creamy enough. Pretty tasty though I wouldn¬ít want to spend the money on it regularly.
Draft. Pours an almost brown hue with an off-white head. Flavor is pine/citrus with something toasted in there. Balanced malt backbone to match the hops, good DIPA.

UPDATED: AUG 31, 2013 First rating: Medium beige head. Tropical fruit (pineapple) and citrus aroma with metallic notes. Hazy red body. Dry-sweetish oily fruity wooden spicy taste with citric notes. Mid-bodied. Mild, hot mouthfeel. Dry citric fruity grassy aftertaste with long strawy notes. Very very good. (0.355l can, Olympen, Oslo.) 7,4,7,3,15=3.6

Second rating: Coarseish pale brown busily shrinking head. Clear brown body with carbonation. Raisiny earthy malty aroma with orangey spicy notes. Dry-sweet spicy orangey caramelly taste with raisiny notes. Full-bodied. Mild, soft, silky mouthfeel with some fizz. Dryish spicy caramelly orangey aftertaste with peppery peachy cinnamon notes. Gorgeous. Drinkable, harmonic, complex. Really smooth, too. (0.568l can at Brewdog Manchester.) 7,4,7,4,15=3.7

12oz canned Nov 3, 2010.  Pours orange/red with a decent light tan head, leaves some spots of lacing.  Aroma is some floral and grassy hops, light caramel malt, rather boring.  Flavor isn¬ít much better, a little grassy and floral, some caramel malt sweetness, some alcohol.  Mouthfeel is slick, low to medium carbonation.  At six months old, I don¬ít expect it to be at its best, but this is already a shadow of what I expect fresh Gordon to be.  Will seek out a better sample in the future and re-review.
Yet another fantastic beer from Oskar Blues.  Loads of hops in the aroma as well as the taste.  Great bitterness balanced will with a slight sweetness.  I love it.

12 oz. can: Pours copper brown with a nice lacing. WOW, those cans really keep the beer fresh: big pungent, citrussy and grassy/herbal hops with a clean caramel maltiness in the aroma, propelled by pleasant alcoholic notes. Full-bodied with an excellent fresh, piney hoppiness and a crisp toasty, even a bit roasty maltiness - awesome. Bitterness is so smooth and mellow. Absolutely among the best IPAs I had so far, it really does a great job at keeping a nice balance without muddling the flavours. If I had to change something, it would be the rather lively carbonation, but this is a very minor point. Wish I could buy this on a regular basis.
Pine resin comes shooting out of the can. Taste is powerful hops but balanced with some dark malt creates a sticky mouthfeel. One of my favorite beers.
Super super hoppy and strong amber ale. Whewy. Citrusy malty goodness. Caramel flavors smooth out this crazy beer.

Can. Pour was rich golden copper with a strong American citrus hop aroma. Flavors were rich with toasty and bread malt, rich in body, and a ton of hop flavors while the bitterness is not sharp at all. This was such a fine blend of flavors and bitterness. I really liked the rich malt characters.
Poured from can. Dark, orange body with small white head and nice lacing.   Malty, sweet aroma with hints of piney hops, sugar and grass.  Flavor mostly of pine, grass, syrupy sugar. Finishes bitter.
Pretty orange/red pour white with nice off white head, good lacing.  Earthy scent with hops. Taste is more strong ale with hop dry finish. Very good!

A- Translucent medium/dark amber body with big foamy off-white head. Head soon fades to a nice thick collar and leaves behind plenty of lacing in the glass.

S- Nice citrusy, mostly grapefruit smell is upfront. This is balanced with a big complex malt backing.

T- Citrus hops are first with a big grapefruit taste. The malt backing is strong and has a caramel character with hints of chocolate. The initial taste is smooth and well balanced. The finish is nearly all caramel malt with minimal hop bitterness. Sweet bready caramel malt lingers.

M- Low carbonation and rather thick body. Goes down smooth.

D- Great hybrid beer. The DIPA/ strong red combination really works here. Its got a big malty character with good hop flavor. Very easy to drink and the ABV is almost undetectable. Something I will have again.

Serving type: can

Reviewed on: 08-17-2007 16:01:30
Very interesting beer and the best I¬íve had from a can. Lots of hops and malt almost on the verge of a Barley Wine. High bitterness and sweetness. Medium-smooth mouthfeel and thick body.

From can@H√•ndverkerstuene, Oslo. Two fingers of dense, sand-colored head. Body is misty, copper brown. Delicious hop aroma. Pepperminty, leafy, grassy and light resinous. Floral notes and a touch of grapefruit and tropical. Taste is hop driven, with the same profile as the aroma, nicely balanced by some gently sweet toffee-ish malts. Medium to full body. Slick and oily in the mouth. Hops linger in a lasting finish. A treat.

Chewy - floral hops - relatively strong for an IPA. Nice and drinkable. Can pours a golden red with very thin head and minor lacing. Sweet caramel, pine, and citrus aroma. Flavors of toasty malts, grapefruit, nuts, and sour oranges. Good pucker to the finish.

Rating #2700 Pours a deep dark orangish amber color. Aromas of big hop action, sweet malts, and more hops. Flavor has some bready maltsy tastes with nice grapefruit and floral hop taste. This is one hoppy sumbitch. Oskar Blues sure knows what they are doing.

Oskar Blues Brewery Brewing Company--Gordon. India Pale Ale--2005 25.4 oz. Bottle.  9.20% ABV--65 IBU¬ís.?  (4.25 / 5.0)  IPA--Imperial.  Mild head.  Hazy dark rich amber color.  Malty floral hop front.  Clean smooth rich mild toasted sweet caramel mild ester fruit body.  Clean smooth balanced hop citrus end.  Rich mellow hop brew.  Sampled 2/7/2005.

Oskar Blues Brewery Brewing Company--Gordon. Beer--Micro-Can	2007 12 oz. Can.  8.70% ABV--85 IBU¬ís.  (4.75 / 5.0)  IPA--Imperial.  Mild lacy head.  Clear rich amber color.  Malty big floral hop front.  Rich sweet balanced tangy caramel hop infused mild fruit ester chewy citrus pine body.  Balanced smooth mellow hop spice clean bitter end.  Sampled 1/18/2007.

Can. Canning is becoming a lot more popular for microbrewing. Poured a very nice looking reddish, orangish color. A small white head was left after the pour. This beer left a lot of lacing on the side of the glass as it went. Aroma was sweetness, hops, pines, and grass. Flavor was mildly sweet, caramel, then went bitter. Long sticky oily aftertaste. A big bruiser of a beer. Very good.

12oz Can. Sweet resin aroma arises from the glass as the beer pours a medium dark cloudy copper color with very nice lacing.  The taste reminds me of a barleywine coming on long sweet and very bitter. Definitely delicious stuff.  The body is think and sticky leaving a bittersweet sensation lingering in the mouth.

UPDATED: NOV 22, 2010 Oskar Blues keep surprising me with astonishing stuff; this last one on can @ Henrik, Bergen. Gordon pours a murky, light brown ale with a creamy, dense white top. Smell is complex: bread dough, vanilla, maple syrup and some fruity tones as a wrapper. This should be good, so I dive in with a predator¬ís lust for something new. Instants after, I am rewarded. The taste is smooth and yet sparkling on the palate; little taste explosions tossing aroma around in my mouth. Out comes first what can only be described as a vanilla-ish maltiness, followed by wild strawberries, floral hoppy notes and hints of boozy cough syrup. Definite alcohol presence, but not too uncomfortable. Complex and original, Gordon is a worthy tribute beer to a giant of the American craft beer movement, and a helluva brew in general.

Can.  Clear orange red, big white had on it with lots of lacing.  Sweet caramel and mandarin orange citrus hop aroma with floral notes.  This has a big brown sugar sweetness that somehow doesn¬ít feel overwhelming.  I had no problems drinking this.  Has a lighter body on it than I would have expected considering the sweetness.  Pretty on the light/moderate side.  Toast and caramel notes appear along with the brown sugar, more citrus orange, light herbal and floral notes.  Pretty hoppy finish on it.  Good stuff.

Can at Patricks, Kristiansand. Pours dark red/ruby with a creamy tan head.
Aroma is full of dried apricot, pine and grapefruit. Taste is fruity and very bitter, with a sweet malt base, light caramel. Finishes off on the bitter end of the scale. Easy drinkable though, and even refreshing in a strange way.

A caramel color beer with a pretty good head that leaves some lacing. The aroma is slightly sweet and smelled like bubble gum, thats right bubble gum. The taste was nice hoppy with a sweet candy like taste and was similar to drinking liquid bubble gum with a nice hoppy presence. Unfortunately most of these are at least 6 to 12 months old at all the stores in my town but was able to get a fresher one.

OVER RATED BEER! I bought one of these at a local brew shop just to try the hype of a IPA in a can! My review... not GOOD! Can I have my money back? I have know idea why people praise these beer... well I¬ím not going to get down on my knees & take a lick and say it tastes SUPER- like a lot of people have done! I¬ím not that kind of guy... I¬ím married with kids and like a Great beer... and that¬ís that!

Pours a dark red with half a cm of tan head. This was served a bit cold, so the aroma was fairly mellow at first. Mostly metallic, actually. After a while, juicy canned citrus fruits take over, along with caramel and sugar. As the can said, this is pretty sticky. The conciderable hop content does keep it from being too sweet, but I wouldn¬ít mind if the sweetness was toned down a little here. This, paired with fairly mellow carbonation makes it a bit of a sipper. Anyways, this is pretty tasty, but not my favourite from this brewery.

355 ml can, courtesy of Cardinal Pub & Bar, Stavanger. ABV is 8.7%. Amber colour, big off-white head with an orangey hue. Excellent complex aroma of American hops, notes of pine, oranges, grapefruit, tropical fruits. The flavour has loads of American hops from start to finish, with fruity (grapefruity), piney and resinous notes, but it is not too bitter (despite respectable 85 IBUs), as the hoppiness is nicely balanced by a sweetness of malts and orange marmalade. Resinous bitter aftertaste.

330 ml can. Dark red body with a dense, creamy off-white head. Aroma is nominated by pine, but there is also some grapefruit here. Flavor is fruity and bitter with rather sweet malt, some caramel and an even bitter finish. A bit different and very refreshing, even being this sweet.

Oskar Blues is a great brewery. 12 oz can. This beer is exactly as described, a mix between IIPA and IAA. The nose is hoppy pine, malt, caramel, and brown sugar/maple. The taste is big on piney hops, caramel malt, citrusy grapefruit, orange, and lemon zest. A wonderful blend of IIPA and IAA. Wonderful brew.

From can at Olympen. Deep red copper, big off-white head. Grapefruity hop nose with hints of metal. Furious grapefruit hop attack, some softening caramel flavours, but overall quite hardcore bitter. Raisins and nuts in the finish. Full-bodied, almost sirupy. Makes its canned statement loud and clear.

Pours from the 12 oz. can (CAN? yes, can) a lovely dark amber color with a thick, pillowy 2 finger off-white head that quickly settles into a thick collar and leaves a sticky lacing on the glass as it subsides.  Aroma is of sweet citrus-y hops (grapefruit, lemon and maybe a hint of pineapple?)  There is active carbonation, but the bubbles seem smaller than usual.  1st sip brings a hoppiness mixed with malt sweetness.  The hops tend to win out, but there is a VERY nice balance.  There¬ís a strong pine-y finish and the aftertaste coats the tongue & lingers for a long wile.  Mouthfeel is smooth & creamy without being heavy, and I could drink these babies all day (or night) long!  The wording on the can says this ale is "Big.  Red.  Sticky.". and that pretty much nails it!  Took me a while to find this here in PA, but the search was well worth it!  I¬íll definetly add Oskar Blues to my list of favorite breweries, and plan to sample more of their lineup VERY soon!!!
Wonderful brew.  Very red and hoppy.  Great head, great lacing and great overall.  I enjoyed this one and god bless Gordon Knight.

Can.Pours a dark red with a frothy white head.Nose is hoppy and clean.Palate is smooth and medium bodied.Tatse is hops and malts blended together  nicely.Great brew by Oskar Blues.I first tried this beer in 2006 and it was in a tin colored can with a green sticker.It was classified as an Imperial IPA back then and I would have rated this beer a 5!!It¬ís gone down a bit but still a solid beer and best beer in a can EVER!!!!

330 ml can. Brown colour. Clear. Tall off-white head that clings to the glass. Intense floral and grassy hops aroma. Tastes very fresh, even though it was shipped to Norway.  The hops dominate without being overpowering. The beer is focused on hops aroma and flavour and not particularly bitter. Some darker malts enhance the malty flavours. Nicely balanced, and very drinkable. An excellent beer. The big brother of Dale¬ís.

Deep copper with off-white head.  Some grapefruit / pine nose with strong malt balance.  Caramelly? 8% ABV hidden pretty well.  Very nice.  I forgot how much I like this!  Will go to it again and again!

This beer poured  a clear red copper with some carbonation, as egg white head and decent lace. This is a beautifully aromatic beer with notes of grapefruit, citrus, and floral hops. This ale is meticulously balanced, yielding a medium body with silky smooth notes of hops leaving a crisp aftertaste. Beer from a can, who would have thought!
Rich amber color with a light head and good lacing. Nice brown ale flavor with a good hop profile and sweet finish.
From a can poured a dark amber color with a fair amount of head.  Strong malty hoppy flavor with a lingering bitter finish.

Red-orange liquid, mostly clear, with a nice enough head and good sticky lacing.  Floral, citric hops and lots of caramel malt. This beer clearly lies more on the side of caramelized malt flavors than most DIPAs. Very mild bitterness, not enough hop flavor for my taste in a DIPA. It¬ís a good beer, but it has shades of a Scottish Ale.  Mildly oily with hop resins. Otherwise, smooth and hides the alcohol well.  Easy to drink, particularly for a DIPA.

UPDATED: JUL 18, 2011 Low carbonation.  Hazy orange head.  Deep Reddish color hue.  Most of the same characteristics of a good IPA.    

Pros: Traditional IPA balanced out with some red ale flavoring.  8.7% alcohol.  Very well made, and not much new engineering here.  Almost no lacing.  Very sweet caramel malts.  

Next time around, not as much bitterness as I remembered very smooth and sweet.  

7/18/2011 Additional notes:  Pineapple and tea notes really come through on the taste.  The sweetness deadens a lot of the flavor but this beer is dangerously smooth.  Would liked more fresh hop flavor. 

Cons:  It¬ís been done before.  A 4 pack goes too quickly.

Pours a clear reddish orange with an off-white head.  Aromas of grapefruit, citrus peel, resin, and caramel.  Taste is lightly sweet and rich, finishing mildly bitter.  Full body with a sticky texture and soft carbonation.  Smooth and balanced.

Draft at the Haze.  Orange-brown color.  Hazy, with a soapy beige head.  Fresh and easy drinking, world class body.  There is some obvious depth underneath the seawater, orange-citrus hop aroma, letting you subtly know there is a slightly higher ABV than your typical beer.  Somewhat soapy and doughy at the same time, completely mellow and unique.  Slight bitter warmth in the aftertaste.  Fresh and awesome.

Huge grapefruit and candied pine needle nose.  Brilliant deep amber color with a medium thick head.  Deep sweet malt, slight lemon brightness with big bitter bite to balance.  Medium carbonation, medium body, rich mouth feel, citrusy, long hoppy finish, with nice warmth burning through.  The grapefruit notes stand out, this is an excellent beer with big flavors.

Can served in a tulip. Clear amber orange in color with a head that fills half the glass. Lovely. Nose is citrus and pine. Some malt also. Not overly aromatic. Bitter flavor, light sweetness. More hops than malt, but the backbone is there. Medium body, some creaminess, absent carbonation. Great finish. Bitter, sticky, and long. The more I taste this the more I like it.

On tap at relight redlight. Pours a beautiful amber color with a low white creamy head. What little lacing is present sticks to the glass like glue. Aroma is a welcome kick to the face... american bitter hops, grapefruit, and a little bit herbal. Mouthfeel is medium to thick and lingers around for some time. Taste is a wondeful, smooth hop. Grapefruit is def evident as are caramel and vanilla tones. One of my favorites on draft or from a can.

Draft at redlight redlight.  Pours a slightly thick amber.  Very bold excellent nose, very much like a Christmas tree.  Lots of sap with a hint of grapefruit.  Excellent bitter flavor.  Loads of hops.  Slightly sweet finish.  Thick, sticky mouth-feel.  Certainly one of the best double IPA¬ís on the market.

A: A deep reddish amber color with a finger or so of white head. Some lacing is present, but not too much.

S: The initial sniff gives an aroma of earthy hops. Subsequent sniffs provide some grapefruit and pine. The hop character is followed by a doughy malt scent.

T: This beer was only very slightly chilled, so the sweet flavors really came out. There was some very light citrus flavor, a very prominent pineapple flavor, and a slight maltiness midway through the sip. The finish is slightly bitter and piney.

M: Not too much in the way of carbonation on this beer. The body is medium to full.

D: Such an easy drinking DIPA. It¬ís more malty and sweet than I generally like (I¬ím not sure how old it is), but great flavors and nothing unpleasant.

Canned on 9/08/09

[can¬ío bliss. satisfy ya.]

-can

I¬íve never had a canned craft beer before so this just seems weird.
Pours orange/amber color with a thumb worth of off white creamy head with above average retention.

Lots of candied hoppy goodness in the nose. Some tropical pineapple and sugar covered orange peel.

Lots of sweetness up front. Candy and sugared orange peel is the best i can explain it. A touch of pineapple too. In the finish there is a touch of bitterness and some mango-ish aftertaste.

Mouthfeel is extremely smooth and creamy. Little to no carbonation.

Drinkability is high. The 8.7%abv is verywell masked. I feel like i could drink a few of these. I would probably be tanked but its super easy to get down.

Overall, i was impressed with this canned beer. For a DIPA is leans a lot more towards the malty spectrum. I definitely prefer more of a hop bite but i can¬ít really say to much negative about it. Its smooth crisp and tasty. I would recommend this one to anybody and would definitely drink it again.

Can¬ít wait until the summer to pack some of these cans in my cooler...deep red with nice creamy head, sweet and bitter all at once. Very close to a barleywine, tasting much like BigFoot by Sierra Nevada. Initial sweetness, followed by bitterness, and finally with a dry aftertaste. Definitely multi-dimensional. Had seen this many times but just tried it tonight...drank 3 of the 4 in the 4-pk. Packs a punch too.
pours deep amber with medium frothy white head. aroma is citrus and pine with decent sweet malt. drinks thick with hops and earthy pine, crisp citrus and toasted malt. fantastic.

Draught @ The Beverage - Pours slightly thick and lt amber with a small sandy head...aroma is bright and full of sticky pine, caramel...resiny...flavour is similar, sweet pineapple and tangerine, citrus peel, pitch...nicely balanced and easy drinking...I wish we got this back home...

I have tried this beer many times over the past two years but just now got around to reviewing it. 

Pours a reddish brown with an off-white head. The aroma is strong citrus hops with some pine. The flavor is grapefruit, pine and orange. The orange is much stronger than the last times I have tried this beer, with a strong pithy orange flavor being dominant. Medium mouthfeel and low carbonation.

12oz can!  Pours a glowing amber body with a fluffy, beige head that recedes and leaves lots of sticky lacing.  Nose is bready, caramel malt and floral/orange hops.  Big malt backbone balances the medium piney, citrus hops well.  Slightly syrupy, with a medium body.  Great pine/citrus lingering bitter finish.  Another great beer from Oskar!!

huge malt aroma hits me 2¬í from the glass: strong caramelized toffee.  up close, aroma is toffee with sweetish peanut brittle like edge.  appearance is wonderful marroon with fine head and immedate lacing.  flavor is bracing bitterness with juicy orange hop character backed by truckloads of strong caramel malt.  big beer all around that starts as the ¬íIAA¬í oskar blues describes with hops that reveal in scores with a fruity edge.
this beer is unbelievable. has everything i want in a beer. it is bitter but is well balanced by malts and has drinkiability!!!
Right from the can.  Excellent balance of hops and sweet grapefruit.  Smooth, very drinkable, and I will buy this one again.

Can from the local. Well looks like I am voting against the masses on this one. I did not like this DIPA at all. I thought it was overly sweet and thick. It reminded me of candy (not in a good way) in aroma and flavor. I actually couldn¬ít finish it. On reputation alone it deserves a re-taste but not anytime soon.

Appallingly grotesque metaphor: David Foster Wallace¬ís corpse reanimated as a bum in the early morning light transposed with the first 15 minutes of a Next Generation episode. That¬ís Oskar Blues Gordon DIPA¬Ömore or less.

Now I¬ím not as thirsty as the bum who was willing to pay me for a face full of dog piss but I am certainly always ready for a good DIPA. 2 days and halway down a growler, this beer puts me in a good mood before dinner and a better mood after a Captain Picard verbal smackdown. And the like the ridges of Lieutenant Worf¬ís brow, the hops in the beer cut a bristling line across the top of your mouth. But the flavor doesn¬ít pain you, it sails like heinous JFK-like sailboat on a sea of bourbon.

Traditional is the mildest adjective I can think of for this brew. Isn¬ít that terribly interesting? Please do try this Colorado delicacy. No, I have not been paid to say that¬Öyet.

Bottle.

Amber color with a small off-white head. Some lacings.

The smell is hoppy with notes ofpine-needles, grapefruit, caramel and vanilla. Rather balanced aroma actually.

The taste is fairly sweet with a lot of caramel and vanilla breaking through a hop character which seems to be going downhill. Notes of resins and grapefruit. The finish is bitter with notes of pine-needles, a hint of alcohol and lingering hop notes.

Medium body, somewhat sticky texture.

A drinkable beer, but too sweet for a Double IPA. Considering the fading hop character, I guess this bottle was a bit old though.

Can at Oliver Twist, Stockholm.

Pours redish with a small and shortlasting beige head.

Fruit, berries, citrus and some alcohol in the aroma.
Taste rather sweet, almost like a barley wine but lighter.

355 mL can.  Not-quite-transparent amber-brown with a medium, sticky, white head.  Nice lacing.  Toffee and American hops dominate the appealing aroma.  Complex malt backbone in the flavour comprised of burnt caramel, nuts, and some roasted fruit.  There are lots of citrussy hops in there as well, more tangerine than grapefruit, and this one has a nice, lingering bitter finish.  Somehow not really an IIPA in my book, but it is a fantastic Imperial Amber.

24th September 2008. Hazy brown beer. Lovely hop profile - robust aromatic hop delivering loads of grapefruit but with no acidity or bitterness. This is laid on a solid foundation of malt. Very drinkable indeed!

Nice pour, Slight red with a head that had good lacing. plenty of hops, but very nice drinker, nothing overpowering, balanced,  very easy drinker, Sierra is harsher, love this brew. Had to open with a Can-opener though, can was messed up, thank god I wasn¬ít in the woods, or it would be a shot-gunner.lol
On tap at Capones. Amber color with aroma of pine, hops, and citrus.  Flavor of pine, citrus with a hop bitterness at the ending.  Well balanced and a solid offering.

Can from Whole Foods (Bowery/E Houston). Dark amber body with thick white head. Nice hoppy nose. Rich taste of hops and pine. Really smooth and well done. A delight and another fantastic beer in a can by the guys and girls from Oskar Blues.

(gn/sv-can)

lct-cpr, ^eff, med-thick-foamy-wh-head, slick med-body, ^co2.

^pine-resin-hop sweet-crml-malt aroma.

T1 crml-malt leafy-hops co2.
T2 ^roasted-malt floral-hops creamy-yet-watery(enigmatic I know).
T3 bready-malt floral-pine-hop-juice.
Tf clingy-bitter-hop-resin.

balanced and ^drinkable, but not sessionable due to high alchl and clingy bitter Tf.

Pours a reddish copper body with some brown hints-pretty opaque. Nice 1 finger foamy white head.

Smells sort of like an IPA with some citrus hops, but also fairly malty for this style.

Tastes like it smells with a nice balance of hops and malts with some caramel hints. More complex flavors than your average DIPA.

Feels nice going down-relatively smooth but thick enough to coat as it goes down. Little carbonation.

Overall an interesting DIPA-not particularly what I was expecting. I agree with what others say regarding it being a bit amber ale-like in quality. Quite nice.

The spicy aroma of this IPA was very present as my glass was seemingly covered with this big, yet clean, flavored ale. As I have been favoring double ipa-s recently, this dark amber ale was very refreshing and a welcome change in my otherwise uneventful day. The elements of caramel style malts and the sparkling hops made this very easy to drink.

A: Pours a beautiful copper hue with a nice sticky head.

S: Wow nice hop profile. Lots of bitter citrus and sweet pine. Hints of caramel malt poke thru as well.

T: Taste is married to the nose. Overloaded on hops without being too bitter. Bold citrus up front, but sweet pine tones things down a bit. Add in some nice toasted and citrus malt and you have a very drinkable IPA.

M: Medium to full bodied, rather full for the style. Good carbonation.

12 ounce can pours a beautiful amberish red. Smells like hops and happy. Tastes like hops and even more happy. This beer is awesome. Very well balanced and the 8.7 is completely hidden. I like this one a lot.
user_location: The World of Beer, Texas, USA

text: Sticky, big red.   Loads of Hops and malt.  Used to be better before they went big

Can pours deep copper with a creamy off-white head.  Aroma is heavy in caramel and pine.  Flavor shows the same but leans more towards toffee and peaches.  Overall body is moderate and sticky with soft carbonation. Oskar Blues, king of the can.

Oskar Blues Gordon is a clear, dense, copper ale with a foamy, chunky, yellowish sand colored head that has rainbow bubbles.  The head retention and lacing are outstanding.  The aroma is very strong.  As soon as the can is popped, you can smell it across the room: grassy, floral, spicy, citrusy and fresh.  It¬ís velvety smooth and pretty full bodied.  The finish is clean and delicate.  It¬ís well balanced; not terribly bitter, but very hoppy.  There are flavor notes of grass, flowers and citrus peel.  The alcohol flavor waxes to provide the finish and a long, hot aftertaste.  Wow.  It¬ís really bold.

RnH: tap: Pour was slightly hazy brown with a red hue leaving a thin layer of tan head.... decent lacing though.  The nose had strong citrus notesm very bright.  Also some sugary malty tones.  The taste carried alot of that citrus/ young fruits but also some darker, maybe even roasted sugars.  Alcohol was present but not overpowering, good balance bordering on mushed together.  A bit creamy in taste yet dry and crisp in feel.  Nice brew.

Pours rich amber/golden with a thick, creamy head into my friend¬ís plastic cup, but I¬ím drinking this one straight from the can on Miami¬ís South Beach: Nose of sugar coated pine dipped into a batch of high octane, liquified hops. Creamy smooth mouthfeel, with a crisp bite of that American Cascade. Drinkability: Earthy flavors really deliver (yet aren¬ít overstated) in what could be one of the strongest DIPAs I¬íve had to date. Rebuy: Yes. #221 on 28112009, DG.

Discount Liquors Milwaukee, WI. 4-pk $9.99 11/09. Caramel aroma, and notes of plum.  Dry-hopped with Amarillo. Nice amber color with minimal head. Medium sweetness at first leading to a light sourness and a well balanced bitter finish. Nice medium body, flat carbonation, leaves a very nice taste in my mouth. I would buy again, very nice beer.

Pours a light brown, some sticky lacing, gives off  a sweet nose almost barley wine like, first sip is bitter sweet like a strong ale. but  finishes like a double IPA. Some thing about this beer makes me want to get drunk (which I never do, any more) Any way, nice beer.

THOUGHTS: I was amazed that this come from a can. Great balance.
TECHNICAL: Bottle. Poured a cloudy, light, orangey brown with a small, off-white head that mostly diminished and left fair lacing. The aroma was moderate caramel malt; moderate to heavy piney, resinous and grapefruity hops; a little more orangey hops; light to moderate yeast with a slight funk to it; brown sugar and alcohol. The initial flavor was rather sweet and lightly bitter; while the finish was sweet and rather bitter with an average to long duration. There was caramel, brown sugar, citrus hops, pine hops, alcohol, orangey hops and a little resinous hops. Everything blended together. The medium to full body was somewhat oily and then a little dry with fizzy carbonation and a lightly alcoholic and slightly metallic finish.
UPDATED: NOV 20, 2009 Can. Clear dark red color. Creamy head. Hoppy aroma. Citrus/orange. The taste is of orange cest with bitter caramel in the aftertaste. A bit thin (or old?) for being a DIPA.

This is lovely when served fresh. Rather dark caramell colour with a chunky off-white head that leaves great lazings. Aroma is a nicely balanced blend beteween juicy, piney hops and a solid biscuit like caramell sweetness. Flavour is the same but with additional bitterness acompanied by a sticky, chewy mouthfeel. Nice.

this is so good- like a thick dark blood orange smell and flavor, very malty and very hoppy.  great balance between bitterness and thick malty body. slides down the throat dangerously easy. On tap at Abraxas Lounge, Miami Beach.

Orange/amber pour with a disappearing orange head. The aroma is full of caramel, pine, and peach. The flavor is caramel, toffee, and sweet fruit like peaches and apricots. Very thick and smooth due to low carbonation. It has a piney finish. Good, but not a very memorable IIPA,.

UPDATED: DEC 30, 2013 CAN: reddish/orange pour, big frothy foamy white head. Nose of pine hops, citrus, and earthy notes. Nice creamy mouthfeel, great hop and fruit taste, well-balanced. Exceptional beer.
12 oz. can.  Orange amber nectar color.  With beige head.  Strong piney and floral hop aroma, lemon and berries.  Rich hoppy taste with long finish, dried fruits, earthy edge.  Overall very nice.

This beer is a high octane ode to the hops flower. It pours as a red thick liquid smelling strongly of hops and pine. Given this the flavor is surprisingly crisp and mellow though possessing of a very strong palate. The hops flavor is strong, though not overstated as can so often happen with American Cascade hops. The finish is hoppy and cleaner than could reasonably be expected. Of those Oskar Blues beers I have sampled thus far this is far and away my favorite.

12oz can pours a reddish amber with a clingy white head.  Aroma and flavor are both a complex of fruity sweetness, tartness, and piney richness.
Medium body, crisp biting finish.  Very VERY nice for a canned beer!
medium bodied with a balance of malt and hops  I really enjoyed the 4 pack 12 oz cans after hearing about it on  a pdocast

Can purchased at Liquor Mart in Boulder. Pours a nearly clear auburn with two fingers of creamy beige head and sticky lace. The nose is of sweet citrus and mango hop notes over a sweet amber ale-like malt note. On the light side of medium-bodied and slightly "grainy" with a big, bitter, lingering finish. The flavor follows the nose. It¬ís essentially a big, fruity and resinous hopped amber ale. This is a nice beer. I wish we could get it here in KC.

12oz can bonused by alagnak.  Stamped with a canned 9-08-09.  Pours a orangish caramel clear brown with a small but sticky head that leaves touches of lacing.  Juicy bready nose with resiny orange hop and pine.  Nice balance of malt with the sweet citrus hop flavors with just a bit of bitterness.  I have had cans and had it on draft before, but this has to be the freshest one I have ever had and I must say it is much more enjoyable.  The 8.7% is well hidden for sure.

This is just good.  I would bathe in this beer, and drink it afterwards...though, I would have to admit, that pre-bath would be the best way to enjoy this masterpiece. Citris, pine, malt, hops.  This beer has everything I want in a beer...Except maybe for the fact that it costs at about 10 bucks a 4 pack... it¬ís still a must buy.  I love this beer so much, that the next time I buy a 4 pk, I¬ím going to drink three of them, and take the 4th to the back seat of my jeep and get it pregnant.
12oz can. Light golden color with a nice thick white head. A light amount of lace left on the glass. The aroma is floral and piney with hops. Taste has alot of alcohol, some hops and not much malt.

tap at the Lyons brewpub - Pours deep copper with a very long lasting head and a great big citrus hop aroma.  It tastes of huge hops with huge citrus flavors and yes, some big malt to support it.  The smells and flavors of this beer definitely loom large and it works great.
12 oz. can- Pours cloudy reddish amber with a nice thick head. Tastes hoppy, almost piney, very good. The best can beer i¬íve ever had.

Sampled at WBF in Durham - poured a hazy golden color with a white head - aroma of hops, citrus, pine and caramel.  The flavor was a nice hoppy grapefruit with a piney resin.  Again - how does this stuff come out of a can tasting this good?  Loving it.
12oz can, deep golden color, thin white head, some lace. Interestingly complex flavor, adequate hops. A bit overrated but not overpriced.

This is a pleasant, fairly well balanced, but simple, uncomplicated double IPA, easily drinkable beer with some character but not much.

Golden amber, it has a medium light tan head with hints of orange, slowly diminishing to a foamy ring with a tiny bit of weak lace. 

The aroma is sweet, full, and flowery with grapefruit, grapefruit ring, raisin, hints of resin, and canned pear.

The taste is grapefruity with plenty of grape and raisin, caramelly grain.  It¬ís fairly sweet with dry zetiness and very faint bitterness  in the finish but lingering. It has unusual bitter-sweet balance, neither being leaning much to being sweet or bitter, but has dominant hop character.
reddish brown. smells like hops , black tea, pencil shaving, and a sweet fruit. a relativley soft flavor for all the hops. sweet and bitter hops for a long time. med-big body but pretty flat.

Pours an orange/amber color with an extremely thin white head. Strong aroma of hops and pine. Flavor consists of pine, huge hops, and a hint of caramel, with a bitter aftertaste. This is one that I really wanted to try and I am very glad that I did. Awesome that this Impy IPA is in a can. Way to go Oskar Blues!

12 oz can.  An imperial IPA in a can!  Wonders never cease.  Aroma is of hops, sweet caramel malt.  Beautiful looking beer with a nice thick head which whittles down to a medium sized head which lasts throughout.  Nice copper hue.  Nice even balance between the malt and the hops.  Strong alcohol aftertaste.  It¬ís slightly watery, but not overbearingly so.  Nice, nice beer (in a can!!).

Picked up a growler of this.  Mild, piney aroma, and a glowing amber pour.  Gordon is a rich, dry, chewy, hoppy, dark ale, with loads of aromatic pine flavor.  Very fresh and foresty, and solidly supported with a some malty sweetness.  I¬ím very glad I got it fresh - good IPAs are usually best this way.
Really nice and strangely complex. It¬ís like a little bit of everything and then a lot of alcohol.

Pours like a bottle of coca-cola, except with a root beer head. Deep brown color, not quite opaque. 

Nose firs strikes me as brothy. Yes, like a soup. Maybe some brewed tea notes in here, when the tea bag came open and there¬ís loose tea floating around. Dark rum too, maybe that¬ís the "sweetness" on the nose. 

Palate has big malt & hops but the other flavours keep you entertained - some birthday cake, root beer, marshmallowy vanilla wafer thing too. 

Finish is more alcoholic than I¬íd like. Normally I hope that bite is more subdued, even for a beer of this strength. It interferes with drinkability for me, and turns this into a sipping 1 per sitting type of beer.

12oz can from Old Chicago. Pours orangish amber with off-white head. Aroma is loaded with citrus, tropical fruit, tons of hops and caramel malts. Flavor is loaded with bitter hops, huge citrus and tropical fruit punch, with nice balance of caramel malt. Superbly balanced for such a hops bomb. Awesome mouthfeel. I can¬ít believe some of the low ratings for this beer. This is a real good double. I prefer this type of beer over all the sweet malt bombs that are raved about as great DIPA¬ís.

12 ounce can.  Pours a murkey orange-amber with off-white head that leaves nice lacing.  Lovely fruity aroma of tangerines, grapefruit, and some tropical fruit (pineapple, mango).  Flavor also has a lot of strong fruit flavors (grapefruit, peach, mango) along with a nicely balanced caramel maltiness.  Neither overly sweet nor bitter.  Medium body with a pleasant lingering bitterness.  Still amazed that a beer this good could come from a can.

UPDATED: OCT 26, 2016 damn 7 year later re-rate.  is this a strong ale, red, or a dipa??   definitely has many dipa qualies - still seem to prefer dipa to ipa which is confusing.    raised score from 3.4;   I think this could be a hoppy go to beer.  well balanced.......................................... purchased in Dillon, CO and brought back to TX.  great aroma and cloudy ruby pour.

DIPA¬ís are not my favorit style of beer, but I enjoyed this better than others.
