malty sweet (a little too much) and the hops were not bitter - close to a tripel type hops.

would try again.  interesting beer..
Red orange color with a bubbly white head.  Excellent hoppy scent.  Taste has the character of a good IPA, malty with a nice smooth hop finish but not too bitter.  Very solid overall.

12 oz can poured into a snifter glass produced an amber colored beer with a 1 1/2 finger head.  The smell consisted of pine, dark fruit and malt.  At first I wasn¬ít sure what to think of this beer as it was a little to sweet for my taste.  But as the beer warmed up it allowed the hops to come through.  At 8.7 percent you can¬ít taste the alcohol.  This is a pretty well balanced beer.  I would try again if I could ever find it on tap.
Amber pour with off white head. Pine aroma with a good blend of hop and malt. Very Good
Very malty nose, deep amber color, taste is bitter and hoppy. In fairness, rating may be skewed as it was sampled after a dogfish head 120 minute

Pours an amber colour with a foamy head that disappears slowly. Aroma is citrus and fruit. Medium bodied mouthfeel. Taste is fruity with a bit of hops kick and a bit of honey. Pleasant aftertaste with a little bitterness.

Location: 12 oz can from State Line, 8/27/09


Aroma: Nose is hoppy, floral, wood, fruit, resin

Appearance: Hazy orange-amber, thin off-white head, spotty lacing

Flavor: Nice hoppy flavor, sweet caramel malts, pretty well balanced

Palate: Long finish, medium body, creamy mouthfeel

Overall Impression:
This is a pretty tasty beer, definitely would make a great tailgate beer, you don¬ít often find beers this good and this drinkable in a can.  Not quite as good as their Impy Stout, but so drinkable that I would choose this one right along with their Dale¬ís Pale as a top tailgate/camping can beer.

a very hoppy aroma with a pleasent aftertaste that reminds me of a good ipa.  good drinkabilty with plenty of flavors from the front to the back of the palate.  even drinkers who do not enjoy ipa¬ís would probally enjoy this beer. and its pretty good from being served right out of the can.

UPDATED: SEP 12, 2011 (Draft 2/20/11). Clear copper color. Medium off white head. Moderate citrus hop aroma. Flavor of the same, with moderate sweet malt. Avg duration. Light bitter finish with light lasting sweetness. Slick texture. Moderate carbonation. Fair lacing.
-----
Initial rating from 8/21/09: Overall 3.3 (can). Cloudy, reddish orange color. Medium off white head which is mostly diminishing. Strong hop aroma with moderate alcohol. Spicy hop flavor. Avg duration. Smooth, light bitter finish.  Slick texture. Moderate carbonation. Spare lacing.

UPDATED: APR 3, 2011 1. From the Can at the Oskar Blues Brewery, Longmont 08/10/2008
Very hoppy aroma. Golden coloured and hoppy with a little dryness in a crisp and bitter malt finish.
2. On Tap at Uptown Brothers, Denver 20/09/2010 (As Gordons DIPA Imperial Red)
Big hop aroma. Amber red coloured very strong in alcohol hoppy and fruity with a hint of dryness in a bitter malt finish.

On tap at RnH.   Pours deep golden copper brown.   Taste is full flavored.. deep floral hop, caramel and malt backbone.  Interesting body, on the thicker side and somewhat oily.  Would like to revisit this again..

Can.  Poured a deep amber color with a dense orange head.  Lots of caramel and earthy, floral hops in the nose.  Medium bodied with a creamy mouthfeel and ample carbonation.  Flavor is loaded with hop flavors and caramel, I also got a slight vegetal note which wasn¬ít pleasent.  Overall very good beer.

can pour, dark golden/light amber with medium light tan head and large carbonation noted, wonderful floral hop aroma like smelling a pack of hops with a slighter sweet smell, beautifully balanced flavors with big hop flavors nice malt sweetness and almost zero hop bitters, a "hop bittering fakeout" if you will, tastes so good should have flashing lights on it!

12oz can poured into a goblet. Pours a reddish copper brown with a nice white head. Lots of lacing, good carbonation. Aroma is heaven. it¬ís full of hops and also a great thick caramel malty scent. Taste is mostly floral hops with a light bitter finish. You also get some caramel, and malt but they¬íre not as pronounced as the smell would leave you to believe. Alcohol is very well hidden. The only thing keeping this beer from being perfect is that it¬ís not quite as heavy and thick as I was looking for. A little lighter than most double ipas.

12oz can into a pint glass.  The pour is deep reddish brown like clay with a thick off-white creamy head that lasts.  The aroma is big fresh hops that you could sniff all night and be satisfied.  The flavor is malt, caramel, maple syrup, and a touch of bitter leafy hops.  The beer has medium-low carbonation with a big creamy body that still goes down nice.  The exhale is more hoppy than the actual flavor, which is nice going out.

Lots of hops. MMMmmm hops. THe body is thick and big oily, and the taste follows the nose with tons of pine, not really any floral, and some citrus. But the flavor for me fades on the back end. After the swallow the flavors are gone, not so much linger. I¬ím glad this is classified as an IIPA now, I think it used to be an American Strong. Very pricey. I really wish the flavor hung around--that bitter burn you get after exhaling after a healthy sip of a hoppy beer isn¬ít really here at all, and I¬ím missing it severely.
VERY hoppy beer, but awesome too! Oskar Blues is a great company with great beer!

12 oz can, love the can. Pours a deep amber with a tan foamy head with some lacing. Aroma is sweet citrus, pine and a good amount of caramel malt. The flavor is sweet then slowly fades to a bitterness. The body is the heavier side of medium with a mild carbonation and a somewhat syrupy mouth feel. Overall this is a pretty well balanced IIPA, just a tad on the sweet side.

On tap at the Tasty Weasel in Longmont on 7/16/09. Pours a great orange with a little off white head.  Awesome pine and citrus hops aroma with a little vanilla undertones.  Very well balanced sweet/bitter double IPA with a long lingering bitter finish.

Pours a robust, sitcky orangish/red. Somewhat fruity nose, but it disappears quickly. Rather sweet at first tastet. Dry-hopped and it shows in the finish. Overall the balance is unbelievable, the flavor powerful and tangy. A true gem and not just because the first time I had it was in the back seat of a car. I¬íve had it several times since and it brings it.
Smelled great typing on phonr tasted good can¬ít go into now great beer playing darts my shot and my screen is blank

copper, thin offwhite head.
thick musky hop aroma.
very smooth texture and balanced flavor, though a bit mild. there¬ís tons of caramel, it¬ís like candied hops.
medium-thin body and very light carbonation.
this is good, but not great.
This is by far one of the most flavorful and power packed IPA¬ís out there. Drink a few of these and consider yourself a man.

Pours a hazy orange with a thin off-white head.  Strong aroma of grapefruit and apricot.  Flavor is tropical fruits up front that is quickly overtaken by piney hop bitterness.  Dry, biting mouthfeel.  A decent IPA but a little overrated IMHO.

Well, I have enjoyed this beer for a couple years now so here is one of my less-than-stellar reviews. Nice amber red color with a head that alludes to the gravity of the beer. Smells like fresh pines and hops. The taste is also very piney, hoppy with some tropical fruit flavors and reminds me a lot of Yulesmith winter. These two beers are helping me understand why people call them "Imperial Red" ales; they are much more malty than a standard DIPA but they still have a super hop element. This is definitely my favorite beer from Oskar Blues

Serving type: can

Reviewed on: 01-01-2008 16:52:51

Can. 
Pours a hazy orange/red with a beige head. 
There is lots of dried apricot in the aroma along with hay and weak notes of peach and pine. 
Flavour is dried fruit especially apricot. Other notes is hay with some caramel in the back. 
Its quite sweet with a nice balance and a very dry, slightly bitter, hay after taste.

Draft @ the brewery in Lyons. Awwesome looking beer - nose is heavy tootsie roll and orange zest resin (imagine zesting an orange and smelling the zester). Flavor is really well-balanced hops and a caramelly malt. Smooth and really dangerously drinakble for the ABV. Bitterness dominates the finish, which is crisp, not mouth coating. Excellent.

Pours mostly clear amber with a frothy beige head with retention. Aroma is toffee and orange. Thick body with toffee, roast malt, bitter hops and a smooth texture. Very bold taste with a brutal bitter finish.

pours a hazy copper with some ruby highlights.  medium tan head leaves some tight lace on the glass. notes of caramel, floral hops, booze.  a bit sweet and sugary,  could maybe use more pungent hops.  big sticky  mouthfeel.  pretty good beer.  satisfied me.  Thanks Santa!

deep amber color, light off white head, diacityl nose, sweet caramel malts, lots of residual sugars, hint at some roasted grains, not overly bitter for style which is actually a good thing for me, it¬ís no pliny but it is much more balanced than most other Impy IPAs, lots of C hops in the flavor, pretty good, the 8.7% is very well hidden

. . . . . . . . . . . . . it¬ís actually only 60 IBUs according to their head brewer, the 85 is wrong...  check out the brewing network¬ís (thebrewingnetwork.com) can you brew it? episode if you don¬ít believe me: http://s125483039.onlinehome.us/archive/cybi07-20-

From a can... gorgeous orange/red color; deep and cloudy. Head disappears fast since the can isn¬ít conducive to carbonation.
Well balanced in both aroma and flavor: dark amberish malts, woody and flowery hops. Strong and bitter in hops and malt. Milky on the palate, pleasant bite on the way down. Strong, and too expensive, but delicious.

I like Gooey double IPA¬ís better than any other beer in the world, but Gordon is a little too sweet and gooey.  It¬ís very sweet and fruity, like papaya.  The hops offer a decent citrus blast, but it is too sweet for the style, in my oppinion.
Drank it on tap at San Francisco¬ís Toronado with my father.  Good, solid IIPA.  Medium bodied, dry and hoppy.

Nose is citrusy hops, very strong.  Not a lot in the way of malts, a little strange for an IIPA.  Attractive red color, tan head, partly hazy.  The flavor is citrus hops, some caramel, malts.  Not enough balance between hops and malts for an IIPA, to tell you the truth.  Finish is lingering hops, mainly resiny, and some citrus. Medium mouthfeel and not very sticky (again a surprise!).  Decent, but not great.

2009 Tap.  Get ready to be punched in the throat!  The hops in this IPA easily do the job of "shock and awe" with your tastebuds.  Similarly to Stone Ruinator IPA, as the palate adjusts to the hops, other flavors begin to pop.  Particularly, a very floral, soapy flavor (not naggingly soapy) comes through.  Overall this is a good brew, but I found it to be a little lacking just before swallowing.  As it settles in the mouth, it seems to get a little watery.  Overall a wonderful beer.
Had at the GABF. I don¬ít know. There was a lot of buzz around this. I didn¬ít see why.

Can: Dark copper, amber color with a nice light brown head.  Super hoppy nose full of fresh hops, grapefruit and hot leather.  It has a pleasant taste which starts out smoth and sweet but finishes off with robust hop bitterness.  The body is thick and smooth and sticks around for a bit.  Delightful.  Thanks Indiana Red for hooking me up with a can.

Enjoyed this brew at the Publick House Boston. Weird dipa. It grows on you. I¬íve not had such a balanced dipa. The hops are present bit don¬ít overpower the malt. Very heavy on the tounge. Would not drink too many of these.
12 oz can... sweet smelling and sweet tasting... overly sweet, and seemed a little off, with everyone i tried.... i¬íll give another try and re rate

UPDATED: NOV 18, 2009 Tap at Rattle and hum. Poured a deep orange with A foamy off white head. Piny hop nose. Mouthul is thick and chewy. Like biting on hops. Robust and full flavored with some sweetness in the middle and a long bitter finish.somewhat unbalanced. Imperial yes, great , not so much.
Fantastic.  I love a DIPA with a malt spine, instead of those over-the-top, burn-your-tongue CA DIPA¬ís.  Tremendous brew.

12 oz. can.  Pours a hazy brownish-orange with a thin, off-white head.  The head is very quick to fade.  Big hop nose with notes of pine, citrus (particularly orange), and sweet malt.  Medium carbonation with a medium, yet dry mouthfeel.  Orange, pine, grass, alcohol, malt sweetness, and a bit of wood on the palate.    The orange sweetness comes through first, then a bracing bitterness, followed by a dry finish.  Medium finish with some lingering bitterness and a touch of orange.  Overall I found it a wee bit understated for an DIPA, but that really made it all the more enjoyable.
amber pour with a dense med off white head. big hops aroma with a warming hops taste (cascade ?)

Clear copper pour with an off-white head, nice retention and lacing, lively carbonation.  It has pine, citrus (mostly grapefruit) with a sweet malt aroma that I can¬ít quite put a finger on.  Whatever it is it balances out the bitterness, and I expect that in the flavor as well.  Has hop bitterness up front that slowly fades to a mildly grainy sweetness in the middle and a dry resiny finish.  Moderately low carbonation, medium body, just a touch of alcohol warmth in the finish, but not solventy at all.  Nicely done on this one, the Amarillo dry-hop does a beer good.  Gimme this and Ten Fidy, please.

Deep copper color with a sticky, lacing head. Great aroma... lots of floral hops and earthy with good malty brown sugar smell.  Flavor is about the same, but more malty than hop flavored (I prefer the hops). Very drinkable, maybe a tad too easy to drink with the high ABV.

Can.  Dark amber pour with off-white head.  Very nice aroma.  Lots of sweet malt followed up with  pine aromas on the nose.    Well balanced, very sweet with a nice hop bit.  More pine and some orange peel in the flavor.   A bit thin on the mouthfeel.  More sweetness/bitterness in the finish, along with a hint of heat.
Pours copper with an off white head.  Smells of sage, pine, caramel, earthy.  Tastes of bitter hops, resin, citrus, earthy finish.  It is great to see an excellent IIPA in a can.
Can. Amber pour. Aroma suggest hop bomb, but flavor  although hoppy is not a fiery as aroma would suggest. This is a great beer.
Can. Appearance: pours copper with a foamy off white head. Aroma: Sweet malts, brown sugar, and hops. Taste: Much of the same.  Still sweet and hoppy flavors. Medium body with a nice bite.

I love Oskar Blues...this rating might be a bit prejudice: Pours a soft amber, with off-white head; Aromas of sweet malt (maple/caramel) and hops; Flavors of sticky sweet malt(¬íbrown shugga¬í¬í but better than Lagunitas Winter Seasonal by the Name+this one¬ís available all year), followed by a (not so)dry citrus hop bitterness. Very sweet for an ImperialIPA; Perfect medium body. Almost 9% c¬ímon!! Absolutely love it!

D√•se: Duft af karamel og amerikansk humle. Flot m√∏rkeorange √∏l med et fint skumhoved. Smagen er klassisk amerikansk strong ale, da humlen er faded en smule. IIPA der har ligget lidt for l√¶nge. Fin √∏l men garanteret bedre frisk.

Poured from Can into Sniter glass.

Pours a clear medium amber that has some nice glowing edges and has a creamy slightly off-white head slowly dissolves into a nice thin layer around and atop the glass. The aroma has a sticky resinous hop bouquet that is accompanied by some brown sugar but still is dominated by the hops. The flavor is sweet candy up front with some sweet hops and brown sugar. The sweet bitterness lingers for sometime after each drink. Gordon is a light to medium bodied beer with light carbonation. The nose on this beer is fantastic and it leads you to believe that the flavor would have much of the same, which it doesn¬ít. A little let down by that but overall it is still a pretty good drink.

This is a great smelling beer.  Flavor is more of a battle of sweet vs. bitter instead of coming together.  A good beer but if the taste lived up to the aroma it would be amazing.  I didn¬ít know there was such a thing as a IAA, but that description works.
12oz can.  Cloudy orange pour with a medium off-white head.  Hoppy aroma with a definite sweet malt presence.  Sweet malt flavor up front with a bitter citrus hop finish.

On tap at Slices pizza in Escondido.  Caramel amber color with a great sticky head.  Nose is sweet hoppy and and maple/brown sugar.  Taste is the same.  Great light flavorful brew.  Malty hoppy sweet yummy.

Wow this came out of a can?!?!  This brewery rocks and I love what they do with stuff from cans.  Anyway it pours a dark amber with a small amount of head that does seem to be sticking around very nicely.  On the aroma I get hops, malt and slight citrus.  A somewhat subdued subtle aroma though.  Medium bodied almost full bodied I guess.  On the palate I get hops, slight malt and very subtle citrus.  Not very much like the double ipas from this area I am used to but still nice.  Definitely recommend this one!!!

On tap at Cogan¬ís in Norfolk.  Pours brownish-orange with a thin white head.  Piney hop aroma with not much else detectable.  Balanced flavor  of grassy hops and malt sweetness.  Actually a bit too balanced for my tastes but still an excellent DIPA.

Rather hazy orange-tan, reddish tones and an inch of thick cream-colored head. Aromas of pine and citrus leap out, light toast, apple and hints of maple with a deeper whiff. Thick malts with touches of light caramel and honey easily stand up to the grapefruit and floral hops at first. Finish is coating and more bitter, with the alcohol and pine apparent. If you¬íre looking for a 8+% session beer, this might be it!
very hoppy double ipa that is very grassy and piney. there is a slight sweetness to offset the bitterness. more malt than usual. good beer but price holds it back.

lets talk gordon for a bit. it¬íll be fun. yep, i¬íve had quite a bit, hell, i¬íve even been given a few 4 packs from people that know their beer. i¬ím no  stranger to this berr. that dark yellow bordering on brown nectar with the white head. that usually smells of a pine forest ansd a grassy field in the rain. damn i¬íve had a lot. i¬íve enjoyed that sharp hop bite with that great balancing vanilla sweetness that makes me think, "holy shit, i know why the hopheads love those insane IIPA¬ís" fuck balance give me more of that. so damn good. but i just want to know who was responsible for this crap ass 4 pack i¬íve been using as a finisgher tonight. tastes like rotten wood and cardboard with a bad moldy plowed grass taste. would someone tell me who to smack around? this ain¬ít my gordon. and for fucks sake i live in the area i should get fresh  ones. who is the asshole? the distributor? the store? seriously someone needs to fess up. o.k. i like this beer, but i¬ím going to write in both scores fresh, and however fucking old this whore is. christ.
4 3 3 1 9 
4 8 7 5 15

Can. Bit hazy amber body. Medium creamy white head. Wonderfull grassy aroma with lots of pine and earthy notes backed up by a great malt base. Flavour is very fruity and dry with pine, citrus, peach and caramel notes. Great variation of hops in this brew. I loved it.

Deep amber color with a thin, yet dense head.  Smells of wonderful citrusy hops!  Other notes of earth and pine are also noticeable.  The flavor has loads of pine and tremendous sweet grapefruit to it.  However, the flavor is a little subdued and it doesn¬ít have that typical DIPA punch.  Still, a very delicious beer.

Thanks lb4lb for this.  Pours a deep amber orange with thick off-white head.  Aroma of is a bit more balanced than most IIPAs, but obvious of citrus and floral hops, strong malt, and grass.  Flavor matches, but just doesn¬ít have that oomph you would be looking for from an IIPA.

Pours dark amber with a modest off white head and a good amount of lacings. Aroma is malty and a good amount of hops. Taste is very bitter leathery fruity hops with a very large amount of sweet candy like malts. I would have pegged this as a big red ale. Not in the same league as many of the super impy / double IPAs. Decent beer but reminds me some of their Old Chub with more hops. The amount of sweet malts hides the 8.7% abv quite well. Worth a taste and I did enjoy it.

Can  Deep mahogany with a huge dense light tan head.  Big aroma of sweet, carmel malts and thick hoppy goodness.  Sweeter and heavy than an IPA, or a double even, but not as bitter either.  The hop flavore is woody and heavy, not bright and crisp like a west coast IPA.  Lingering thick malty palate as well.
Good stuff.

Clear copper with thin head, and nice lace.  Woodsy hope aroma.   Twangy bite to start, bitter orange, and a little, followed by woodsy, grassy bitter finish.  Sweetness of the malt lingers a little.  A lot going on with this beer, very interesting.

12 oz can from Bier Stein. Pours out a nice amber color with a solid beige top that fades quickly leaving almost no lacing. Very nice balance between citrus, floral and light pine hops and a sweet caramel malt finish. Very easy drinking especially for the abv.
Pours a deep amber. Nose is floral citrus hop bomb. Full flavored malt and hop balance. Hides 8.7% well.
Pours a clear amber with thick tan head. Very nice lacing.Aroma of caramel malts and hops, some tang as well. Taste similar with hops, very boozy.

Imperial IPA complexe. Le houblon n¬íest pas tranchant, ni trop pr√©sent, mais fait sa place. De couleur brune asser fonc√©e, la Gordon d√©veloppe des saveurs de caramel et de cassonade, m√©lang√© aux notes de houblon et d¬íalcool. Tr√®s bonne.

Can. What a great beer. From a can! Really impressed with this one. I now have my beer of choice in a can for those events this summer not allowing any bottles. Pours a nice reddish color with all the characteristics of a good IPA. Well done.

Yeah know... I think I must have bought a bad can???  Smells like a DIPA with a huge amount of skunk!?!  and flovor was acidic with DIPA after flavor.  I have liked the other brews from Oskar Blues Grill and Brew so...  I¬íll wait and try another one at a later date. and re-rate it.

On tap at Raleigh WBF. Pours a deep copper with a nice tan head. Great lacing. Aroma of caramel malt, citrus hops, pineapple, and watermelon. Taste is pineapple and passion fruit with a spicy alcohol bite. Dry finish. Yum.

Copper borwn with off white head and nice lacing. Aroma of caramel, malts and some dark fruits. Flavor was caramel, dark fruits, light hop bitterness and a pleasant alcohol finish. Nice syrupy mouthfeel.

Impressive three-finger, thick head.  Leaves a chunky ring lace after each sip.  The color is dark copper and is crystal clear.

Beautiful floral hop aroma...very inviting.  Light malt in the background, but this is as it should be: A hoppy ale.

Creamy texture, with a lightish level of carbonation.  Great balance for a DIPA.  Solid malt body that quickly succumbs to the hop bomb.  Not as bitter as some which makes this a very easy to drink beer.  The alcohol is muted, which means this is a deceptively powerful beer.

Pours a deep, off-white head that laces and a clover honey color body.  Smells of  hops and barley.  Makes me think of a barley wine.  Tastes of barley, hops, caramel, tea, and lemon.  Finish is bitter and dry, almost tannic, like black tea. Hopped well.

12 oz can (thanks again to Pawola22).  Aroma is very pleasant as its hard to keep my nose away from the glass, but does not strike me as a true iipa, but more of American strong ale.  A bunch of fruits, melons, citrus, grapefruit, heavy fruits like dates, medium fruits like apples, also with a good nutty caramel and cereal grains.  The pour is decent, small creamy smooth head, little carbonation, decent lacing and retention, good clarity with a medium body, and good rusty orange color.  Tasting this beer confirms my belief that this is more toward the imperial amber side of the description, but no matter what you want to call it, there¬ís a bunch of quality things going on in this beer.  Balance is superb and the flavors here go very well together.  Rich roasted cereals malts and nutty caramel come up right away, paving the way for more some heavier fruits like melons, thicker citrus with lemony grapefruit, minor spices alongside some darker fruits, and then a finish that is more herbal earth and light citrus that still maintains some of the melon and other malty starting qualities to make a fairly wet and sticky linger.  Things are never too clumped together and blurred, but it does ride the edge of that fairly closely.  Overall, I am definitely a fan of this beer.  Well done.
Amazing...probably the best beer in a can i¬íve ever had.  Strong (8.7%ABV) and smooth IPA.  Reminds me a lot of Dogfish¬ís 90 minute ipa.

Clear golden amber color with a big fluffy beige head. Lots of sticky lacing and nice retention. Aroma is pineapple juice and a huge dose of caramel and brown sugar. Overly sweet. Flavor is sweet caramel malts and fruity hops. Not a lot of bitterness. Pleasant but not that complex and a little too sweet. Body is medium, carbonation is subdued, high drinkability.

Had on tap at Taco Mac.  Pours an amber color with an off-white head.  Aroma is of citrus and pine hops with some caramel malts.  Flavor is the same with a decent bitter finish that lingers.  Not very much warming on this one.

UPDATED: OCT 22, 2009 Canned. Just maybe the best drinking beer ever! It has a beautiful amber color. Make sure you drink it a little warmer. If it is too cold the aroma seems mild but when left at an appropriate IPA or PA temperature this IIPA/IAA explodes with scent. The beers palate is oily...maybe a little too oily (my only complaint) but combined with the sweeter caramel malt palate creates an incredibly sticky beer! The taste is bold ver BOLD with sweet malts of caramel and lots of hops on the back end that makes the finish linger bitter for a while. A little fruit on top.  Alcohol is high but well hidden. Great Day Beer!

12 oz can courtesy of Discount Liquors (Milwaukee, WI). Pours a dark murky amber with big bubbly offwhite head that dissipates to a moderate amount, laces well. Aromas are evident straight from the crack, carmel malt based with floral hops complimented by citrusy grapefruit, pine, and some resiny earthiness. Smells a bit sweet overall. Initial pushed malty bready and carmel overall up front, no shocking bitterness, but moves to some citrus and florals and moderate bitterness further in. Moves to pine and resin a bit, but still malt dominant overall. This is a good beer, but just not my thing as it moves towards the Strong Ale category easily.
Poured amber with a white head. Aroma of pine and caramel. More sweet than bitter. The malt kind of overpowered the hops. Some citrus hints.

12oz can.  Interesting.  Pours a nice, dark, hazy amber.  Looks more like an American Strong Ale opposed to a DIPA.  Aroma consisting of woodsy, bready notes.  A somewhat pleasantly sweet, almost candy flavor with a nice hop presence still placed in the background.  Not quite what I was expecting, but definitely pleased.  Let¬ís see if it ages well.

Can at Church Key, North Beach, San Francisco, with Phyllis, 26th Mar 09. Clear dark amber with a cracking nose of peach, orange zest and loads of hops. Rich and malty on the tongue, great balance, smooth palate. Superb for a beer in a can.

Rich deep brown pour, light brown head.  Nice hop and malt aroma with a hint of funk.  The flavor starts with a blast of malty sweetness then fades into pine hops; almost like a hoppy scottish.  Alcohol is not overpowering.  Finish has lasting malt and hops-very nice.

Can. Nice orange-amber color with a small light head. Hoppy aroma with a little bit of graininess hiding in the background - interesting. Flavor is very well-blended, a pleasing mix of bitter and sweet all the way through. A little alcohol comes through. Pretty smooth, as well. Definitely well-made, though there isn¬ít anything particularly amazing that I¬ím finding in this brew. Would make a good everyday beer, though, since it¬ís pretty easy to toss one back.

Canned.   Dark-orange-amber colored with am off-white head.   Piney, floral and dark crystal malt aroma.   Light malt sweetness, medium bitterness and piney hops in the flavor.   Lightly astringent, alcoholic and a little metallic.   Medium bodied.   Decent, but I¬ím not really feeling this as a DIPA at all.

(can - 12 oz) Ruby red pour with a thick tan head. Aroma is rich and malty with a strong citrus and floral hop background. Flavor begins with a smooth malt and with a light citrus and floral backbone. Flavor disappears almost instantly and only leaves a light bitterness. For as good as it smelled and as good as the flavor began, I was shocked that it disappeared that quickly.

What a great pour from a can. Bright, intense hop aroma, flavor of citrus and kind of a toffee malt, with other fruity, herby overtones.  Nice dry finish.  Alcohol seems just right.  I can wait to pop a can for my snobbish friends who think good beers only come just in dusty old bottles.

Poured from can.  Awesome aroma of hops (of course), malt, ocean.  Dark amber, persistent head.  Oh my,  the hop/malt flavor is both bitter and sweet at once. Very balanced and very drinkable.  Alcohol is noticed in backtaste.  This beer makes my mouth very happy.
user_location: York, SC via NJ, South Carolina, USA

text: Foamy white hea and a dark amber body. Smells a little bit like booze, but also smells like flowers and stuff. Taste is hoppy, but not hopslaughter. It is a little sweet, and as the can says, it is also rather sticky in the mouth. Overall, there are a lot of malts all through this beer. ¬íTis a pretty damn good beer on whole.
On tap at The Big Hunt, Washington, DC. Dark, reddish copper pour, dense off-white head. Sticky, thick, candy-like mouthfeel. Sweet, resin, caramel, alcohol, hops.

12 oz. can courtesy of lamas.  Poured hazy, light amber with a few small splotches of lace.  Nose is bready and sweet with a subtle floral bouquet.  Oily and medium bodied.  Sweet, resiny, citrus flavor.  Smooth and hoppy, this one is very easy drinking.  Alcohol is very well hidden. Nowhere near as big as other DIPAs out there.  Met one of the OB brewers in a Phish lot, he said this is more accurately classifed as an imperial red.  Very nice.

Sampled in Lexington, Va. A big punch out of a small tin can. As a very nicy hoppy flavor that is not too over powering, but quality. Alcohol percentage is very strong but still a pretty easy drinking brew.
Can thanks to mcbackus: Poured a coppery brown with a off white cream head. Aroma is hoppy and citrus. Taste is caramel malt with a bitter chewy hops finish.
Nicely done. Great fresh open air aroma, like being in the woods. Nice bitter flavor with an extra dry finish. Really good.

on tap at the memphis taprooms- pours brownish amber with a great white head. nose is pure hops, herbacious leafy green nose. resinous and pure. taste is similiar with a great malty backbone to balance everything out. A really strong beer with great herbaciousness to it. very enjoyable.
Pours a reddish amber color with a thick fluffy tan head  Aroma is lots of hops.  Taste is caramel malts up front, with a bitter hop finish.  Very tasty and I like the IIPA/Amber hybrid.  Nice beer.

UPDATED: SEP 19, 2012 Original Rating (3/19/2009): 12oz can. Pours a deep copper red color and see-through body with a big, two finger-width, soapy foamy, off-white head that takes forever to dissipate and leaves a lot of lacing. Lots to this aroma, just not as BIG as most DIPA¬ís. Lots of caramels and mild citrus hops. Lots of different kinds of fruits including grapefruits, sweet clementines, peaches, and melons. Some wood character to it and pine needles. Flavor is very round and sweet. Sweet bready and caramel malts give this a very full body while the mild, but piney citrus hops balance this out nicely. Some of the melon creeps in there along with the citrus. Finishes malty, slightly piney and woody, with lots of mild hop linger. Overall, lots of hop taste, but not the explosion like most DIPA¬ís. I like that about this. Its very flavorful, but subdued. I also love the fantastic soft body. Really nice stuff right here (7,4,8,5,16=4.0). Re-Rate (9/19/2012): 12oz can that I found buried in my cellar. So old it still says "Gordon" on the label with a stamped on canned on date of 10/17/09. Well...lets see how a 3 year old DIPA holds up. Okay...I¬ím not going to re-rate this, but its held up surprisingly well. Not nearly as well as my original rating, but still pretty tasty. The malts are still fairly sweet, but have a nice, caramelized breadiness giving off a slight toffee sugar note. There is still a decent amount of orange and grapefruit citruses, but the melon fruits and peaches certainly come through still. It finishes sweet and malty, but well balanced with a drier bitterness, despite the hops being a bit bland when it comes to flavor. Lengthy aftertaste following a full, somewhat chewy body and a creamy, medium-light carbonation. Overall, my shock at finding 2(!) cans of this in my cellar can only be topped by how drinkable and enjoyable it is after  3 years. Full bodied and malty with a nice caramelized aspect, yet bitter enough to balance without any of the stale hop taste I was expecting. Alright!

can thanks to boomer0813.  poured an dark amberish color with a soapy beige head that left ample lacing.  aroma was a sweet buttery caramel and some pine resin.  flavor was pine resin, hops, and some alcohol on the backend.  medium body with medium-high carbonation.  this was a good offering from oskar blues.

Canned. Nice lacy head and deep amber color. more hops on the nose than malt which is true for the taste as well. Definetley a hybrid with its hoppiness, but also a red with the distinctive malt they are known for. At 8.7% you wouldnt know it unless told ecspecialy when it is so light bodied and easy to drink. Still can taste the can but i try to put that aside being i dont drink canned beer well ever! I will be taking this backpacking for sure!

While good craft beer does come in a can, that doesn¬ít mean I have to drink it out of the can if I don¬ít have to, and so I lovingly pour Gordon into my awaiting glass. Gordon exits his canned confines thick, syrupy, and deep umber red, quite a promising prelude of quaffing to come. A small head of perfection tops her off while lace clings stubbornly to the sides of her new home. Gordon puffs on command, releasing an explosion of sap, pine, hop oils and resin, orange peel, cut grass and spring flowers. Like a lab rat upon command, my mouth starts to water and I raise her deep amber depths to my lips for our very first kiss. A full mouthfeel thoroughly coats all inner surfaces as she goes down sweet and sticky with a crisp hop finish. My first impression is of honey, orange, and melon backed by caramel, malts, and toast. Following second are a plethora of hop delights; grass, pine, oils, and sap all ensconced in soft floral notes. Wait, did I just pour this out of a can? Why yes, Kristyn, there really is such a thing as a good canned beer. All hope of personal restraint gone, I hungrily enjoy every single swallow and sip of my Gordon from Oskar Blues. As he warms and I near the end of my glass, a network of laces marks his path while my mouth remains a sticky smorgasbord of orange pulp, grass, pine, and new to the mix, some grapefruit. Finishing her off is a solid balance of toasted and caramel malts.


I could pour Gordon blind for anyone and they would never guess he came from a can. As easy as it can be to cast aside prejudices and misconceptions, it can be as equally hard to let them go, consciously or subconsciously, when the price tag is the same as a 6 pack of bottled craft beer. But we are America, land of the free, the brave, and finally of damn good canned craft beer. Fear not the unknown, and instead embrace your inner can freak. Heck, it¬ís even good for the environment, along with your tastebuds, of course.

Clear red pour with a healthy head. Has a fresh aroma with just the slightest bit of hops. Interesting taste! Not hoppy at all but smooth and almost sweet. Better than anticipated. Aftertaste doesn¬ít leave any anguish.

Enjoyed via 12oz can.  Pours a deep copper.  Aroma is strong; one of American hops (Cascade, Centennial, Amarillo?).  Palate is pretty thoroughly dominated by hops, as one might expect.  However, nice notes of malt in the finish keep this example from being overly hoppy.  A dry finish makes it dangerously drinkable.

Can...  Poured an amber with a wonderful, frothy, slightly off-white head that lasted forever.  Lots of hops on the nose.  Dry, well carbonated palate.  Big complexity in the flavor with a strong licorice character.  The hops soon took over carried but the malt backbone of the brew.  Finished like a fresh batch of iced black tea.  Not one of the best IIPAs, but definitely quite unique from a lot of them.

Thanks so much to Blankboy for gifting this to me: murky dark red with a decent sized off white head. Aroma: hop forward, malt there too, some sweetness  and indeed pineapple/mango too. Lovely. Flavour: wow, confusing, lots going on: malty, fruity then dry and sweet, somewhat tangy and hoppy. Nice long caramel hop finish. Really Nice.

Another homerun from Sparky.  Man this was a very nice treat Eric.  Great cirtus and grassy nose.  Color was a cloudy orange.  Taste was of butter and tons of citrus. Great aftertaste.  My second beer from Oskar and I hope to have more

Absolutely gorgeous amber color with a perfect 1 finger head. Nose is pear, grape juice, C-hops and sweet malts. This smells amazing. Probably one of the best smelling beers I¬íve ever had. 
The taste leads off with hops and is immediately followed with a pleasant sweetness. Finishes an interesting bittersweet. Really nice mouthfeel and a pleasant aftertaste. Lacing was awesome throughout. This is probably my favorite beer at the moment. This is definitely the best canned beer ever.

12 oz can purchased from Green¬ís Discount Beverage in Atlanta.  Poured a hazy gold/orange color with a one finger, bubbly, white head.  The aroma was very much citrus, with pine and sweet malt present.  The flavor was caramel malt, with a solid, fruity finish.  I was expecting a seriously bitter beer, but this turned out to be great.

Thanks bro!  Pours a murky orange color with a medium fluffy white head that fades quickly to a simple ring and leaves some strands of bubbly lacing.  Aroma is piney and citrus hops, with some caramel malts and toast.  Taste is pretty flat, no carbonation, caramel malts, piney bitterness, some weird sugariness, and some astringent bitterness. Bleh.

From can.  Available at Specs in Houston.  Pours clear orange with tan head that lasts a bit with nice lacing.  Wonderfully hoppy and smooth with an AWESOME bitter finish...almost like a Stone IPA in a can!  I did not expect this to be so tasty!  Delicious.
It comes in a can. Its a beautiful red IPA. Its bitter as heck with back of roasted barley. A clean finish, and an easily transportable six pack.

12oz can from Trinity Liquors in Spring Hill, FL. Pours a light brown amber...with an off-white head...Very nice, fairly strong nose of pine and grapefruit. Flavor is pine sap and some citrus (grapefruit). Really easy to drink for an IIPA...not much of an aftertaste. Medium mouthfeel, a little sticky. Overall...its a pretty damn solid beer...Its not earth shattering...but really good....This must have saaz hops in it...I dont think theres a beer brewed with saaz that I wont enjoy.
Dark amber in color with a decent sized off-white head. Aroma is of hops, grass and perfume. Taste is of hops and grapefruit.

Can.  Pours a deep ruby brandy color with a small white head that falls off almost immediately. Heavy pine and citrus hops, background of sweet malt with a hint of toast.  Thick bodied and slowly sweet.  Finishes without as much bitter as the hefty hops up front have promised, and a little lighter than I might like.

Great IIPA.  Again the can is a little weird, but what¬ís inside is solid.  Amber color with an off-white head.  Aroma is sweet malt and citrusy/piney hops - lots of them.  Flavor is the same, more hops than malt.  Hop character is sort of a mix between those typical of SoCal and the Pacific Northwest.  Medium-full palate with a nice mouthfeel.

Sampled at Flour City Beer Festival (Rochester). AU15/08.
App.:  Dirty amber, light tan head.
  
Aroma:  Big sticky sweet malts and lots of C-hops.
  
Palate:  Medium+ body, medium full carbonation.
  
Flav.:  Like the nose...big sweet, sticky malts and strong C-hops; kinda sweet and fairly bitter.

I¬ím saturated on the style for the moment.
Bistro DIPA Fest.  Pours clear golden amber, balanced, roasted malts, nutty, hoppy.

12 ounce can purchased at the Davis Food Co-Op.  Aroma has plenty of piney, floral, and citrus hop notes.  Sweet, husky, and very aromatic and complex.  Smells sooo god.  Moderately hazy amber body with a frothy, off yellow head, which leaves great lacing.  Sweet, malty start with some roastiness as well as some nuttiness.  Seems pretty nutty.  Some herbal and spicy hop bitterness tis present in the end.  Balanced nicely and easy drinking.  A dangerously drinkable brew that doesn¬ít kill the palate with the hops.
On tap at Bistro DIPA Fest. This amber ale poured with a huge beige head and a mellow roasted malt flavor. The hopping is just bitter enough to round out the palate.

Can pours clear red amber with a large head and sticky lace.  The aroma is citrus and malty.  The flavor is quite sweet, citrus, pine, and orange marmalade.  The palate is rich, thick, and coating with hop oils.  Overall, this is quite nice.  I only wish they made pint sized cans.

Captain Ridiculous, your ship has landed!!!  Wow what full balanced richness from this luscious can!  Smell of lactose pineyness, like a creamy hopsicle.  Awesome look of hazy deep orange and a rich really flavorful light tan head.  Flavor and mouthfeel is what all DIPA should aim to be.  Beautifully balanced with both extremes well represented and a full saturated sticky chewiness to the mouthfeel.  This is what sierra nevada fans think bigfoot is.  Congrats Oskar Blues.

Can.  Pours a rich amber color, hazy, with a medium, very frothy white head.  Aromas of strong hops (both citrus and spruce), a bit of roasted malts, and a little orange.  Moderate carbonation with a nice slick, oily texture.  Taste is actually balanced with a bitter beginning and then a nice malty finish.  Wonderful beer!
On draught at Birreria Paradiso.  Clear golden amber color.  Very strong hop flavor but well balanced with a very strong presence of malt.  Nice one.

UPDATED: FEB 3, 2009 Pours a thin copper/amber with a medium white head.  Dry hopping is apparent in the aroma, along with juicy fruits, toffee, and malt.  Drinks very smooth, fruity, piney, and hoppy, a great balance.  LIke a mix between an imperial IPA and a red ale. Very solid, Oskar Blues never lets me down, love those guys.  Def. recommended.

Crushed with Jakebra.  Big nose fulla hops.  Piney, bitter, sexy, and also with a big sweet malt backbone comin in.  Flavor isn¬ít as good as the nose.  Still an absolute knockout.  One of the sexiest brews to come out a can since¬Öthat other Oskar Blues I just had out of a can.
The look is orange to amber in color with a pretty good beige head.  The smell is hoppy, caramel, grainy, malty, and bready.  The taste is just about the same as the smell.  Good beer.

Pours a murky orange out of the can, with a good, dense head. Aroma is nice and sweet, packed with hops, as well as bready malts and cereal grains. This is a very tasty beer. Probably not one I¬íd put at the top of my list, but I could absolutely see this becoming a ¬íregular¬í for me. Extremely drinkable, despite its ABV and the large amount of hops. There¬ís also a great earthy yeastiness to counter the sweetness that comes with the style. I wouldn¬ít blink before I brought a case of this to a gathering.
UPDATED: JUN 13, 2009 On tap at Naked City.  Pours clear copper with a thick, frothy beige head.  Aroma is citrus and floral hops and cotton candy, mostly hops in the taste.  Sweet citrus hop finish.

Pours a clear copper/amber with a thin white head and very nice lacing... Aroma of citrus, pine, alcohol, sweet tropical fruits, very aromatic.... Taste of immediate citrus/tropical fruit(mango? papaya?) hops, some sweet malts, but not overwhelming, just enough... This beer defines balanced in the realm of DIPA¬ís, where the malts cut the hops just enough... The body/finish almost has a refreshing quality, the beer almost asks you to take another sip immediately, AWESOME... This should be ranked higher...

More refreshing than would be expected from a beer with this much alcohol.  Balanced, drinkable...pleasant but not overwhelming hop aroma, medium body, somewhat bitter with a really nice hop flavor.  This is delicious, well done, and not at all over the top.  (I like over the top, but quaffable is good, too.)

12 oz can.  Pours a cloudy nugmeg color with light carbonation and a dark beige head.  Good lacing.  Sweet, citrus nose.  Very drinkable with mild malt and hop flavor. Very smooth on the palate.  You would never know this beer is 8.7% ABV.
Nice amber color with a beige head. Smells like fresh christmas greens and caramel. I love the hop profile in this, beautifully rich and balanced.

Can split with sixfootsix.  Pours a clear burnt orange with fair light tan ring of head.  Near perfect nose of sweet pine and citrus hops.  Flavor is not quite as nice as the aroma, a little vinous, sticky hops, and a slight metallic twinge, but I can¬ít tell if that¬ís just my brain knowing that it is from a can.  A little thin on body and semi-cloying on the palate, but an excellent IPA none the less!  I love that they can good beers!
A copper nose with a red pour and lite tan head very sticky hops with a little citrus. a lite ending beer.

A friend left a can of this in my fridge... I can¬ít say I had very high expectations for it.  But it turned out to be a pretty damn good double IPA.  It was well-carbonated and produced an initially large head which settled quickly and left behind lots of sticky lacing.  Amber-to-brown in color, mostly clear.  The aroma was primarily sweet and malty and didn¬ít give away the hops that were hidden in this beer.  I guess there is a slight hint of citrusy sweetness.  The flavors, however were a huge blast of earthy, piney hops.  There was some grapefruit/citrus character but it was fairly subdued.  Pretty damn good stuff though.  And it¬ís great that it comes in a can.

UPDATED: FEB 11, 2009 Clear amber, fluffy sticky head.  Copious aromatic hops over a little sugary caramel.  Clean (not watery though), quenching, mild compared to my expectations.  Some juicy hops of pine and citrus in the finish.

UPDATED: JAN 21, 2010 very floral and aromatic with complex citurs notes.  medium ruby color with a nice white head and good lacing.  grapefruit and pine flavors with a heavy mouthfeel.  the citrus lingers pleasantly in the finish without drying out too much.  one of my favorite double ipas to date...

On draft at the Blue Dog in Chalfont, PA. Deep garnet pour with thin white head. Nose full of hops. Flavor was caramel malts, citrus hops, piney hops and a dry finish. Medium bodied and very drinkable for its alcohol content. Real nice IPA.

Hazed copper body with exquisite lacing. Bold aroma of citrusy apricot and pink grapefruit, edged by hot caramel. Creamy body. Taste echos aroma, with blood orange joining the citrus. Marmelade with melted caramel in a can of real whoopass, kissed with divine hops.
Tap at The York.  A clutch-ass beer that masks every drop of its 9% ABV.  Sweet, citric hops with outlines of cane sugar, tea, and love.  Very drinkable, very crisp and Coloradoan.

Pours a warm amber color from the can with a creamy off-white head and faint carbonation.  Smells and tastes of mild hops, lemon rind, and chewy caramel.  Black tea also seems present as this one warms.  Nice, but fairly tame for a double IPA.

12oz can from Jans Wine and Boos #2 (Tampa, FL). Pours a dark reddish brown amber color with a massive frothy tannish white head. Good retention and lacing. Aroma is sweet and malty with heavy notes of citrus and grapefruit and other notes of caramel, honey, floral hops, yeast. Flavor is also malty and sweet with notes of caramel, floral hops, grapefruit, citrus, some honey and grassy notes. Generally medium body with a bitter hoppy finish.

Can shared by footbalm, thanks again man. Pours a light copper color with a light white foamy head. The aroma is nice piny hops, some light malt behind the hops. The flavor was very nice; some strong hops, mostly piny and some light citrus, light caramel malts. Very drinkable, and no alcohol present at all.

Dark amber pour with a big ol‚Äô off white head. Looks great. Well-balances, caramelly and hoppy nose. Flavor is great, albeit a bit thin. Lots of great spicey hops and caramel malt. Extremely well-balanced for a IIPA. Also, it‚Äôs cool that it‚Äôs in a can.

Can pours a dark amber with a white yellow hued head 3 fingers thick.  Lots of hop character pine, citrus, and earthy hop notes.  A strong malty backbone with a light etoh warming well masked by hops.

UPDATED: DEC 31, 2008 Strong hop aroma, very "sticky" smelling as the can indicates.  A little watery in the palate, but the falvor is great....the 8.7 ABV is extremely well hidden.  Almost no alcohol flavor or nose.  Overall, a great beer in this style.

Great beer. I love what Oskar Blues is doing to promote craft beer in a can. Pours a beautiful red amber, with a tan/off-white head. The hops hit you straightaway, but are balanced nicely with some sweeter notes and some really nice spice. I wish I could remember more, but that 8.7% ABV caught up with me.

Perhaps the one I got was old, but this didnt seem as hopped as I expected.  Very sweet, and bitter, but didnt have hop flavor.  Aroma was nice, but the hop flavor was really lacking.  I hope it was old.

draft at barleys in greenville. pours a dark amber color with touches of red when the light hits. topped with a half inch creamy head. aroma is excellent with big sweet hops, rose, cinnamon, orange peel, and pear. flavor is dominated by hops but leads to flavors of orange, rock candy, and hints of kentucky bourbon. palate is very smooth and easy drinking without  a hint of the 8.7%. another great beer from the kings of cans.
Hazy dark amber color.  Smell is creamy vanilla and pine hops.  The smell is amazing.  Taste is strong hops, but not overly bitter.  There is a little sweetness to it.  Excellent beer.

Received via trade with Beerlando.  Nice rich hoppy aroma as I poured it into a frosted pint glass, with a quarter inch white frothy head.  Initial flavor was of bitter hops and then finished with a creamy citrus aftertaste.  Very easy drinker for an DIPA, I hope OB starts distributing to MN soon.

Bottle, from Southington in CT.  Pours a beautiful cloudy orange, with a cream-colored head.  Really nice lacing on this brew.  Aroma dominated by orange, tangerine, nectarine, and a touch of tartness.  Flavor is unexpectedly sweet; at first sip I really am not sure what to make of this.  Where did all the hops go?  Carbonation is under-average, and mid-body emerges surprisingly mild.  Finish descends delicately back towards crushed-hop bitterness, but stops short of becoming sharply so.  Sweet fruit also lends good balance to the finishing palate.  BUT, as a hophead, I say leave the word ¬ìbalance¬î at the door.
Pour is a clear copper with a thin white head. Lots of citrusy hops with a semi-dry finish. Great lacing. Very nice - easy to drink.

Tap at Papago in Scottsdale. Wow what a ncie IPA. Pours with a copper color and a medium head. The aroams are just outstanding. Grapefruit, pine, some estery notes. Great balanced flavors of aggressive hops but tampered by some malts that give some butterscotsc finish. It was listed at an IPA on the menu  but I think having it categorized as IIPA is more appropriate.

pours a murky and dark copper with minimal head. Aroma has lots of hop, citrus, and a great sweetness, quite resinous. Flavor is very nice- not as hoppy as expected, but the resin continues, along with malt and caramel. Palate, is great, really nice beer.

Pours opaque amber with minimal head. Aroma is pungent with hops- resinous and citrus ridden. Nice biscuity malt character creeps in there nicely. Flavor is quite moderated, but wholly delicious. While the hop presence strikes through with its resinous vigor, the caramel malt sweetness counteracts with a great presence. Balance and complexity is great. Palate is vinous with nice dry finish.

Poured a transparent, deep copper brown with a thin white head that faded midway down the glass. Aroma was very hoppy, citrus and flowers with strong sugary malt. Flavor was the same, brown sugar and caramel maltiness with lemony, citrus American hops in tow. Slightly bitter, slightly sugary finish. Very drinkable

4-pack of cans from Total Wine. Pours an amber color under a firm off-white head. The lacing is sticky and thick. The aroma is huge with resinous hops. Flavors have a caramel-malt base and an all-around hop presence with subtle notes of oak wood and a pine-cone aftertaste. Medium carbonation and full body. A great IIPA, but incredibly overpriced at over ten bucks a 4-pack.
Can. Pours a hazy copper color with a medium off white head. Aroma of hops, malt and citrus. Taste is hoppy with a light spice and malt flavor. Has a light bitter finish.

Pours a nice a medium dark, forming a nice sized off white foamy head.  Aroma of citrus hoppage, pine resinal, field grass and water.  

Flavour full on tasty caramel, hop brine with a smoothness of clean refreshing beer.  Excellent DIPA/American Strong Ale from Oscar Blues!  Me want more...
user_location: The Crystal Coast, North Carolina, USA

text: That‚Äôs one bitter hop aroma. This is a pretty hoppy beer. Flavor is mostly bitter hops as well, but not too heavy in the finish. Doesn‚Äôt seem too strong. Certainly tasty.
I was pleasantly surprised when I tasted this beer. I was expecting hops, but was pleased with the balanced malt addition. This was a very drinkable beer for such high IBU.

Orange/amber pour, nice off white head arose. Citrus, pine aromas, faint sweet malt. Interesting for a pale, almost creamy mouthfeel. Nice bitter hop up front, but quickly mellows to some sweet malt and light red and citrus fruits. Little biscuity. Very clean, alcohol well hidden. I particularly liked it because it was not just a hop bomb. Pretty excellent version of the style.
user_location: from Michigan now in Charlotte, North Carolina, USA

text: Wow- interesting take on an Imperial IPA.  Pours a deep copper with a creamy off-white head.  Heavy on the aroma hops- floral with notes of light sugar, lemon, and slight citrus.  Flavor is mellow malt with water, sugar, and a lingering floral sweetness in the finish.  I really like this Double IPA.

12 oz. can.  Pours a clear amber with a moderate off-white head that lasted through the first quarter of the glass and left partial lace.  Very pleasant aroma of citrus and pine, with more emphasis on the citrus.  The flavor is again citrus and pine with more emphasis on the citrus, along with a bit of caramel.  I especially like the hops contribution to the flavor without being prickly on the palate.  The mouthfeel is somewhat resinous and fairly smooth.  Very nice beer.

Can as shown. Pours a hazy copper amber color with a medium frothy off white head. The aroma is a piney hops and citrus. Good sticky lacing on the glass. The taste is light malt with pine hops. Hides the alcohol well, a great Double IPA from Oskar Blues.

Can from the BP in Sylva.  Pours a amber beer with a fluff white head.  aroma is piny hops with a resin note.  Flavor is sweet malty with a the big punch of hops.  Notes of citrus.  Very sticky the can reads and it is.  This beer rocks my socks off!

Can from New Beer Distributors, NYC.
Fruity aroma.
Sweet and spicy. Cinnamon, mint, black cherries. Somehow balanced by bitterness to avoid being cloying. Lovely.

On tap. Pours a deep amber with a finger of white head. Aroma is coniferous hops and sweet malt. Flavor is coniferous, sweet malt, maple, citric, and a slightly bitter resinous finish. Very nice. Carbonation is good but not overpowering. Palate isn‚Äôt adverse and alcohol is well hidden. Good beer.

Pours a amber/dark cooper.  Nice pine and citrus hop aroma.  Good bitterness, but at the same time it was also a little sweet and incredibly easy to drink.  Very little carbonization.  I do like Imperial IPAs coming from a can.  Thanks for the brew BOLTZ7555.

Can. Poured into a snifter, beautiful amber color, good head. Good aroma of pine and citrus hops. Taste is a well balanced DIPA. Nice sweet piney hop taste with malt in the aftertaste. The texture is creamy/smooth and very easy to drink. For sure it is one of the better DIPA out there.

Can. Pours foggy orange amber with a beige head. The aroma has grassy and floral hops with caramel malt. The flavor is well balanced with sweeter malt, floral hops, and some light fruity esters, followed by a nice bitter finish. Nice.
Really enjoyed Gordon.   Lots of hops but what I liked was its malt character.  Had lots of cramel and roasted flavors.  Also has sort of a baked bread character. Very good.
Hoppy as hell.  Darkish red color.  Citrusy hint in the aroma.  Very evergreen .  Does not taste like it as 8.7 abv.  Smooth and creamy.  Very nice.

Can pours dark red-amber with thick and almost creamy beige head. Resinous, dank-hoppy mellows after a bit, heading toward pine needles and fruit punch. Intensely juicy hop aroma. Tastes like America! Sweet but only moderately bitter. Soft carbonation, somewhat thick and almost creamy mouthfeel. A bit sticky. Sweetish, tangy and hoppy aftertaste. More refreshing for its strength than it has any right to be.

Can.  Pours clear amber, with a medium head, good lacing.  Pine and grass dominate the nose, with a little bit of grapefruit.  Fairly thin palate.  Pine and citrus flavor, well balanced with light malt sweetness.  Not as bitter as one would expect for an Imperial IPA.

UPDATED: DEC 26, 2014 can: aroma of hops, some caramel and brown sugar. Nice taste, the smoothest beer I have had with a designation of double IPA in the description. The hops are not strong up front but appear after the initial taste with a pine and grassy hint. The initial taste is more malty. Does not taste like 85 IBUs. Very chugable like all Oskar Blues beer, and buzz inducing, the 8.7 abv is not remotely noticeable. Does Oskar Blues have any mediocre beers, or are they all the dankness?

UPDATED: OCT 11, 2008 this is one smooth mamma-jamma in the canna: orange and caramel aroma; many bubbly, translucent copper-brown body, copper-orange highlight, light tan head, twinkly moderate lacing; medium flavors--orange sorbet, caramel, bread, water; smooth and balanced; very good.

12oz can from a liquor store in northern Mass. Pours a hazy copper-red with a good half inch of light tan head that leaves a fair bit of nice lacing. Citrussy piney hops dominate the aroma, but not without a fair bit of caramel malt to add balance. Tastes like piney, citrussy, and grassy hops with just enough caramel toffee malt to give the beer some balance. Silky smooth mouthfeel, like few beers I‚Äôve had, with ample carbonation helps make this sipper go down fast. Wow, what an awesome beer. Surely one of the best examples of the style. Practically perfect in every way.

Tap @ brewpub. Hazy orange color, short off-white head. Dry hoppy taste, bit floral and fruity. Not in your face hoppiness. Grapefruit and pine. Good balance.
Canned: has a bad metallic taste to it. As I mentioned before: pa-lease do NOT put this stuff in a can. Its so much worse. Rating drops to 3.0

12-ounce can in Albuquerque. Dense amber color with a tan head. Big hoppy aroma. Medium body, slightly sweet caramel, malty flavor with solid underlying hop bitterness. Late hop bitterness lingers on tongue. Great flavor combo. Nice late alcohol note. Impressive!

Wow!  Great beer.  Big aroma of spicy hops and caramel sweets.  Flavor is lots of spice from hops and a resiny texture, with loads of caramel malts.  Bitter bite and hides the alcohol well.  Great job.

Can from Discount Liquors. Finally found this one. Pour is reddish brown, a bit cloudy. Nose is hugely hoppy, pine, caramel, grapefruit. Smells straight sticky. Off yellow head that is in fact sticky. Creamy smooth body with a nice balance of caramel malt with a moderate bitterness. Some iced tea notes, not too sweet, clean bitterness. The more I drink it, the better it gets. Amazingly drinkable for 8.7%. It‚Äôs like a better version of Arrogant Bastard....
Awesome.

Can. Poured a dark orange with an off-white head that left good lacing. Nice hoppy aromas of citrus and pine. The flavor had grapefruit and caramel. Medium body, smooth, starts slightly sweet but ends with a medium bitterness. Nice!
Canned. Strong aroma of hops.Orange, pine, caramel. Clear, orange coloured with a thin head. Taste is slightly sweet, wuite bitter. Has caramel, pine, citrus. Bit on the sharp side. Okay though.

Needs re-rate of fresher can. Aroma smells like I just opened a bag of hops w/ a hint of chocolate & caramel and I like it. Some cat pee in the hops though. Flavor feels a bit watery. Between IIPA and Imp Red Ale sounds about right to me. Some chocolate in the finish, surprisingly not that bitter. Low carbonation. Solid, but seems a bit off, which I‚Äôm hoping a fresher can will solve.

Very nice reddish amber pour, good head, pretty lacing. Awesome pine, citrus, fresh malt aroma. I believe my can is bit old, but the flavor is still good. Sweet mineral water malt, caramel, pine, orange, some floral notes. Body is thick and smooth, but just light enough to keep this brew refreshing. Good overall, and would almost certainly be better fresh.

Appearance and aroma: Pours a deep amber/red with a nice tan/light brown sugar colored head. The aroma is all hops...resinous pine and big citrus, notably grapefruit and orange zest fill your nose. You can also get a sense of the substantial malt backbone in the aroma but it‚Äôs definitely taking a back seat to the hops.
Flavor: Big and bitter up front followed by a substantial sweet clean malty flavor with a touch of caramel and burnt sugar then it‚Äôs all about those glorious hops....sticky resinous pine w/ plenty of grapefruit and light floral notes. Alcohol is very faint and complimentary to the overall flavor.
Palate: Substantial body but not too chewy. Finishes fairly clean w/ moderately low carbonation.

Can.  Pours mahoghany with a small light tan head that leaves nice lacing on the glass.  Aroma of caramel and toasted malt and raisins.  Flavor of raisin and grapefruit and bitter citrus hops in the finish.  Would have liked some more hops, but maybe I didn‚Äôt get a super fresh can.  Tasty beer nonetheless.

Thick frothy head which disapates quickly.  Dark amber in color.  Aroma of rich pine forest and grapefruit - smells sweet and woody.  Flavor is sweet and bitter grapefruit.  Oily yet somewhat thin mouthfeel.  This wasn‚Äôt as overpowering as I expected, but a delicious beer - especially for one poured from a can!

Although heavily hopped beers aren‚Äôt my favorite, I really enjoyed this one!

Amber with a substantial head.

Nice hop aroma and hop taste as well, with a not unpleasant bitter aftertaste.

Overall, a very nice brew.

Unbelievable, this was an amazing brew that is massively hopped from the get go.  I had put off trying this one for years because of the can, what an idiot.  this pours a dark yellow, and it is one of the most well balanced beer i have ever had with a great bouquet of hops on the front while it finishes with a strong bitterness at the end and best of all no residual aluminum anywhere in there

V - red with great lacing
A - malty with amber ale like caramel elements and hops
T - just like the nose, hops with the malty caramel
P - great balance
Tap from Monster B‚Äôs. True original. Nice amber color with a thick tan head. Flavors unfamiliar, had hop IPAness with sweet malts.

Now let me say this rating is for the Gordon that was brewed before the recipe change circa 2006.The can had a sticker on it.Just drank my last can recently and man was it good!Mmmoth hops and silky malts make this my numero uno beer!The new version is in my top ten but not up to the standards of the original.We sell so much in Georgia I can see how the quantity vs availability hurt the quality ever so slightly.We forgive and thank you Oskar Blues!

12oz in bordeaux glass.  Deep amber, low off white head.  Huge resiny, floral aroma.  Thick with lupulin.  Says 8.7%, but it‚Äôs barely there.  Color is just about the only indication there‚Äôs malt in here.  An orgy of late-hopping in a can.

Scarily drinkable is the first thing I wrote down, haha.  Poured a deep reddish brown with a thick head.  I like the way this one is sort of like an IPA, but not quite.  Lots of IPA in the nose; but, lots of malt/caramel on the palate.
Can. Ruby-amber beer with a light tan head. Pine and grapefruit aroma. Grapefruit, pine, and caramel flavor. Fuller bodied. Caramel, pine, grapefruit linger. Nice flavor. Decent bitterness.

Dark amber body with a nice bubbly head.  Plenty of pine and citrus hops going in the aroma with a kick of crystal malts backing it up.  There is a remarkable balance going on in the flavor making this by no means a hop bomb, which I love here.  Citrus hops and caramel and crystal malts with some oranges going on in the flavor.  Finishes smooth and somewhat dry.  This is a fantastic beer.
dark amber ppour, frothy offwhite head.  heavy hops in nose( citrus). Strong hoppy flavor, some great richness in the palate.  dryy woody finish

Can.  Pours a deep amber with a moderate head.  Aroma of Cascade hops.  The flavor is dominated by a bitter hoppiness, balanced only somewhat with sweet toffee malts.  Much closer to a Double IPA than an Imperial Amber.  A bit too astringently bitter on the palate for my liking.  A good beer nevertheless, but somewhat underwhelming.

Pours red/copper into the glass with an off white head.  Aroma is sweet caramel and resinous.  Flavor is very rich and has a caramel and toffee like quality to it with a nice amount of hop bitterness to counter.  Very easy drinking for a bigger beer.  really nicely done.

Can from Total Wine.  So I figured someting that costs almost $5 per can better be damned good...well it is and more.  Nice orange pour wtih a fair head...leads way to some great fruity hop and malt aromas.  The flavor is rich and fruity wtih a juicy malt flavor.  Damn am I glad that I can get this whenever I want.  Very well done.
Bottled: great beer! Pours a dark red with an orange tint and a beige creamy head. Smells sweet with hops and tastes hoppy with caramel and the alcohol is hidden well!

Canned sample via oakbluff. Amber in colour with medium carbonation. Nice floral hop aroma, which is balanced by some lightly toasted malt notes. Quite well balanced in the mouth... even though it‚Äôs malt dominant, the malts are very focused. Some minor caramle notes are present too, but the citric hops balance the brew quite nicely. Sort of like a baby IIPA... good stuff!

From bottle : Clear copper color, with a small sticky white head with decent lacing.  Very strong nose of piney hops, pepper and some alcohol.  Taste is much the same, has a big hop taste, but not the bitter bite.  Body is medium, palate is pretty nice and smooth, not to sticky.  Aftertaste has the hops and som caramel, but not much, and it doesnt linger very long at all.  Alcohol is hidden pretty well.  Good brew.

Can at the twickenham tasting. Aroma is unmistakenly american caramaly and citrusy hop, lychee, toffee, peppery. Taste is similar, alc very well hidden, great beer, however perhaps getting too much of that caramalt cloyingness. Still an excellent drink.

On tap at Papago.  Pours a deep amber-orange color with a big creamy tan head that sticks around throughout.  Lots of aromas happening.  Roasty caramel malt, pine hops, grapefruit, and earth.  Flavor is mostly the sweet caramel pitted against the pine hops.  Ends up being a huge flavorful beer, that manages to stay pretty well balanced and drinkable.  Feels thick and full on the palate, with a lingering grapefruit peel finish.  Im gonna have to say fantastic!

Aren‚Äôt you glad this isn‚Äôt a seasonal anymore? I am. Poured into a pint glass from a can and already you get a nice smell of hops, dry hopped for sure.  Beautiful amber color. Nice hop flavor but not over the top. Light malt and a nice long dry finish.    This is the best tasting canned beer i‚Äôve ever had!!

Poured from a 12-oz can an orange color with a fluffy head. Has a sweet candy smell. A nice smooth taste, which really hides the alcohol. A sticky hop flavor of pine and grapefruit. Some nice malt balanced out the hops for a very drinkable beer.

A great beer. Another balanced, strong, hoppy, malty and complex beer. So much going on: Caramel, big hops, breadiness and a sticky palate. Not that clean, but that‚Äôs not always what you want. A great winter warmer to enjoy with a light cigar next to the fireplace with a big leatherbound book (with the aroma of rich mahogany in the background, of course).
Poured deep amber, with a decent off white head.  Aroma was malty with lots of piney hops.  Flavor is rich maltiness, sweet caramel, hoppy bitterness.  Thick mouthfeel

Hazy copper amber with a rich tannish head.  Looks good.  Hoppy, floral, pine and citrus aroma.  Smells good.  Balanced malt and hops, chocolate and caramel as well.  Nice finish and palate, this is a fine beer.

UPDATED: NOV 20, 2011 Really hazy, deep rusty orange color with thick tan head and lacing. Rustic, rusty, earthy hopped nose. Smells thick. Soft but enthusiastic carbonation. Sweet entry, passing through layers of caremelized fruits before rounding out to a crisp hop finish. Bready without being burnt. Chewy but very nice....re-rate but not changing the original score on this....3 - dull dark orange color, decent head
7-bright tropical fruit aroma
3-thick and syrupy
6-the sweetness really overpowers, eliminating potential complexity.
13- not the most well-structured beer but at the same time, hard not to like it as an average nightcap
Red-amber with a bubbly, off-white/beige head. Odd nose of sugary malt, caramel, pine, and dank wood. Flavor is similar with lots of hop bite, caramel, piney citrus. Good beer.

Appearance is cloudy orange-to-brown hue with a fair amount of moderate white foam that dissipates to a ring, big sticky lacing on the glass.

Smell is mostly piney hops with slight citrus, sweet caramel malts, alcohol, and a touch of (dare I?) chocolate peppermint!

Taste is characterized initially by those unique piney/floral hops and flowing quickly to biscuity/caramel malts, some sugary sweet spices, citrus, and chocolate pop up and this finishes mostly sweet and bitter.

Mouthfeel is medium-bodied, thick and oily texture coats the mouth, moderate carbonation.

Drinkability is moderate, I would like to have seen more of a hop presence here but it scores points for balance, the sweet profile is a little strange (like chocolate and candy mixed) and detracts a bit from drinking in larger quantities, i like Gordon but it definitely falls behind Dale‚Äôs and Old Chubb IMHO.

Can from South Bay Drugs. Pours a sort of mahogany color with a rich formation of cream layered head. The nose is mild with malt being over dominant compared to the amount of hops. However the flavor is different and allows more tasting of a toned down west coast hop bite and light reminder of a sweet caramel malt variation.

Pours a clear copper colour with a small white head. Aroma is nice and hoppy- floral, grapefruit notes are prevalent. Taste is astringent, citrusy and well hopped. Another awesome brew from OB, probably my favorite thus far.

Pours a light copper color with a sizable white head.  Nice lacing on the glass. Aroma of crisp, pine hops.  Taste is more pine hops, a bit of citrus, and caramel malt.  Alcohol is well-hidden.  Flavor is more mild than I expected considering the ABV.  Tastes like a good pale ale.

Four 12oz cans purchased from Bauer Wines in Boston for $12.  It‚Äôs not too often I get to enjoy Oskar Blues beers after having an Old Chubb explode in my checked suitcase on a flight.  But I was spending a full week in Boston this time, so I took the opportunity to drink some cans while in town.  I had to choose between the Gordon or the Ten Fidy, and was in a hop mood.  Pours a clear dark red with a big fluffy head and a hoppy aroma I can smell from over a foot away.  A plethora of lacing.  The flavour is well balanced with a solid malt base and hops that linger long after the beer is swallowed.  Taste is perhaps slightly lighter than expected for the alcohol level, but it‚Äôs still a nice bold brew.  I was planning to say that the beer perhaps didn‚Äôt warrant its $3/can pricetag, but this last one is making me rethink that.

Can pours dark amber with a white head.  Has a nice hoppy, citrus aroma.  I can detect some malt in the background.  Has a medium mouthfeel with the right amount of carbonation.  Taste is mostly citrus hops and some malt on the finish.  Overall I really enjoyed this double.  The only downside to me was the malt finish.  I like hops throughout in this style.  Still a solid beer.
Dark amber with a large off-white head. Hop aroma with grass and pine notes. Slick on the palate with a clean finish. Great drinker!

Pours a hazy orange marmalade colour with half a finger of off white head and nice lacing.  Nose- caramel, and pine.  Taste- a chewy caramel pineapple candy.  Mouthfeel is very full and creamy.  Caramel and sweet cookie dough are front and center. Hops certainley don‚Äôt overpower- pine needle, earthy hops meld very well with the malt. Finishes dry and puckering from the hops with still some lingering sweetness but not too cloying.  Nice stuff

Nice looking pour.  Amber brown with a one inch tan head.  Spider web lacing.  Nose is full of hop.  This beer might be the cause of the hop shortage!  Grapefruit and pine dominate the flavor with some sweetening caramel underneath.  The hops provide a big bite along with tons of bitterness.  Feels creamy.  The ugly can told me this would be a cheap crappy beer.  It lied.

Pours a deep ruby red with a very nice, yet restrained head. Aroma is a beautifully clean American hop extravaganza. Taste reflects the aroma. Very clean; makes me think that only one hop was used. Many times breweries utilize way too many hops and the character gets muddled. Few and far between are gems like this that let one shine through unabated. I‚Äôm going to call this an Imperial IPA, and my favorite thus far of the style.
Pours amber with thick head. Wonderful piney/citrus aroma... all hops.  Flavor is sweet with big, well-balanced hop kick. Good beer.
From a can, pours a golden copper color with off white head.  Big citrusy hops in the aroma.  More of the same in the taste along with some sweet caramel malts.

I can¬ít remember the last time I had a beer out of the can but I think it¬ís safe to say it wasn¬ít as good as this one.  Pours a murky orange color with a thin off-white head.  Aroma is strong citrus and pine with some malt following.  Piney and citrus hop flavors, light bitterness, and a nice caramel malty backbone.  Not hoppy enough to be an Imperial IPA so this definitely seems more like some sort of American Strong Ale.  Good beer.

From a can, which I‚Äôm really starting to get into.  I love the way cans offer the perfect head when pouring... at least Oskar Blues beers offer a great head.  Copper pour, either hazy or dark enough not to see through.  Tenacious off-white head and great lacing.  Lovely beer in appearance and in consistency.  Hoppy nose; very pleasant if not utterly complex.  Loads of citrus and light pine.  A little sweet smelling.  Great balance of hops and malt... waaay too drinkable for an almost 9% beer.  This is a ridiculous thing to say, but this would have been an awesome beer for 10 years ago in college when getting drunk was a goal, but I still tried to drink good beer.

Clear copper in colour, large and ligering off-white coloured head, excellent lacing.  The aroma is very hoppy with both pine and citrus, caramel sweetness and some alcohol.  The flavour is hoppy, lots of caramel sweetness, lots of pine, woody and dry.  Moderately bitter mouthfeel, medium body, medium/high carbonation.  Finishes long, sweet and hoppy.
This was quite hoppy, at times very foresty.  Seems to lack a bit of body was was a little on the thin side.
355ml can from the Premier Gourmet in Buffalo, New York.
Opened on February 21, 2008.
No date.

Dark copper pour with a cream colored head that recedes quickly but coats the sides of the glass in little laced islands.  Very intriguing nose smells like Belgian candy sugar, strong amber malts, hoppiness, and alcohol.  Taste is even better, floral hops and sweet sweet malt blends like a mellower Imperial IPA.  Has a wine like stickiness in the mouth.  Fantastic beer, first beer from a can that didn‚Äôt taste like metal.

Fresh out of the can.  Pours a hazy auburn with a short bubbly head.  Sugary grapefruit and pine aroma.  Robust hops in the taste.  Lots of grapefruit and resin, with a fair amount of pineapple and mango flavors blended in.  Caramel malt backbone with just a little biscuit.  A truly righteous imperial red.
Taste 7/8 Can Looks: Cloudy tea, clinging cream foam. Aroma: Sweet malt and sour mix. Good floral. Taste: Great. Thick bodied with nice floral taste and a spicy finish.

Can from BevMo Mission Valley.  Pours a mostly clear red with a big frothy off white head, tons of lacing.  Big nose of citrus, pine and toasted malt.  Flavor was a bit more malty than expected, palate was (like the can says) sticky!!  A great brew.
12 ounce can purchased at Total Wine Pembroke Pines, FL for $4.39. Very good.
Hoppy and tasty.  Good strength.  Another fine brew from Oskar Blues.  Sampled at the St. Pete Florida Craft Beer Fest.

Bottle courtesy of gford217: Poured a deep brown color ale with a nice foamy head with good retention and some lacing. Aroma of bitter and citrus hops are dominating. Taste is also dominated by those citrusy and bitter Qwest Coast hops with a nice caramel malt profile that is overshadowed by the hops. Full body with some good carbonation and no discernable alcohol behind all those hops. One-dimensional for sure but still very tasty and nonetheless a beer I wouldn¬ít mind having access on a regular basis.

A Mes rate: Bottle at the Tom¬ís awesome Twickenham Brewery tasting.A gorgeous rich amber colour with a thin off white head. Massive cheesy and resinous hops with some lovely fruit. Bitter finish. A little over the top. Straight forward but not amazing.
