A caramel malty sweetness balances well with a spicy bitterness, all complemented by a lengthy dry, but not overly bitter, finish.

When the local beer store told me I should try this ¬íinteresting¬í beer in a can I didn¬ít think it was going to be a good idea.  Wow was I wrong.  Thick and sweet with a huge hop aroma and flavor.  Floral hop taste is very powerful.  Very similar to my favorite homebrew ever which was a Double IPA that haunts my dreams still.  Wonderful surprise!

Can. Dark, almost maroon with good cloudiness. Tiny white head that sits on the beer all the way to the end. A bit of burnt malts on the nose, near odorless. Really interesting flavor. Rich, sugary malts. Bitter hops. Warm alcohol burn. It all blends remarkably well to make a unique, drinkable heavy brew.

Can, bought @ √òlbutikken, Cph. Pours a beautiful clear red amber with a medium creamy off white head on top. It leaves a good deal of lacing. Aroma is very floral hoppy with pine and caramel behind it. Upfront bitterness with good pine and fruityness is exchanged with a vinious sweet caramel middle with a finish in the medium bitter end. This is really a nice brew - bitter, fresh and sweet all at once.

Canned. Amber coloured. Slightly unclear. Huge dense light brown to beige head. Has a very piney and citric/grapish aroma. Notes of caramel and sweets. Flavour is great. Floral and light herbal. Pine needles again and caramel in the background. Is quite citric and dry. Medium to full bodied. Has a balanced light sweet bitterness in the end. Aahhhh this is a treat. My first hoppy beer in month. Might have effected my positive rating, but who cares. This is a good one. And cannned.... Suitable as a lawnmover beer.

Tap at The Front Door Boise, Pours out a dark amber topped with a off white head. WOW what a great floral hop aroma. A very nice floral hop tast. I also picked up some sort of mellon on this brew as well. Very tasty.

Can. Pours a hazy dark orange body with a frothy white head. Delicious aroma consisting of tonnes of sweet grapefruit and orange resin, along with fresh pine needles and toast malts. Medium body, doesn¬ít really seem to overwhelm the senses to the point at which the aroma led me to believe. Reasonably sweet with significant orange and citrus resiny type flavours. Finishes very long and piney in a tongue scraping fashion. Alcohol provides some kick to the body.
Really good!
Finally man this is awesome, for a can, no, this is great for any vessile. Aroma and taste maltlicious wiht some creamy hops. Nice hoppy red strog ale.

UPDATED: OCT 17, 2007 Pours a clear amber with a nice off-white head. Nice full-flavoured of hops and a malty backbone. Some caramel. Mostly piney anf prape fuiry hops aromas. Gave me nice hoppy-citric flavored burbs. Full bodied. Medium to high carbonation. Long, quite bitter finish with a tiny touch of alcohol. I like the strong hoppines that is backed up by body and malts. I wonder why this is an American Strong Ale and not an IIPA.

Canned. Pours out in a hazy amber colour with a rich white head. Sweet and sappy aroma of plenty of piney, floral and citric C-hops. Initially sweet flavour of nectarines, caramel, flowers and oranges. Finishes drier but not overly so of grapefruit, flowers and nectarines.

Can. Pours a slightly hazy amber with a one finger lasting off-white head that leaves good lacing. Aroma of floral, pine, and citrus hops with a sweet malt and light caramel background. Taste is the same as aroma. Medium slightly resiny mouthfeel with a strong but well balanced bitterness. Very good.
12 oz can from that place on 44th street and 10th ave, nice hoppy aroma,diggin¬í the amber red color, nice headstrong hoppy start medium bodied.somemaltyness towards the finish. good stuff
0.355 l can. Dark amber color. Sweetish honey and flowery-lemony hops in the aroma. Bittersweet, honeyish and hoppy flavor featuring flowers, lemon and black currant. A bit sticky palate. Very tasty.

Can.

Following Oakes¬í suggestion, I let this one warm to 55 degrees or more before tasting. It pours deep red with an ample fluffy head. The aroma screams grapefruit and pine and caramelized sugar, like something to come out of Lagunitas but maybe a little bit nicer, actually. Flavor is sweet, lots of brown sugar on the early side, turning to woody hops later than finish maybe a bit metallic but really quite nice. Very smooth creamy mouthfeel albeit bordering on oily. The beer comes together quite well, and though not exceptional it is certainly very enjoyable.

UPDATED: FEB 1, 2009 12 oz can.  Pours slightly cloudy amber with a substantial frothy off-white head that eventually dissipates to a steady coverage and leaves nicelacing. Aroma is mostly of piney hops with some toasted malts and fruity esters in the background. The flavor is nicely balanced with a solid malt backbone and clean fresh piney hops in front.  Dry, but not really bitter. Nice smooth mouthfeel. Medium to medium-full bodied with moderate carbonation.  Some warming, but alcohol not really noticeable. Really nice beer.
*********
AR6 AP4 FL7 P4 OA14 Total - 3.5
Re-rate 1-31-09 draught.  Pours orange amber with slight haze and a small head but great lacing. Aroma of caramel and tart citrus, but a bit muted when cold. Flavor is dominated by very citrusy hops (grapefruit) with a nice smooth carmel malt backing and some sweet honey notes as it warms a bit. Finishes with some alcoholic bitterness, not unpleasantly.  Medium bodied and smooth with moderate carbonation. A nice hopjuice DIPA.

Big thanks to mcbackus for this canned beauty. Pours a hazy medium amber with a nice sized head. Aroma is malts, pretty big hops. Flavor seemed to have a barley wine type taste to it. Lots of boozy malts and hops, barley, ripened fruits. Finish was pretty bitter and dry. This was a nice treat.

Can: Pours a reddish amber with a large light tan head. Great aroma of sweet citrus, possibly oranges with a hint of pine. The flavor is where something seems off. I¬ím expecting more to follow-up the nose but it¬ís not there. The bitterness is pronounced and dry, malt is the driver here. The mouth feel is light and unobtrusive but I expect more. I¬ím not sure how old the can was but this example falls at the lower end of the Gordons I¬íve sampled. Too bad but hopefully I¬íll re-rate this in the future.

Orange √∏l.

Duft af s√∏d amerikansk humle.

Smag meget IPA agtig, men mere parfumeret og let s√∏d.

For humlet til min smag - men ellers ok.

Super clear red amber body, huge whipped cream yellow beige head, some laces; Quite big fresh pine hoppy nose, there is a slight unfitting buttery vanilla, dry wood touch; Big a little to sharp carbonation a little to fat yet thin body pleasantly bitter but not a fresh enough bitterness; Long pleasantly bitter finish, not fresh enough pine aromas but a little to malty caramel as well. Nice very drinkable beer that has a few flaws to be perfect to me.

12 oz can - 8.7%-  pours a deep copper color.  nice tight head.  big citrusy hop aroma backed up by lots of malt.  lots of malt in this ipmy ipa.  hops have faded some as this can i am rating is about a 10 months old.  sweet caramel and citrus with a piney finish.  very tasty.

Can from IrishBoy. Nice caramelly and strong hop aroma. Pine and almond. Nice head on the auburn pour. Dry, chewy flavor, lots of hop but a good bit of nut and wee malt flavors. Very drinkable, very tasty.
Good balance between malt and hops.  Taste of caramel and toffee.  Solid malty IPA.

Canned. Orange amber coloured. Quite hoppy aroma with toffee notes and a roasty touch. Sweetish fruity and malty flavour with a rather bitter hoppy finish. Slightly weak aftertaste. Medium bodied. Slightly sharp carbonation.

9/15/05. 750ml bottle.  9.2%.  Mahogany brown with large tan head. Sweet malty vinous aroma. Sweet up front with bitter ending. Really malty for an IPA and expensive at $16. Have not had it in the can.in the new formulation.
Pours red/brown, with an off-white head. Aroma is hops and malt. Flavor is much the same. A solid brew.
Yum, this is a different beer.  I have never had beer from a can that was this good.  It looks like a red smells like an IPA and tastes like a malty  IPA, I¬íd drink this again.
Pours brown with lots of foamy white head.  Strong hop and citrus aroma.  Taste much the same but with some nice malt flavor.  Reminds me a a good IPA.
A nice mix of styles coming together in this great can.  Kind of hits you in the face without thinking twice about it at first pour.  Amazing great things like this can come in a can.

Big glass at Bocktown for $6.  Big foamy off white head. Color is hazy iced tea. Big hoppy aroma, like clean pine needles. Big citrus grapefruit rind flavor. Quite an impact on the taste buds. It gives me the feeling like there is perfumy dish soap in this brew. Some mild carbonation. Hops are very one sided and overwhelming. A little sweet initially with each taste but that turns into an offensive bitter bite after it¬ís in your mouth for a while. A little too much for my girlie lager taste buds. Very coarse and very annoying on the finish, as expected for this style. Will not buy again.
user_location: Beaver Valley, Beaver County, Pennsylvania, USA

text: Wow the nose on this baby is like walking through the hop farm while eating caramels.  Smells like an IPA but is dark amber in color.  This must be poured from its can.  Medium bodies with sweet malts and  and big bitter hoppiness that lasts to the finish.

Can, tasted with beermouth: Paid around 8,50 US dollars for this 33cl can. (Lets keep that a secret) Clear red amber with a full white head. Sweet malts, caramel & sugar & a power hoppy aroma & taste. Far from thick body, though filling & very smooth. Oily & sticky palate. Good lacings. Medium carbonation. Bitter hoppy lasting end - soapy & flowery hops... Wauw... Great Ish!
On can, thanks to dedollewaitor... Clear reddish amber like with good solid white head. Nice hoppyness and good fruity caracter. Lot¬ís of caramel, malt and sweet spices. Fine lacings.
Nose is orange and piney hops, orange/copper colour, pours a small off-white head. Flavour has loads of orange, pine and malts.  Full bodied, well balanced, bitter and ever so tasty. Great example!

(Can, Bishop¬ís Arms, J√§rntorget, Gothenburg, 1 Aug 2007) Dark amber colour with frothy off-white head. Fruity, hoppy nose with notes of grapefruit, pine needles and resin. Frutiy, hoppy taste with pine needles, resin, grapefruit and citrus peel. Full body with slightly oily mouthfeel. Sweetness is rather balanced, with notes of marzipan coming through the wall of hops towards the finish. Great beer, the best canned beer I¬íve tried this far.
Draft.  Battery acid brown coloring.  Limited head.  Hoppy, rye, tart.  I need to re-sample later on - I had to cut short my note-taking - and fear I haven¬ít done this one justice.

UPDATED: AUG 27, 2011 
Name: Gordon
Date: March 04, 2005
Mode: Bottle
Source: Tasting, RateBeer SE Gathering, 2005
Appearance: dark amber
Aroma: strong hop aroma with lots of citrus grapefruit character
Flavor: nice sweet malt flavor well balanced with lots of hop flavor, nice mild bitter finish

Name: Gordon
Date: January 19, 2006
Mode: can
Appearance: dark amber with suspended yeast particals, thin cream head, lots of lace
Aroma: sweet grapefruit aroma with lots of carmel sweetness creating that targeted sugar coated grapefruit
Flavor: big carmel malt flavor with a nice dose of hops, carmel sweetness holds its own against the hops, long bitter finish
Overall: a good drinking big IPA but lost by today¬ís standards

Name: Gordon
Date: May 12, 2006
Mode: draft
Source: brick store
all sweet pine, nice pepppered hops, great lace, lots and lots of pepper

Name: Gordon
Date: January 24, 2007
Mode: can
after a year in a cold fridge the hops fall off as expected but in their place is a great rich dark caramelized caramel sweetness that nicely offset by earthy bitterness, different but no better or worse after a year

Name: Gordon
Date: August 13, 2011
Mode: draft
Source: tmac kennesaw
Appearance: muddy dark red, dense beige head, heavy lace
Aroma: bready and earthy aroma, hint of pine
Flavor: rich sweet caramel malt flavor, touch of breadyness, balancing hops, touch of citrus and pine, sweet pine comes out as it warms along with a touch of spicy pepper, medium bitter finish
Overall: much like the year old can, but I was thinking this was a recent batch that came to town

Aroma: 8/10; Appearance: 8/10; Flavor: 7/10; Palate: 6/10; Overall: 15/20
Rating: 3.7/5.0Drinkability: 7/10
Score: *** /4

What a surprise this is - true quality in a can. Lovely red amber colour with a nice lasting tan head. Lots of flowery hops in the nose. Quite sweet flavour with notes of caramel breaking through the hoppiness. Smashing stuff.

Unexpected greatness in a little silver can.  Beautiful amber color and cream-colored head.  A very drinkable strong ale and one that achieves the right balance that so many strong ales are unable to pull off.

12oz can
Recieved in trade with RustyDiamond

Gordon pours with an amber body with glowing orange highlights when backlit. A creamy one finger beige head formed on the pour that fell to a half finger while leaving sheet lacing that slowly falls back into the body leaving some stragglers.

Much bigger malt backbone than I expected. Huge caramel malt, actually some of the best smelling sweetest caramel malts I can recall. Juicy brown sugar sweetened grapefruit juice. Fairly simple and straight forward but delicious.

The can says this beer is "Big. Red. Sticky." Couldn¬ít have been said any better. Much like the aroma the flavor has that huge sweet smooth caramel maltiness. Brown sugar sweetened grapefruit add another layer of sweetness along with a mild bittering component. I¬ím usually more into the hop bombs but this is a masterful cretion of maltiness.

Medium bodied with an incredible lush smoothness. Slight alcohol fumes rise on the finish. Fantastic mouthfeel.

An incredibly easy drinking high abv beer. This beer would be in constant rotation if I lived in their distrobution area.

Another great beer from Oskar Blues. I¬íve tried three of their offering and everyone was great, not just good, great. Keep canning these brews, I want to try them all.

8/24/07
on tap @ Coles Buffalo NY. Amber colored with hoppy & aroma. hops well balanced with sweeter malts. nice beer but prefer more hop bitterness
Pours nice clear amber with a foamy white head.  Very hoppy/floral aroma.  Soft, buttery, sweet, hoppy taste.  Finish of caramel with a slightly bitter end.  Wonderfull beer.  Best beer in a can.
A dry and piny version of the strong ale. Makes this a guzzler of an ASA. Beautiful big red and sticky appearance. Love Oskar Blues, Love the can. Thanks Beerlando.

Canned. 
Dark orange colour with average head. Musty, tea-ish hoparoma, something in between of citruses, grapes and nuts. Sweet malty with caramel and loaded with flavouring hops. Bit woody with rounded mouthfeel. Not as biter as the 2IPas but bitter enough. Very good, tasty beer.

UPDATED: SEP 5, 2011 12oz can from my Secret Santa - thanks, Santa! Really fine looking brew, with a deep ruby-to-brown body and modest head. Amazing how much quality canned beer is out there these days. Something about the aggressive hop profile and the smooth caramel just screams Arrogant Bastard to me. And though Gordon ranks just a shade below, the comparison is largely favorable. Big props to this one.

Sampled during Cellar¬ís Wine & Spirits Friday evening beer tasting in St Paul, MN. Pours a coppery orange amber brew with a decent white head that has a good retention and lacing. Aroma of caramel malt, honey, papaya and some citrusy spruce. Taste is medium bodied, light carbonation with flavors of smooth caramel malt and apricot flavor. Finish is slightly hoppy bitter with a fruity aftertaste. It appears that Oskar Blues has their canning system working above par.

12 oz can. Thanks for splitting the 4-pack iowaherkeye. Poured a clear reddish-orange color. Head was a prodigious three fingers high and off white. It was so sticky that it lasted until the bottom of the glass. Plenty of lace was left behind. Attractive aroma of caramel, citrusy hops, dried apple, and apricot. Sweet, oily, and smooth on the tongue with a fruit and malt dominated flavor consisting of burnt toffee, peach,  caramel, and a squeeze of grapefruit. There is a lingering honey covered nut accent. The hop bitterness is on the low end of the spectrum and only peeks out in the last few moments.

Bottle. High creamy and long lasting almost orange head. Clear cobber body. Apple, pear, peach, oranges, nuts aroma with a nice shot of hops. Flavor astonishingly fresh and fruity and has a fair amount of hops bitterness. Good balance between the frutyness, the bitterness and the relativly high alcohol percentage. Low carbonation, good and dry long aftertaste.
can. Pours copper/amber with a medium off white head.  Sweet malt and citrus hops. Taste is the same.  cloying and not my style.

12 oz can. A deep copper pour with a medium tan head. A strong hops aroma greets you right away. A flavor that is heavy malt followed by a very nice warmth. A bitter that isn¬ít as harsh as the aroma would indicate. A palate that is full and smooth with very nice middle of the road carbonation that a beer this big needs to be successful in my opionion. Not the hop monster that I expected from the nose but a very good beer.
Tasty, thick, hoppy, malty concoction which reminds me of Arrogant Bastard a bit.  Very nice stuff.

I still can¬ít believe I just poured this from a can. Everything I love about an ASA - loads of hops, coming through here with some bitterness and some serious pine flavors, balanced out by a solid malt backbone, here with some subtle chocolate and caramel sweetness. We need more canned beer that tastes so great.

Can. Pours a clear amber color with s longlasting off-white head. Maly hoppy piney citrus aroma. Sweetish malty hoppy piney flavor with some hints of grapefruit. Long malty finish with some weak chocolate hints and it has a long bitter aftertaste.

From the can.  Aroma is malty and sweet with a lot of citrus hop character.  Appearance is a cloudy copper.  Flavor is an even malt/hop balance followed by a ton of earthy hops; grassy and musty.  Mouthfeel is medium bodied, round, with low carb texture.  Overall, it¬ís just way too earthy and doesn¬ít have nearly a wide enough range of hop flavors.  Maybe I¬ím sensitive to something in it, as most of my friends love this too, but I just don¬ít get this beer as everyone else does, and I love everything else from the brewery.

Canned at The Rover, G√∂teborg.  Clear orange-brown, small head. Striking lychee aroma. Sweet and rounded with medium body. Bready and lightly fruity, very hoppy. Lingering very bitter finish where some light saccharine disturbs a little. Best beer out of a can?

dark copper with a thick tan head....sweet aroma of citrus and malts..smooth caramel and hops taste...bitter finish with a hint of alcohol...lots of lacing left on glass..thick mouthfeel with a little bit of cardboard...great tasting beer

Beer can sampled with stegosaurus. Pours a dark copper color with a white head. Aroma of citrus, piney hops, and caramel malts. Flavor follows the aroma and is well balanced with a nice dry finish. Best beer out of a can i ever had.

Can.  Cascade aroma, grapefruit with light caramel.  Orange-amber pour with a large creamy/rocky/dense/spoonable/smooth cream-colored head.  As for taste, medially bitter and mild with measured hoppiness and a little caramel grit.  The Cascades are really coming through here in a different way - very expressive.  Touch of orange and yeast, touch of Stone AB hoppiness.  Grapefruit and faint pine sap.  Medium-full body with a slick, sticky feel and a dry, sticky, hoppy aftertaste.  Despite the heft from the alcohol, and though it only sets in late, this can be drunk rapidly and in great quantity, or sipped and savored.  I have been very impressed by OB¬ís lineup - everything offering is solid.  Bravo!

Poured an amberish copper color with a small white head. It has a really nice look to it. The aroma is of big piney hops with some grapefruit and citrus in there as well. The flavor is big with the hops, some citrus, and a hint of sweetness to mellow out the hops. The hops don¬ít overpower, but you get that bitter finish at the end. The finish was smooth, but you could still feel the hops on the palate. This beer had a lot going on in it. It was monster hops, but I liked how it didn¬ít overpower the flavor. Another great canned beer from Oskar Blues.
Draft. Another great product from Lyons, Colorado.  Glad to have this one year round.  tannish creamy head.  noticable hops.  great beer.

Canned (thanks heemer77!). Dark coppery colour with huge offwhite creamy head, which leaves a lot of lacing behind. Aroma is big time hops (grass, hay as well as freshly cut wood). Flavour is very much the same, strong hops along with a slight creamy touch and some slight stinging alcohol in the finish.
Muddy brown.  Nice refreshing hoppines aroma.  Bitter hoppy taste.  Taste not refreshing at all, because the bitterness lingers too long.

UPDATED: SEP 24, 2010 Rated 7/22/07.  Cloudy amber color with a beautiful, pillowy, cream colored head.  Excellent lacing all the way down the glass.  Lively but balanced carbonation.  Aroma is strong and hoppy, with mostly grassy, citrusy and herbal hops, accompanied by heaps of sweet caramel malt.  Flavors are largely the same, again giving bold citrus, pine, and grass hop notes amidst ample caramel malt sweetness.  Not overly complex.  Well executed in its simplicity.  Heavy on the sweet side.  Sticky on the finish, as advertised.  Good in small doses on rare occasions, but nothing I¬íd drink regularly.

Probably the best DIPA I have had since Moylander.  Deep amber in color with a nice white head.  Oozing hop aroma.  Hops are mainly citric and biting with an excellent malt bone, very rich, with a hind of dryness.  The burn isn¬ít there like on some.  Very nice.

This is MY kinda Brew right HERE....if you don¬ít like this "Big. Red. Sticky." Beer, you must have a slit where your meat and potatoes are supposed to be.....I¬ím serious when I say the following...since this is in a can most people won¬ít recognize, I¬ím gonna start drinkin¬í and drivin¬í again...it¬ís ON like GordON, mahfuckas.

This is ok but not such a great DIPA, which it clearly is despite the description.  Burnt orange with a bit of haze.  Small off white head.  Citrus aroma with a hint of grass.  Body is a little thick, syrupy.  Mildly unpleasant aftertaste.  A touch of alcohol hotness.  Overally I¬ím dissapointed, especially since their other two beers are so strong.

NorCal tasting July 07 - A double IPA in a can? Whoa. Thanks to beerguy101 (I think) for bring this one. First whiff of the beer and there was some clear floral and citrus notes coming from the glass, with a very subtle piney profile luring around underneath. Appearance is burnt orange/copper in color, nice off-white one-finger head. It felt a little too harsh on in my mouth for my liking. A generous helping of juicy citrus hop character along with some malty goodness makes this one interesting DIPA from a can. I would have probably rated it higher had the hops been more prominent (a DIPA should be all about the hops IMO). Since I¬íve never had a DIPA from a can, this is clearly the best one I¬íve had.

UPDATED: FEB 13, 2009 Almost clear orange-copper body topped by a small beige head.  Hops flavour has a lot of pine-tree and some floral notes.  Sparse soft carbonation.  Lots of hops essence.  Could have been a bit crisper.  I never met Gordon Knight, the man honoured by this beer.  But judging by the beer I¬íd say he was a sweet man.  He was also very bitter but his bitterness would quickly go away.  He had an alcohol breath.  He was a down-to-earth person (not very fruity).  He also had a heavy body and he should have showered more often cause he had an oily, very very oily body.

Medium to Dark Amber Color with Off White Skin.  Piney and Citrusy Aroma with Subtle Sweet Malt Notes as Well. Medium Bodied. Crispy and Lightly Creamy Mouthfeel.  Some Nice Caramel Toffee Notes..Along with Agressive, but Balanced Citrusy Hops...Some Piney Qualities to it.  Very Smooth for a Strong Ale.  Caramel and Hopped Finish.  Oskar is a Wonderful Taste Illustration of What I would Picture in a West Coast Beer.

Can at The Rover in G√∂teborg. This was one of the highlights of the evening for me on our small Gothenburg pub-crawl in July 2007, and it kind of feels wrong to put a beer like this in a can ;) It¬ís warm golden with a nice, creamy head. The aroma is beautiful and alluring with hoppy notes of pine, citrus and fruit. The mouthfeel is smooth and oily. The flavour has an impressive caramel-base, loads of citrus, pine, slightly sweet citrus fruits and a lot of other hoppy notes and a nice bitterness - yummi, I fell in love with this one... 2379

Pours a reddish orange out of the can with a small white head.  I was looking forward to this one.  There is something fascinating about beer from a can that is good.  Anyways, it is a strong brew, very hoppy, nose of floral hops and pine.  Taste was much the same, with just enough malt to balance it out.  Very nice beer.

UPDATED: FEB 3, 2008 really nice amber color, thick creamy head, wicked lacing on my glass....looks like glue! Wow, the hops aroma is really nice, and floral. The flavour is huge on the hops, and the malt balances it out really nicely. Very well balanced beer. Wicked stuff, and the 8.7% is nowhere to be found, this is quality beer! I would say this is a DIPA.

Canned.
Golden with a creamy, off-white head.
Sweet and flowery hoppy nose.
Sweet flavour with pine and citrus. Flowery hoppiness here aswell.

Canned, at the Rover, G√∂teborg. Nice shiny amber color, creamy offwhite head. Hoppy, citric aroma, fruity, grassy and with pine apple notes.Hoppy bitter, metallic and grassy flavor with some malts bringing balance. Some apple notes can be found.

Can (50 cl) at the Rover, G√∂teborg, Sweden. Clear amber with a medium creamy off-white head. Intense fruity malt aroma, hops add more fruitiness, pine needles and floral notes. Medium bodoed and very smooth. Perfect balance with a rich malt sweetness and an intense bitterness. A truly great beer.

Can, and this was my most expencive beer in a can Ive have paid for, just have to say it!  Dark red colur, nice creamy head. aroma of lots of hops!!,flowers citric,and a malty aroma in the end. Whow what a bomb of hops here was! Flavor is fruity,hopy,and almost the same as in the aroma,smouth mouth feeling,medium to great body,long finish. This was the best beer in a can of 0,35 Ive had try, so it was ok, for the cost of this. Great beer,thake a bow folks!

True red ale. This is the hoppiest red ale I have ever tasted. It is very sticky and like Dales the head is very foamy and is of a darker orange and brown, that kind of creeps out of the top of the can. This has a great hop aroma and a sweet finish.

Hoppy smells just smacks you in the face. What a great smell. It has a more mature smell than the Dales Pale Ale. The smell is sweet and hoppy. The beer has a dark amber color with a nice creamy smell. This beer was definitely worth the price of $12 per 4-pack. This beer has the qualities of both an I.P.A. and a Strong Ale. The beer is nice and hoppy, but also has the ability of giving me a sweet caramel/fruit taste. This beer is great, and the high IBU content does not take over the flavor of the beer. What a fine and delicious beer. I am very much impressed. Any company that can combine an I.P.A. flavor and a Strong Ale, has my vote. Go Oskar Blues!

12 ounce can from Beers of the World in Rochester, NY (June 2007), consumed July 1 2007.  Can is popped without a whimper, but the beer cascades into my Allagash glass, a bit below cellar temperature, into a perfectly beautiful translucent bronze liquid topped by a tremendously lasting big-bubbled off-white head that leaves fine spidery lacing ¬Ö..very, very fresh resinous hop nose, lots of grapefruit and some interesting whiffs of gingerbread dosed with caramel, close to perfect if you like very forward, acidic PNW hop bouquets ¬Ö¬Öthe mouthfeel, too syrupy-slick for me, and the carbonation level so low, really belying the appearance ¬Ö.flavor is good, but doesn¬ít live up to the fine aroma, old dry candy sweetness like slightly stale caramel creams mixing with dessicated oranges and mangos, alcohol rather too forward at the fairly bitter finish ¬Ö.a mixed bag altogether, as I¬íve found all of the Oskar stuff thus far.

Can. Amber with off-white head. Aroma is piney and lots of grapefruit hops. Full bodied  Flavor: Much of everything, a lot of maltiness and citric bitterness. The strength is well hidden, but on the whole a bit too much.

tasted in the studio library after the "2:40" tasting at www.wfmu.org with Scott Williams on 6/29.  color is a deep reddish copper, light amber at edges.  light tan yellowish head.  aroma is syrupy malt like a barley wine, with fresh hops and grapefruit/orange peel.  flavor is deep sweet vinuous malt, some deep caramel, with more fresh hops and bitter citrus.  nice hybrid of styles, although I don¬ít know if I¬íve had enough imperial ambers to compare.
Golden orange with an off white head. Aroma of hops and malt. Loaded with hops, finishes sweet with a big thick mouth feel.  Awesome beer.

12 oz can thanks to john_adam for this trade.  Pours a orange gold with a beige head.  Nose of malt and citrus, nothing to defining but nice.  Mouthfeel is really creamy.  Malty carmel citrus flavors a decent bitterness.  Refreshing and tasty.

UPDATED: SEP 8, 2011 First rating from back in 2007355 ml can at The Rover, G√∂teborgClear copper color, white head. Extreme fruity hoppy citrus scent. Very bitter hoppy apricot taste. Smooth mouthfeel, big bitterness.9/3/7/4/15=3.8RerateCan at Rotary, G√∂teborg, on September 2, 2011Hazy brown color, big lasting off-white head. Cream malty scent. Hoppy cream taste. Smooth mouthfeel, medium high bitterness.7/5/8/4/16=4.0

12 oz can.  Pours dark orange color with white head.  Smells like malts and piney hops, neither one overpowering the other.  Lots of flavor... taste is similar to Dale¬ís, but somewhat stronger.  Medium sweetness.  If it weren¬ít so unnecessarily expensive, this would be a regular for me.

UPDATED: JUN 29, 2007 (Bottle) Pours amber red. Strong green hop aroma with a lot of pine, grapefruit and black currant. Also some apricots, resin, blood oranges and hints of lychee. All the hops almost burnes your nose hair. Malt brings caramel and some honey are also present. Light to medium sweet flavour with hoppy tones of pine, oranges, black currant tea and light grapefruit. Some caramel. Round and a bit sticky mouthfeel Medium to full bitterness. Dry. Grape peel tart-ish finish. Medium full body.

Can: Deep rusty copper/ orange color with clarity and a well retained tan head. Very nicely aromatic which is full of cascades and various sweet American hops. Some lemon cookies and citruses. The body/mouth feel is a bit lacking. There¬ís definitely lots of malt in the flavor though, giving it a slightly slick mouth feel. The hops are there yet don¬ít seem as robust as the aroma. Some what strange papery resin-ish finish. The flavors aren¬ít bad, but seem subdued or restrained somehow. Straight forward and still decent.

Can.  Deep amber with a thick tan head that diminishes to a thin coating rather quickly.   Fruity aroma of oranges, pine, and cookies, but not quite as powerful as I expected.  Moderate hop bitterness (pine, orange peels) in the flavor is accompanied by a nutty, bready sweetness.  Good, but not mind-blowing.

Can.  Ruby red pour with auburn highlights.  The big rich fruity nose reminds me of a barleywine.  A lot of hops in the flavor from beginning to end with fruit tones of cherry and ripe red grape in layers below.  The finishing hops add an almost rose petal while the bittering hops completely obscure the 8.7% ABV.  Very rich full flavor, but the body is only a medium-plus, so it¬ís not quite as "sticky" as the label indicates, but it does make it surprisingly refreshing for an American strong ale.  On a side note, as the beer breathed, the nose and palate seemed to reverse - the nose becoming all hop, while the flavor became more fruity.  This kept the beer complex and interesting through to the end.
Tap at fest : Sparkling amber,lasting beige head.Rich malt/hop nose.Huge malt profile, great long strong hop finish. Chewy and well balanced

Pours a deep amber with one and a helf finger head that settles slowly to a thick cap. The foam leaves behind a nice sheeting of lace.

Smell; piney hop resins with grapefruit and oranges shining through as well. Some nice caramel malt sweetness is present, with a very nice floral aroma floating around the fringes.

Taste; grapefruit and oranges dominate, but the pine is present right behind and there¬ís some other tropical fruits mixed in. Very hoppy, but not crushingly so. The malts do just enough to balance out the hops a little with some caramel and brown sugar. It¬ís a bit sweeter than I expected, but it seems to fit this beer very well.

Mouthfeel is fully bodied and oh so smooth and creamy. This is one of the smoothest beers that I¬íve had in a while, and that only increases the drinkability for me. I picked this up at total wine and more is Sterling, Va and I¬ím glad I finally had a chance to try it. I just hope that I¬íll have another chance to have this again.
user_location: Where the hell am I?, Nebraska, USA

text: Can from mcbackus, thanks Matt! nose of piney citrusy hops; copper-orange with a medium beige head; flavor of piney hop bitterness and a bit of caramel sweetness, but not much. Medium body has a hoppy finish.

Can. Tullip. Orange-amber pour with creamy tan head. Very hoppy aroma with a hint of sweet malt. Pleasantly bitter, but lacking in complexity. Malty notes are accented by a medium-heavy mouth feel. Good.

Can:  Pours a clear copper color with a large, frothy white head.  Nice thick lacing.  Nose is very intense of citrus and piney hops.  Big grapefruit presence.  Taste is more or less an assault of hops with more citrus, floral, and piney hops taste.  Nice finish is dry and lingering with hops bitters.  A slight sweetness is there to balance the large hops presence.  This is very well done.
Delicious. Amber orange color, Great piney aroma. Tastes of malt, some bitterness but not at all overwhelming. A very well balanced imperial IPA. Enjoyed it very much. Thanks Jason.

Tallahassee, Fl. - Market Square Liquors, 12 oz can.  Dark copper - orangish pour with a sticky khaki colored head that leaves good sticky lacing. Very fresh sprucey aroma with hints of maple syrup. Fruity, juicy flavor with some requisite grapefruity citrusy notes and so much more.  Pick up hints of nectarines, apricots, caramel and brown sugar. Extremely thick and creamy mouthfeel. High ABV hidden well in the flavor. Been a while since I gave a rating this high - well deserved.

Big fresh western hop aroma.  Slightly foggy tea color, big persistant bone colored head that hangs onto the side of the glass like a vanilla milkshake.  Deftly balanced - lots of hops, chalky body, light roast, moderately sweet, pear esters.  Finishes with a bitter milkiness and roast.  Very good.  Market Square.
Quite piney hops.  The hops don¬ít overpower it though, as the flavor is very smooth and rich with a hint of fruit cocktail on the finish.

Can sampled with Beerded_one.  Pours hazy orange/deep amber with a small off-white head. Aroma of citrus, slight caramel, and hops. The flavor is caramel, citrus, with a bitter undertone, finishindg dry. Very nice.

Firey amber pour with a lovely staying layer of foam.  Rich pine resin aroma with touches of orange peel, maple syrup.  Subtle but not subdued in flavor.  A hint of aluminum fades into a massive woody bitterness, not exaggerated but rustic and real.  Dried peaches hidden beneath crunchy malt cereal lend momentary brightness before a lightning flash of strawberries toward the end.  Full, lengthy and toasty single malt finish.  Truly intelligent - an impressive example of balance and complexity.  Thanks John!

UPDATED: NOV 30, 2007 12oz can courtesy of mreusch- A nice amber body with a nice white head and an aroma of hops and malt. Taste of hops mixed with malt then malt and hops with a nice dry finish. Great tasting beer.

Wide-mouthed can (which, for the sake of rating, I poured into a glass). Pours hazy red-amber with big, tight ivory head. The aroma is quite malty, with a rich toastiness and caramel sweetness; orange and pine come through, too. The flavor is rich pine up front (though not much bitterness comes out), caramel and toast provide a rich malty support, and wood and orange emerge toward the finish. The aftertaste is a little bit dry, with a tasty mild citrus and pine quality. This is delicious stuff. Even better, I can drink it from the can on my porch without the redneck neighbors thinking I¬ím a douchebag.

Can. Pours amber with a large fluffy white head. Aroma is strongly of fresh pine hops, with a robust slightly sweet caramel malt backbone, and a hint of citrus. Flavor is the same elements, but a bit more malty, with a slight breadiness, wood, and roasted malt finish. This is excellent.

Wow. hops blast out of the can. Really fresh, really pungent. Unique taste. A medly of flavors I¬íve never experienced in an IPA. Sweet, citrusy-orange, bitter, some brandy and alcohol burn. Finishes with heavily toasted malts, cereal, wheatgerm and more hops. Amazing. Can still taste the hops coming up  a few hours later.

Copper pour with a small, loose off-white head.  Generous hop aroma that is mostly pine with a hint of citrus.  Lots of caramel malt background with a hint of wood, some nuttiness too.  Flavor profile is pretty much the same as the aroma with a bit more bready/nuttiness coming out in the finish.  Medium body with a fair amount of carbonation and a dry finish.

From can.  Pours a hazy copper with nice off white head.  Nose is sweet malts and underlying hops.  Flavors follows with a chewy mouthfeel.  Nice light bitter finish.  Really good, but a little too spendy.
Poured a dark amber with a white head. Smells of a ton of hops and malt. Flavor started out with a ton of hops followed by a sweet caramel malt. Well balanced.
12 oz can. Pours cloudy amber with off white head. Hoppy aroma and taste with bitter after taste and very clean finish. Hard to believe it is in a can.

Can; poured a clear orange-copper; small to medium off white head.  Aroma of grapefruit and pine; some caramel malt.  Flavor was smooth and balanced; some creaminess.  Flavor like a DIPA, but doesnt have the same hops punch.  Good balance in the taste of caramel malt and grapefruit.  Alcohol was well hidden; A touch of sweetness.  Very good.

12 oz can.  Pours a cloudy caramel color with a massive beige head.  Aroma of caramel, floral hops and faint pine.  Taste is of rich caramel, and  mild west coast piney hops.  Pretty darn good.  Wish they would bottle this.

A fine choice for by birthday beer! Oh so tasty. Much like a double IPA, but maybe not quite the hops but still a good hop bite in there. Not as sweet as some DIPA which is good. Very smooth going down for sure, i will have aquire more of this from my trading buddy. happy b day to me!!

Va BF 07 Draft: Sweet clover aroma. Copper color, quickly dissipating head and no lacing. Strong thistle and orange flavor. Much of the same stays on the palate, but more like rose petals. Enjoyable and distinctive, quite unique. IPA fans will absolutely love it.
*Previously rated as the whiskey barrel version, which was probably incorrect. H/T to maniac

Pours out of the can with a big white head. Once it settles down, you get to see the nice copper color of the beer. The aroma is slamming, in yo¬í face with hops.There is a little bit of outdoorsy smell in there that brings me back to the woods of the northeast. The hops have a bit of a citrus tinge to it. Goes down smooth, even with all of those hops. Because of the price, I only get this one occasionally, but it is a real treat. All of the beers from this brewery are amazing.

UPDATED: MAY 24, 2007 12 oz can original run with paper label shared with rebelbeerguy. Poured a clear cooper/red with a small white head. Nice strong hoppy aroma with a slight malt backbone. Flavor is mostly hops but could have been a little stronger. Not really sure why this one is so expensive didn¬ít seem to be worth $4.00 for one 12 oz can.
Draft at Virginia Beer festival.  Wow, fantastic strong ale.  Dominant amount of hops in there.  Pines, grapefruit, and some malts.  Hard to really imagine that this is as strong as it says.  Great!

thanks zeswaft.  red toffee brown with a dirty foam head, looks pretty good and maybe 70% opacity.  hops are dominant but a little muted, i like it.  honeyed and a little spicy.  the hops are more like apples than super citrus.  flavor is pretty good.  it¬ís really drinkable for almost 9%.  some bitterness lasts on the tongue.  it¬ís a bit watered down altogether.

UPDATED: MAY 29, 2008 Poured a nice looking dark red mahogany color.  Nose was mostly piny hops, with some brown sugar and wood to back it up.  NIce flavor of caramel, brown sugar, and earthy buttery hops.  Surprisingly mellow finish considering the IBUs and presence of hops in aroma and flavor.  Some pine, butter, and a real smooth bitterness.  I was impressed by this, it reminded me of the winter Yulesmith but in a can!

Opens out of the can with a thick syrupy smell. Good hops balance out the rich hazy sweetness. Alcohol smolders beneath. Plan to try this on tap in Lyons after nailing Hall ranch trail on the bike. Would also make a good campsite beer, canned and cooled in the shade or the creek. A righteous beer.

Had on tap instead of from a can. Pours a bright amber, with medium thick off-white head that liongers atop the glass thru most of the beer, and leaves good lacing. Pleasant aroma of hoppy citrus fruit, joined at mid-glass by a hint of malty sweetness. Tingly mouthfeel brought in the flavor of more hoppy fruit-sweet malt mix. The 8.7% alcohol stayed well hidden in the taste, but by the end of the glass, I could tell it was there. 

Finish was slightly bitter, but not as much as expected. This was a darn good beer!

Can via trade with jayg.  Pours aber with a big 3 finger puffy chunky white head.  The nose is malty and fresh with a nice hoppiness as well.  The taste is very balanced drinkable and sweet.  Some bitterness is nicely equalized.  Very nice brew, thanks jay.

12oz can from MrBendo.  Aroma:  Light grainy maltiness with a touch of sweet caramel.  A strong dose of hops with a big note of citrus and apricot and pine.  Appearance:  Dark reddish amber in color and slightly hazed.  Off-white head was full and creamy with great retention.  Great lacing.  Flavor:  Sweet grainy malt with a strong caramel character.  Hops come in strong with lots of citrus, apricot, and pineapple.  Some pine and grass mixed in there, as well.  Not as bitter as I was expecting.  Some sweetness lingers past the finish.  Palate:  Medium-full bodied.  Medium carbonation.  Light alcohol warming in back of mouth.  Overall:  This was pretty good, but a little too sweet.
Huge hop aroma (more classic hops than citric). In the mouth the intense bitterness is balanced by a big caramel sweetness. The combinantion gives a viscous, herbaceous feeling. Quite interesting

Draft @ Friscos Grille in Columbia, MD. This is a DAMN GOOD BEER! Pours clear caramel / bourbon with small/med head. Like other raters I found it to be well balanced. A great meld of big malt and ton-o-hops. Reminded me of a DFH 90min with not quite as much the malty sweetness to it. I love this beer!
Can.  Very nice hop aroma of grapefruit, floral, and pine; some malt also.  The flavor is well-balanced between caramel malt and citrus / floral hops.  An excellent beer.

Clear amber body with small off-white head. The aroma is light caramel sweetness and citrus hops, but light for the style. The flavor is moderately sweet, grapefruit, apricot, moderate caramel and some tea. Medium body leans to watery.

Wow.  They know how to brew a can of beer.  Cantastic.  Canerific.  This might be the best of the Oskar Blues. I gots me a case of the Oskar Blues....but this cured thats.  At 4.99 for a single, might not be worth it, but this was wonderful.  This did taste surprisingly sweet and balanced.  It looked beautiful and tasted wonderful.

Pours a very cloudy, orangey, gold with a thick, soft white head. The aroma is very hoppy but also intensely fruity. Citrus and hops combined with a fruity malt profile. The flavor follows the aroma - lots of soft fruit, strong malts, balanced well by a ton of floral and fruity hops. The balance is impeccable. The finish is both very bitter from hops but also very fruity and sweet with malts. The after-taste is very hoppy - but not bitter. The mouthfeel is very full bodied, but nice on the tongue - not syrupy. Overall - very delicious!

From can thanks to Jrob_21. Aroma was floral hops, sweet caramel malts and a slight nutty tone. The taste had a strong bitterness along with a good amount of malt. The body was medium with a sweet alcohol finish.

Can, with a thanks to jimbowood for this, pours a clear iced tea brown with a foamy dark tan head that quickly dissipates, good lacing.  Very faint and mild aroma, with little identifiable coming out.  Taste is mild and well balanced, pretty much neutral between the hops and malts.  Not bad on the palate, very smooth, a bit creamy, but generally uninspiring.  A bit warming from the alcohol, but not much else.  Been wanting to try this for some time, and this is my first OB beer, but I hope there is better to come.  Not bad or anything, just ho-hum; hope OB is more careful about throwing around descriptions like Gonzo, Imperial, Massive, etc. without more to back it up on their other beers...

Decent sized frothy white head of fine bubbles.  Light carbonation.  Nice and hoppy aroma.  Loads of sweet malts, spruce and caramel.  Color is a dark mahagony brown.  Big malt presence again with a nice helping of hops to offset the swett malts.  Caramel and more spruce.  Not floral hops.  Strickly resinous evergreen hops.  Nice alcohol presence and warming.  Finishes sweet with a little lingering bitterness.  A very well balanced brew.  Pretty damn good!  Cheers Gordon!

Can, poured into a tulip.  yea can, the new trend of craft brews?  cheaper, ages better, keeps light out..... all plusses, the negative?  association w/ macro-american breweries....
anyway, good beer.. pours a cloudy amber with a hoppy strong aroma.  the beer is light and smooth with the hoppiness coming thru on the finish.  after a few drinks it has a numbing effect on the palate... a good effect... this beer reminded me a lot of Arrogan Bastard but more palatable.  it was very similiar on the finish... goood..... funny to say, but unique because of the can...

12oz Tin Can 
A deep amber color brew.  This was a nice strong ale.  Great flavor and a good use of high flavor hops.  This was a very nice beer.

Cloudy brown, it came to me with a thin head. Aroma was not particularly noticeable but was fairly hoppy. Taste is not complex and has a strong alcohol bite, making it taste almost like a liquor than a beer. Thick and smooth, it has some bitterness in the aftertaste but is still pleasant to drink. This is a beer to be sipped slowly and savored rather than chugged down.

Appearance: Pours a semi-cloudy brown-amber body with a rich, fluffy off-white head.

Smell: Ahh, finally an assertive nose demanding of one¬ís attention! Pacific Northwest hops bring pine and, to a lesser extent, grapefruit to the table, while the malts deliver some caramel, biscuitiness, and maybe even some brown sugar, too.

Taste: Begins with a sweet butterscotch maltiness that¬ís quickly succeeded by a myriad of fruit flavors including grapefruit, peaches, and blood oranges. Eventually, the pine and grassy hop flavors show up to welcome in the bitter, dry (but still somewhat sweet) finish.

Mouthfeel: Medium-bodied. Medium carbonation. Oily texture.

Drinkability: Extraordinarily well-balanced, just as it¬ís secondary Dale¬ís Pale Ale is. A beer good enough to help you pull yourself up out of the muck and make your life something worth living. Thanks a million, Oskar Blues!
Love this beer....lots of hops, yet balanced surprisingly well. So glad we get this in Seattle now. Almost creamy. Yum.

Ok, a canned beer thats 8.7%, and it doesn¬ít say malt liquor on it!....pours a copper color, lacing forming already-impressive....pungent hop aroma...creamy balanced flavor, a little sweet malt with just the right amount of hops

Bought this stuff last weekend in Atlanta. This is by far the best beer I¬íve had out of a can. On to the beer, It pours out a brownish red with a fairly thick tan head. Aroma of grapefruit and pine with a strange bitterness that I couldn¬ít put my finger on. Taste is great with a sweetness of caramel and malt that sort of gave the beer a thicker taste to me. Next your tounge is assaulted by all the citrus and floral flavors of the hops. The alcohol is present but not nearly as harsh as expected at 8.7%! Great beer.

Poured a dark amber color with a medium sized, off white head that left nice lacing on the glass.  Aroma of pine, floral hops, citrus fruits, with some sweet caramel malts balancing that out.  Taste of citrus fruits, pine, caramel malts, tobacco, and a bitter grapefruit finish, with some alcohol backing up the bitter hops. As with all IIPAs, this one is better fresh!

On tap @ Oskar Blues.  Cloudy dark amber colored pour with a small creamy looking off-white head.  Great hoppy nose - a lot of grapefruit.  Smooth and refreshing mouthfeel, prefect amount of carbonation for the style.  Awesome grapefriut hop flavor, not too sweet like a lot of beers this strong.

Thanks to jimbowood for the trade.  Maybe I should have left this can sit a while after opening the trade box.  The can burst open and squirted everywhere as soon as I touched the tab. The beer flooded into my snifter and nearly overflowed. The pour is a muddy brownish red. The head is big from the pour but it is now a creamy layer of lace and chunks. I¬ím not sure of the aroma. I remember Dale¬ís being hoppier than this. Although the bigger malt is more evident. The flavor is very smooth and well blended. The hops and malts couldn¬ít be much more balanced and smooth, but that isn¬ít really what I was hoping for. I guess I was expecting a lot more hops presence after drinking Dales with all the  sharp hops.  Lucky for me I have three more of these; maybe it will change my mind.

Cloudy copper, thinnish tan head.  Nose is caramel, pine, fruit (mostly orange), brown sugar, malt.  Flavor is caramel, piney orangey hops.  A hint of lemon in a very bitter finish.  Body is a bit thin.

Nice hoppy nose! Color is deep amber with reddish hue. The flavor is hoppy with a nice bitter quality. Somewhat dry with a nice balance of malt and a touch of fruit. Caramel isn¬ít overbearing and the alcohol is extremely well hidden. The can given to me is a variation of the can pictured and is rated 8.7%ABV

Can.  Pour is amber is a large, solid white head.  A bunch of lacing, a very nice looking pour.  Aroma is pine and sweetness, baker¬ís cocoa maybe.  Initial taste is strong hops, though balanced nicely with malt.  The sweetness remains in the taste, though more caramel now.  Finish is bright and clean.  No trace of alcohol in this one.  Great beer all around, tough at $5 a can, certainly not an everyday beer.
Awesome pine aroma.  Nice looking beer, too--smooth and creamy head with good lacing.  Goes down exceptionally smooth for 90 IBUs and 9.2% ABV.  Is comparable to a strong pale ale.

Another great beer from a can. Had to pour a little just to see the beer, but drank the rest from the can. Light copper body with a nice white head. Floral hops on the nose, slight sweet malts. Big hop taste balanced nicely with some caramel and fruit. Very well balanced.
tap at mcgraths pub.  Very similiar to a stronger IIPA, decent body, little thick.  Sweet Hoppy aroma, Flavour is dominated by Fruity Hops with a bit of spice, pretty decent.

Can.  A deep copper pour with a smallish light-tan head.  Pretty bubbly.  A decent amount of both hops and caramel in the well-balanced nose.  Goes down pretty smooth with just as much balance.  Some nice caramel and hints of apple juice upfront followed by bitter hoppy notes at the end.  Some musty, funkiness in the middle.  Pretty good, but 3 bucks and some change for a 12 oz. can is ridiculous.  My can says 8.7% ABV and doesn¬ít look as cool as the one pictured either.

From the can, it pours a nice copper color with a thick, rocky white head.  Aroma is very hoppy - citrus, pine and a smidge of floral.  Flavor started off with the hoppy notes, but eventually the malt come to the front.  Somewhat sweet, fruity, caramelly.  Alcohol is pretty well hidden.  Enjoyable.  Pricing is perhaps a little out of whack.

Ok, first beer rating from a can. Not much carbonation on opening. Kind of a quiet opening unlike most cans. Clear copper with about an inch initially of froth. Settling down quickly. Huge hop aroma typical hoppy IPA. Pine, citrus and caramel. Very smooth body and low carbonation. A bit chewy. Chocolate malt hit me right away, followed by intense bitter hops. Wow! Lots of hops in this one. Reminds me of fresh Bigfoot. Malt definitely present in flavor especially chocolate in the finish. For sure best beer I¬íve ever had in a can.
user_location: Cape Coral Waterfront Wonderland, Florida, USA

text: Good for it¬ís style with lots of hops and balancing malt.  A potent lacey mix with cloudy yellow and beige head. Hoppy "C" aroma.  Some citrus, drying aftertaste.
Dark copper color with no head.  Strong aroma of Cascade hops and fresh oranges.  The taste was okay, but almost a letdown, consisting just of slightly bitter malt and weak oranges.  Ho hum.

Tried from both draft and can today. Pours a copper-amber color with a very generous head. Lacing is about as good as it gets for an imperial ipa. The aroma was grapefruits and pine, light floral. The flavor followed suit, some resinous overtones that seemed to come out more in the aftertaste. With increasing temperatures, the malts got a little too strong, somewhat sweet and fruity, oranges and other light fruits and melons mixed in there. The mouthfeel was the main distinguishable difference between the tap and can, little creamier from the can (almost nitrogen-like), yet on par for the style from both. A nice but not excellent dIPA.

can: pours a wonderful red chestnut coour with a small white head. aroma is hoppy  citrus and pine.  some nice sweet malt also.  flavour is a creamy hop flavour that is earthy and sweet. finishes a nice bitter. pretty well balanced IMO. very good glad to have it available.

12oz can.  Awesome.  Pours a beautiful ruby color with a soapy white head and some sediment.  Impressive lacing.  Smells creamy, grassy, maybe some grapefruit, hoppy, sweet, unique.  Creamy mouthfeel with a smooth, hoppy, bitter taste.  Piney and sweet.  Afterwards when I burp it tastes like mad grapefruit.  The alcohol is hidden wonderfully on this.  This is a solid, overpriced beer.  I¬íll probably buy this again but sparingly, if only for the price.

Thanks to Beerdrenched  for sharing this beer.  Pours clear bonze with a tan head.  The aroma is woody, earthy and green pine with bits of butteriness.  Medium / full body with a small amount of carbonation.  The taste starts with caramel malt and some woody hops.  The finish has some cardboard and woody hops and butterscotch.  This was alright - the good parts were quite good, the bad parts really took away from things.  It seems like this has some age on it, I would love to try this fresh.
This is a big beer.  I thought the hops came through aloing with the alchohol.  It packed a punch but also had some subtleness that really came through the beer.  Nice job.

First impression is: where¬ís the hops?  Slick and smooth mouthfeel, but really lacking in something.  Just doesn¬ít have the hops I expected.  That same soapy malt flavor that the Dale¬ís has.  Comes off a bit flat.  No alcohol whatsoever.  No bitterness.  Tastes like an amber.  Rich caramel malt.  A little spicy, floral hops.  None of the sharp hop flavor I get from cascades; completely smoothed out by the malt.  Incredibly easy drinking and tasty, but lacking the hops I wanted in a 9% imperial.

12oz can.  Why a can?  I heard good things about this, but it really fell short of my expectations.  The nose was good, with abundant fresh hops and grapefruit rind.  The head was large and "dry;" it kind of floated atop the beer itself and moved around independently of it.  Flavor was hoppy, kind of grassy, with a weird maltiness with dark fruits that I did not particularly enjoy within this style.  The beer seemed to go flat towards the end of the glass too.  Not great.

12 oz Can!-pours a clear orange color w/a moderate white head. Definite hop aroma, reminds you of an IPA. Moderate floral hop flavor, but it¬ís not overpowering. Had some pine & citrus overtones, w/a little bit of dates & figs. I thought this was an IPA, reminded me of a moderate one. Pretty good stuff. Long spicy finish
UPDATED: MAR 25, 2007 A very good pale ale.  Huge hop aroma and assertive but one dimensional hop flavor.  I had no idea the alcohol was so high.  Very drinkable.
Strong spruce hop aroma. Hazy orange color with a medium lasting head. Not that much hop bit to the taste. Slight alcohol comes through in the finish. No bite from the alcohol.
UPDATED: AUG 15, 2007 Woody hop nose with light brown color and a small covering of white head.  Bitter floral bite that end dryly
Thanks to brewfiend for the treat.  Nice mahogeny amber color.  Great woody floral nose.  Nice floral bite that dries out very nicely.  Great citrus profile.  The finish is spectacular.
user_location: Farewell Minny; Hello Puyallup, Washington, USA

text: UPDATED: JUL 17, 2007 12 oz. can. Hops dominate the superb aroma, which features lemon, pine, pomegranate, and grass notes. Pours a clear golden brown with a large amount of thick, uneven, cream/tan-colored head. Produces extensive lacing. The beautiful foam rivals that of top Belgians, but the liquid is rather ordinary in appearance. The taste is not nearly as hoppy as the aroma implies and is in fact very malty. The alcohol is noticeable but not overpowering or offputting. Soapy yeast elements complement the sweet carmel malt. Medium-bodied, smooth, and undercarbonated in the palate. Easy to drink. If a typical good amber ale is pleasant, then this "imperial" amber ale is very pleasant. Oskar Blues Gordon is memorable, unique, and exciting. I love the cans and strongly encourage more brewers to switch to them. Thanks to iradog for picking this up on his trip to Colorado.

Thanks Ira for picking this up while you were in Boulder.  This beer has a strong grapefruit and pine aroma.  Nice, I could smell this all day.  A reddish orange body with a tight bubbled creamy head with excellent lacing noted.  I also detect some caramel malts in the nose.  Flavor is not as hoppy and more malt forward, but regardless this is a very well balanced brew.  I¬ím thinking this is why it is categorized as an American strong ale vs. IIPA.  RIP Gordon Knight, they made a nice brew for you.  One last note...did I detect some mint?? in the finish.

I drink this brew in tribute to the late Gordon Knight. In addition to opening some of Colorado¬ís first microbreweries, Knight was a Vietnam vet, grade-A citizen, and huge promoter of craft beer. He lost his life in 2002 while fighting a wild fire outside of Lyons, Colorado. Cheers to you Gordon. Pours a brilliant redish/orange with a huge frothy dirty white head. The aroma is hops, raisin, bready malt, and pine/herbal hops. The flavor doesn¬ít quite match up to the robustness of the aroma. Some herbal hop flavor going on with some earth notes. Pine and metallic notes make up the finish. The mouthfeel is a little sticky with some alcohol warming. Body is solid. Good hop character all around.

On tap at the brewpub. Flowery white pepper and chamomile aroma, with fragrant hop juice and wisping salts. Pours a lightly clouded golden, darkish, with soapy foam in ivory. Flavor dominated by a singing catty Simcoe hop presence, unpleasent. Very cat, lemon, urine like. However, the hops are clean, clear and well-defined. And the beer hides it¬ís alcohol deftly and with good higher alcohol support of the beer. It finishes clean and feels light and heavily drinkable. However, this particular hop character is not particularly pleasing to me.

This is decadently delicious! my gawd. Had it this evening at the Bodega Brew Pub dowtown La Crosse, Wisconsin.  Be nifty if they¬íd put this on draft also like their others. Very hoppy of course but so perfectly balanced and matched to the rest of the beers character. Some of the beer styles here are confusing so I won¬ít dwell on that suffice to say this is Miiiiiiiiiiiiiighty Fiiiiiiiiiiiine brew. Oh yes.

UPDATED: APR 1, 2007 12 oz can.  Darker reddish-amber color with big off-white head.  Aroma is dominated by big piney hops.  Taste is somewhat sweet with very bready malts balancing gently with piney-herbal hops.  A bit thinner than expected.  It could be my imagination, but I do detect just a hint of metal in the aftertaste - I guess I¬íll have to try this on tap.  Definitely the best canned beer I¬íve ever had.  I¬ím just a bit confused as this beer was originally under the DIIPA category if I remember right.  Like Troegs Nugget Nectar, it calls itself "Imperial Amber", and I have to say its similar in many ways, but doesn¬ít quite match the superior NN in my opinion.  Still pretty happy Oskar Blues cans and widely distributes this one though..........RE RATE FROM DRAFT - METALLIC TASTE GOES AWAY AND QUALITY GOES UP.  STILL HAPPY TO HAVE CANS AVAILABLE.

My new favorite canned beer!  A lovely warm clear amber with an offwhite head, thin. The nose is rather ridiculous.  Big nasty herbal resin.  The nose has some malt, but it just barely matches the herbal green hops.  Full and rich in the mouth, creamy and a bit sticky.  Really very nice.  The flavor are unfortunately a cut below the aroma, but mostly because this beer is so out of balance it isn¬ít even funny.  But it still is delicious.  Creamy green hop resin with a bit of sweet light malt.  This malt would need to be so round and sweet and cloying to balance the fresh resinous piney tones here that it would probably not really be all that drinkable, so it¬ís a double edged sword.  It¬ís not that this beer is bitter, or for that matter hoppy.  It¬ís that the hops that are here (in abundance) taste and smell exceedingly fresh.  There¬ís a little diacetyl in the finish, but I won¬ít hold that against it as the aftertaste becomes big with lingering hop resin shortly thereafter, and in a rather clean way.  As this warms, it loses its balance more so, getting more boozy and less malty.  Still a great brew.

Can from Broudy¬ís Liquor. Poured dark amber color with an average frothy off-white head that was mostly lasting with fair lacing. Moderate balanced caramel malt and spruce hoppy aroma with a small alcohol tone. Medium to full body with slick texture. Heavy balanced bittersweet flavor with a medium bittersweet finish of moderate duration. This is a standout brew.
Fantastic, the aroma is deep Mahogany amber with smell of wood, and strong earth style hops. the malts shows real character with the taste of caramel and the mouth feel. Alcohol is well covered.

Draft at Capone¬ís. Amber body with nice size head. Very hoppy aroma. Taste was syrupy and sweet, cherry hovering a little bit in there. Had a nice bite to it, decent carbonation. How is this not an IIPA?

UPDATED: OCT 12, 2007 Can. Trappist Glass.  Red amber color, decent head.  Aroma of strong citrus (grapefruit) hops with some caramel.  The taste, however displays the malt, caramel and some fruit to go along with the citrus hops.  Smooth body with a brominated vegetable oil coating of the palate.  A strong hop monster that is balanced by malt and caramel.

UPDATED: AUG 12, 2007 Rerate.  When did they change this to an American Strong Ale?  This 12oz can is painted (and says 8.7%).  Pours a clear copper with a one finger beige head that fades to a creamy film in a minute or two.  Pine, grapefruit, spicy hops, and a thick scorched caramel, almost toffee backbone--check that, I have now decided there¬ís toffee.  I do get a touch of alcohol and some toasted malts.  Flavor has an added herbal character, and wasn¬ít as intense with the bitterness as I¬íd expected from the aroma.  Bitterness peaks at a 4 out of 10.  The nice toasted malt and scorched toffee meld well overall with the "subtle" hops--if you can really call it that.  Full creamy body with soft light to moderate carbonation.  I did enjoy this can better than the previous one.  Old rating follows12oz can from Paul (Dickinsonbeer), big thanks!  This was a plain can with a sticker label.  Pours a clear dark orange copper with a one finger creamy light beige head.  Aroma of piney resiny hops, some toasted and caramel malts with a hint of toffee and vanilla.  Flavor is a little more toasty and resiny, with all the other aromas poking up in the background.  Moderate bitterness at best.  Semidry finish.  The alcohol is very well covered, and it should be noted that my can places this beer at 9.2%, not the 8.7 that is listed on the site.  Low carbonation, full body.  Gauging from the way the hops are, I don¬ít think this is the freshest.  Nonetheless, it seems to be aging good so far.  8-4-7-4-14--3.7
user_location: Ocean Beach, San Diego, California, USA

text: Can shared with HogTownHarry & biegaman -- courtesy of HogTownHarry. Pours a clear amber with an average size diminishing off-white head. Nice aroma of resiny hops and burnt caramel malt -- interesting! Flavour¬ís a more subtle version of the aroma with caramel malt and resiny hops. Alcohol¬ís well hidden. Medium bodied. Very good -- and from a can even!!

Draft. Beautiful amber/red color. Nice sized head that vanished quickly. Sweet fruity, hoppy aroma. The taste was the same. Smooth. Thick full body. Kind of reminded me of Elder. Liquid gold in a can, can you believe they put this in a can!? Got kinda syrupy as it warmed.

By far the most expensive can I¬íve ever seen in a bottle shop. The cheapest I¬íve seen it is $3.50ea. At half the price I¬íd be drinking this beauty all the time. Poured clear clean polished copper with thin tan head. The aroma is pretty big with roasted biscuit, an almost a wood note and sweet tangelo to grapefruit hops. The flavor hits the senses with citrus hops. The moment you have enough time to sense and identify the hops a wide truck load of sweet, roasted and hints of biscuit malts take over the flavor. Yes, sizable malt. Then as the malts recede away the tasty citrus hops re-surface and usher you into the aftertaste.
Tried both on draught and in can.  Both very good.  The draught was very fresh and floral.  Lots of sticky hops.  big beer.
deep golden, it has huge head and is very bitter like dandilioons but flavorful.  medium bodied.

How did they fit so much beer in that tiny can? This is a nice full ale that is almost a Barley Wine in my  book. The hoppiness really shows on the nose and the finish. The middle of the beer is honey like malt that isn¬ít overly sweet. Overall, a nice big ale in a can.

Can.  Ruddy and red with a sticky head.  Aromas of birchwood, coffee, apple, and some hop perfume.  Serious hops, backed by a sweet caramel and soft alcohol notes.  Long bittering hop finish.  Round palate and exceptional weight, yet somehow clean.  Flavors really shine.

Can (12oz).  Shared with blankboy and biegaman, my can - yeah!!!.  Clear amber, solid frothy/creamy head.  Rich aroma of slightly burnt caramel and resin/ light funk hops - wow, that¬ís realy something.  Pretty average IPA taste - herbal/resin hops, caramel malt, not so much carbonized character, hardly any alcohol.  Somewhat syrupy body, light carbonation, slightly sticky/caramel aftertaste - pretty nice, but I think I like the Dale¬ís Pale more.

On tap at Mad Mex Robinson. Pour was a dark gold/orange with no head. Aroma was 100% floral hops. Taste was like a flower basket. I now understand what "floral" hops taste and smell like. Mad Mex list this as an IIPA and could pass as such. Not much other than hops in the taste with a thick mouthfeel.
user_location: Moon Twp, suburb of Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania, USA

text: Can.   Pours a copper color with a medium size beige colored head that almost settles out.   Aroma is sweet malt, pine, grapefruit, floral.   Flavor is nice punch of sweet caramel malt, citrus, pine and floral hops knock at your tonsils, some brown sugar as well.   Palate is medium-full bodied, medium carbonation, sweet, sticky, bitter finish.   Really nice!!

At the 2007 Big Beer, Belgians, & Barleywines Festival in Vail. This was in the limited release canned version at 9.3% ABV.  Pours opaque copper amber with a rich thick fluff of hoppy smelling foam atop this dense beer. Strong orangey sweetness is blended with a bomb of citrus and grapefruit that grabs the tongue and hangs on.

12 oz can from beerandblues2 (thanks!). Says 8.7% abv.  Pours an almost clear dark orange/brown with a large beige head. Nose is citrus and pine. Taste starts with some sweet caramel/crystal maltiness, then the citrusy piney hops lick in. Finish is a very nice bittersweet balance. Medium body. Almost syrupy mouthfeel. Some alcohol in the finish. Very good beer, and it comes in a can!

On tap at Capone¬ís in Norristown...
Appears a semi-transparent dark amber with a light tan head that quickly fades out. Tons of scattered lacing is left around the glass.
Smell is of pine, caramel, grassy, citrus, brown sugar...very sweet in the nose.
Taste is of the mentioned aromas with a bit of a raisin flavor going on in there as well. Again, it¬ís very sweet, even bordering cloying with the pine and brown sugar. Not too bad but not knocking my socks off either.
Mouthfeel is medium bodied, seemingly under-attenuated, fizzy, and sweet.
I was expecting a little more judging from some of the ratings but now that I look at the overall average...I guess my opinion isn¬ít too far off base.

Coppery red clear body, Nice fluffy sticky tan head. Rich flowery hop aroma. Citrus and dry caramel grains. Sweet syrupy aroma.
Flavor is pretty good, but not unique (not that that is bad in this case). Kind of a stale sweet malt covering up a lot of juicy hops. A little unique in that respect, and definitely drinkable.

Clear amber with a huge, dense, off white head. Nose is venomous, floral, resinous, and sweet. All hops and just a hint of grain in the nose. Flavor shows a ton more malt than anticipated. Nearly balanced. Hops are the same plus citrus rind with some graham cracker, cookie, and light caramel malt. Very drinkable. Medium/full body, balanced. If it¬ís warm next weekend, I¬íll be taking a 4 pack to the beach. Very solid.

Darker amber with a large pillowy head, good lacing and retention. Aroma was initially pine, grapefruit, more fruits, caramel, and later showed light vanilla. Flavor brings this, light alcohol as well. Very drinkable and easily the best beer in a can I have ever had.
Amber with nice full head.  Aroma is hops galore with pine domination.  Flavours is hoppy with the pine and spruce and a touch of citrus.  Nice balance of malty bread.  Tasty and a great can of beer.
pours clear copper with small head. fresh sweet pine and grapefruit aroma. nice malty palate with a crisp and chewy mouth full. it is great to have such big goodness in a can!!

UPDATED: MAR 1, 2007 Can. Clear orange-copper with a large head. Good lacing. Aroma of pine resin, citrus rinds, and a fair amount of caramel malt. Incredible malt backbone in the taste. Sticky texture. Spicy and bitter finish. Excellent.

Arizona strong Beer Fest

Big aroma and flavor of pine ,citrus,hops and grapefruit.
Heavy and thick on the palate.
GOOD BEER!

Draft at Capone¬ís.  Turbid deep coppery color with 1-finger off-white head.  Aroma of heavy hops, caramel malt, slight cherry, and slight rauchiness.  The flavor was very hoppy, but very well balanced by a huge malt bill, with notes of slight fruit and pepper.  Dense, very complex palate.  This is an outstanding beer.
7th Annual Strong Beer Festival, Mesa, Az. Can. Grapefruit and pine aromas. Copper body with decent head. Citrus hop flavors refreshed the palate. Good citrus palate cool and crisp.

12-Aug-06  Can at Firemoose¬ís and probably a dozen times since.  This is some pretty expensive stuff but not so out of line these days.  Surely one of the finest aromas of any IIPA I¬íve had in a while with fantastic pine, resin, and mixed citrus all sugar coated by massive caramel malts.  The body is full, sticky, and smacking with every penny of the high price tag.  The palate is long coated with this nectar and finishes more bitter, tacky, and pithy than dry or quick.  Now, call me crazy, but it seems that this beer has changed over the recent months.  The first cans I had were the sublime, full, sticky, and nearly perfect IIPAs I¬íve just described.  These were the can¬ís that first showed up in NJ and had a white adhesive label claiming 9.2 percent abv, but recently new fangled cans have arrived and the beer is absolutely not the same stuff.  Maybe it¬ís just batch inconsistency, but there¬ís also a curious change in that the abv appears to have decreased a half percent in recent months.  I don¬ít know if there¬ís anything to it, but it sure doesn¬ít seem the same to me.  My score reflects the earliest samples I enjoyed, and I¬íll reserve judgment on this newer model until I¬íve had it a few more times.

Definitely a bit pricey, at $4.25 a can¬Ö but worth a try nun the less! 
 The beer pours a rich amber body¬Ö light carbonation, but a massive ivory head. The aroma is explosive! A wallop of hops smacks you right in the face¬Ö the malt bill must be huge because this is one chewy snack. The senses are inundated with caramelized brown sugar, fresh grapefruit and tangerine, pine resin and cedar wood chip spiciness. Overall, I would drink this beer regularly¬Ö if I could afford to do so!

Mmm.....beer in a can.  Already having had Old Chub and Dale¬ís Pale Ale, I know better than to be surprised that there¬ís a quality brew under this pop-top.  The head was big and short-lived.  The aroma is huge with lots of piney hops.  The flavor, though, is a bit of a let-down at first.  Kind of weak, flat and unfulfilling at the start.  The flavors continue to resonate and develop after each sip ultimately making this a good one to sip.

I ranked this beer high in aroma, appearance and palate but the flavor was lacking complexity and fullness so overall it got low marks. Mahogony colored pour with large head. Aromas full of hops, oranges and cherries. Taste is mostly alcohol with a background piney and light fruity and resiny.  The body is very chewy and thick and the finish is alcohol and grapefruity. Not bad at all for a canned beer.

Dark ruby-orange color with a thin white head.  Sniffed the can after opening, before pouring, and got a nosefull of hop aroma.  Real piney and fresh.  Taste begins with sharp resiny hop flavors.  The finish lacks any lingering hop flavor, but the beer is so drinkable, I can¬ít knock it too bad.
Pours a amber orange color with a white head.  Aroma is caramel and lots of grapefruit hops.  Flavor has some nice malts with bitter grassy, grapefruit hops.

It pours a rich amber color with a pretty stable light white head.  Very nice and inviting looking.  Big piney hops aroma, quite monstrous.  Very sharp.  Also has some grapefruit hints and citrus.  Very big taste although the hops arent overwhelming, but still bigger than normal.  Very smooth finish, which I wasnt expecting.  Pretty bitter towards the finish and I get alot of funked out citrus as well.  Hard to imagine canned beer being this good and complex.
The aroma has grapefruit and pine hops along with caramel. The appearance is deep amber with a three finger head. The palate is sticky as advertised. Good beer in a can? Thanks Gordon.

Slightly resiney aroma, some citrus, and caramel.  Pours a dark amber.  Hops are definitely the defining flavor, citrus, pine, spicey, a little alcohol, resin, with a dry hoppy finish with a dash of caramel in there somewhere.

12oz can.  Pours a dark, reddish-amber appearance; fluffy, off-white head with big-bubbled lacing.  Citrus and grapefruit and minerals in the aroma; set against a backdrop of tea-like malts.  Full, chewy mouthfeel: lots of grapefruit and citrus; dank hop presence; wet malts and maple syrup backdrop; well-balanced.  Lengthy, citrus hop and wet malt finish.
Deep amber colour with a tan head. Sweet, close to buttery aroma with a hoppy floral and fruity note. Buttery flavor, seems diacetyl infected.

Can.  Dark orange with a medium sized rocky white head.  Candied citrus and ruddy floral hop aromatics with tinges of buttery malt underneath.  Metallic citric hop character up front, mildly toasty malt follows with a deeper pine hop flavor.  Stale caramel in the finish with some residual toastiness and a lingering earthen hop bitterness and astringency.  Mouthfeel is medium, fairly dry.

can. Poured with a thick frothy head. A fine film remained with a thick edge that stuck to the glass. Lacing was heavy, but thinned as beer warmed. Very attractive color, burnt amber. Strong notes of apricot, with light alcohol and maple wood. Considering the nose to this beer, the taste was surprisingly light. Tasted heavily of hopps with under tones of pine. Felt like heaven in my mouth. Thick and creamy with a wonderfully dry finish. Super Beer!

Another canned beer from Oskar Blues! This one just recently got to the area. I am glad they decided to start canning another beer and not make it a seasonal. Pours a clear dark amber with a nice off-white head on top. Aroma is full of citrus, pine, grapefruit, and cookie malts. The aroma is absolutely fantastic! Flavor is citrus, oranges, pine, and an ending sweetness brought on by the cookie malts. The flavor ends pretty easy on the palate with no big taste of the alcohol or bitterness. The bitterness is more dominant at the first hit of the tongue and balances out nicely. Another great beer from Oskar Blues!

Chocolate brown, half inch of tan head, and hops up one side and down the other. Roasty toasty, and bitter enought to make a hophead smile. Complex and tasty.

Somewhere between a stout and a barleywine. Medium body, soft carbonation, and pine hops in the aftertaste all day long.

Can. Pours deep brown with steady thin white head. Aroma is fantastic. Extremely sweet and hoppy. Candied citrus. Open smooth and settles into a wet bitterness with light carbonation. Perfect thickness. Taste is citrusy hops, bitter like an orange peel, but balanced by the sweetness. Not too complex, but superbly drinkable. Probably the most drinkable 2IPA i¬íve ever had.
